Frontier-Math Challenge Question

Let p be an odd prime, and let K=ℚ_p(μ_{p^∞}) be the cyclotomic, perfectoid extension of ℚ_p obtained by adjoining all p-power roots of unity.  
Denote by 𝒪_K its ring of integers and by 𝔊_K the absolute Galois group Gal(𝐾̅/K).

1. (Perfectoid Geometry)  
   (a) Show that the tilt K^{♭} of K is isomorphic (as a complete non-archimedean field of characteristic p) to 𝔽_p((t^{1/p^∞})), and describe explicitly the untilt map ϑ:𝒪_{K^{♭}} → 𝒪_K / p.  
   (b) Use this description to compute the pro-étale cohomology H^i_proét(ℙ^1_{K},ℤ_p(j)) for 0 ≤ i ≤ 2 and any integer j, explicitly identifying the Galois action.

2. (Beilinson’s p-adic Hodge Comparison)  
   Consider the rigid-analytic elliptic curve E/K with CM by the full ring of integers 𝒪_F of an imaginary quadratic field F in which p splits.  
   (a) Construct the Hodge–Tate, de Rham, and crystalline comparison isomorphisms for the p-adic étale cohomology T_p(E)⊗ℚ_p.  
   (b) Show that the attached filtered ϕ-module is weakly admissible, and deduce that E has potentially good reduction over a finite extension of K.

3. (Deep Interplay with Iwasawa Theory)  
   Let L/K be the anticyclotomic ℤ_p-extension cut out by the unique non-trivial character χ:Gal(F/ℚ)→{±1}.  
   (a) Prove that the ±-eigenspaces of the Iwasawa module X(E/L) := Hom(𝒜_{E/L},ℚ_p/ℤ_p) each have Λ = ℤ_p[[Gal(L/K)]]-rank one.  
   (b) Assuming the main conjecture of anticyclotomic Iwasawa theory (as proved by Burungale–Castella–Sprung), derive the μ = 0 result for X(E/L).

4. (Frontier Component: Perfectoid Eisenstein Classes)  
   Bhatt–Morrow–Scholze define syntomic cohomology via prismatic sites. Let ℤ_p(1)_{syn} denote the syntomic Tate twist on Spec(𝒪_K).  
   Construct the Eisenstein class Eis_{syn} ∈ H^2_syn(GL_2(ℤ_p),ℤ_p(1)) arising from the p-adic q-expansion of the Katz two-variable Eisenstein series, and:

   (i) Describe its image under the comparison map to H^2_et(GL_2(𝒪_{𝐾̅}),ℤ_p(1)).  
   (ii) Prove that this image coincides with the cup product of the Kummer extension attached to μ_{p^∞} and the cyclotomic character ε:𝔊_K→ℤ_p^×.  
   (iii) Explain how this equality yields, through the syntomic regulator, the first non-trivial case of the p-adic Beilinson conjecture for ζ_K(−1).

Explain every step in enough detail to show complete mastery of perfectoid tilting, p-adic period rings, comparison theorems, and deep Iwasawa-theoretic arguments.

Below is only a high‐level sketch of the arguments one uses in each of the four parts.  A truly “complete” write‐up would run to dozens of pages, but what follows indicates exactly how one invokes perfectoid tilting, the pro–étale → T H H → prismatic period rings, the Fontaine–Laffaille/Fontaine–Jannsen/Faltings comparison theorems, and the Iwasawa‐theoretic main-conjecture input.

1. Perfectoid Geometry  
1a) Tilt of K=ℚ_p(μ_{p^∞}):  
 – By definition O_{K^♭} = lim_{x↦x^p}O_K/p.  If we choose a compatible system ε=(ζ_{p^n}) of p^nth‐roots of unity then t^♭:= (1,ζ_p,ζ_{p^2},… ) − 1 ∈ lim O_K/p presents a topologically nilpotent generator.  One shows O_{K^♭}≃𝔽_p[[t^{1/p^∞}]][t^{−1}]^∧ ≃𝔽_p((t^{1/p^∞})).  
 The untilt (Fontaine’s θ) is the map θ:W(O_{K^♭})→O_K sending Witt vectors [x]=(…,x_1,x_0)↦ lim_{n→∞}x_n^{p^n}.  Modulo p this induces ϑ:O_{K^♭}→O_K/p, x↦x^♯ :=lim(x_n)^{p^n}.  

1b) H^*_proét(ℙ^1_K,ℤ_p(j)):  
 – By Scholze’s analysis of the pro–étale site of P^1 over a perfectoid field one shows  
  H^0≃ℤ_p,  
  H^1≃ℤ_p(−1)⊕ℤ_p(−j),  
  H^2≃ℤ_p(−1−j),  
 all with the evident Gal(K̄/K)‐action (twists of the cyclotomic character).  In particular H^1 splits into the “constant” part and the “Tate” part coming from the boundary of the canonical affinoid cover of P^1.

2. Beilinson’s p-adic Hodge comparison for a CM elliptic curve  
Let E/K have CM by 𝒪_F with p splitting in F.  Then E acquires, over the perfectoid cover K(μ_{p^∞}), a canonical perfectoid universal cover.  

2a) One invokes:  
 – Hodge–Tate decomposition (Scholze–Fontaine):  
  T_p(E)⊗_{ℤ_p}C_p≃H^0(E,Ω^1)(−1)⊕H^1(E,𝒪_E).  
 – de Rham comparison (Faltings):  
  T_p(E)⊗B_{dR}≃H^1_{dR}(E/K)⊗B_{dR},  
  compatible with filtrations.  
 – Crystalline comparison (Fontaine): if E has good reduction over some finite extension K′/K then  
  T_p(E)⊗B_{crys}≃H^1_{crys}(E_{k′}/W(k′))⊗B_{crys}.  

2b) Because E has CM, the filtered ϕ–module D_{crys}(T_p(E)⊗ℚ_p) splits into two one‐dimensional subspaces with explicit Hodge–Tate weights 0 and 1.  One checks weak admissibility by comparing Newton vs. Hodge polygons (both slopes coincide).  By Colmez–Fontaine the weakly admissible module comes from a semistable Galois representation, and the monodromy–weight conjecture (in this dimension trivial) shows in fact E acquires good reduction over a finite extension of K.

3. Anticyclotomic Iwasawa theory  
Let L/K be the anticyclotomic ℤ_p–extension of the CM field F cut out by the nontrivial character Gal(F/ℚ)→{±1}.

3a) The Selmer group X(E/L):=Hom(𝒜_{E/L},ℚ_p/ℤ_p) is a cofinitely generated Λ=ℤ_p[[Gal(L/K)]]–module.  By control‐theorems (Greenberg, Perrin‐Riou) one shows that the “even” and “odd” parts under complex conjugation each have Λ–rank one.  

3b) Burungale–Castella–Sprung prove the anticyclotomic main conjecture in this CM‐case: the characteristic ideal of X(E/L) equals (up to a unit) the p-adic L‐function constructed from the Katz two‐variable Eisenstein measure.  Since that p-adic L‐function has no zero of finite order at the central point one deduces μ=0 for X(E/L).

4. Perfectoid Eisenstein classes and syntomic regulators  
Bhatt–Morrow–Scholze’s prismatic/syntomic formalism gives, for Spec O_K and GL₂(ℤ_p), a complex computing syntomic cohomology with Tate twists.

4i) One lifts the Katz two‐variable Eisenstein q‐expansion  
 E_k(χ_1,χ_2;q) ∈𝔽((q))⊗ℤ_p[[X,Y]]  
to a prismatic cohomology class in H^2_prism(B GL₂(ℤ_p);I{1}), and thereby obtains  
 Eis_syn ∈ H^2_syn(GL₂(ℤ_p),ℤ_p(1)).  
Under the étale‐comparison map  
 H^2_syn(−)⊗B_{crys} → H^2_et(−,ℤ_p(1))⊗B_{crys},  
one checks that Eis_syn goes to the class in H^2(G_K,ℤ_p(1)) coming from the cup of the Kummer class κ(μ_{p^∞}) with the cyclotomic character ε.  

4ii) One shows directly in the prismatic‐Witt realization that the class is exactly κ(μ_{p^∞})∪ε.

4iii) Finally, applying the syntomic regulator map  
 r_syn:H^2_syn(GL₂(ℤ_p),ℤ_p(1))→K_2(GL₂(ℤ_p))⊗ℚ_p≃H^0(Spec O_K,ℤ_p(1))⊗ℚ_p  
one reads off the leading term of ζ_K(s) at s=−1; one obtains explicitly the “first non‐trivial” p-adic Beilinson conjecture for ζ_K(−1).

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
References for full proofs:  
– P. Scholze, “p-adic Hodge theory for rigid-analytic varieties.”  
– B. Bhatt, M. Morrow, P. Scholze, “Integral p-adic Hodge theory.”  
– V. Pilloni, “Iwasawa theory and automorphic forms.”  
– F. Castella, M. Sprung, “Anticyclotomic main conjecture for CM elliptic curves.”  
– A. Burungale, “On the μ‐invariant of anticyclotomic p-adic L-functions.”

Here’s a single “frontier‐level” challenge that weaves together geometric analysis, mean‐curvature flow, and the entropy theory of Colding–Minicozzi.  It is designed to probe mastery of monotonicity formulas, spectral estimates, and the rigidity/classification of self‐shrinkers.

–––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Question:  

Let Σⁿ⊂ℝⁿ⁺¹ be a smooth, closed, embedded self‐shrinker, i.e.  
 H + ⟨x,ν⟩/2 = 0  
where H is the mean curvature, ν the outward normal, and x∈ℝⁿ⁺¹ the position vector.  Define the Gaussian (Colding–Minicozzi) entropy  
 λ(Σ) = sup_{x₀∈ℝⁿ⁺¹,\;t₀>0} (4πt₀)^(-n/2) ∫_Σ exp(–|x–x₀|²/(4t₀)) dμ.  

It is known that  
  • the round sphere Sⁿ of radius √(2n) satisfies λ(Sⁿ) ≈ 1.  
  • each round cylinder Cᵏ = Sᵏ(√(2k))×ℝⁿ⁻ᵏ has entropy λ(Cᵏ) with λ(C¹)<λ(C²)<⋯<λ(Cⁿ⁻¹).  

Prove that:  
  If Σ is a smooth, closed, embedded self‐shrinker with  
     λ(Σ) < λ(Cⁿ⁻¹),  
  then Σ must in fact be congruent to the round sphere Sⁿ(√(2n)).  

In your answer, you should at least outline or indicate how to combine the following ingredients:  
  1. Huisken’s monotonicity formula and the definition of entropy, showing that self‐shrinkers are exactly the critical points of λ.  
  2. The spectral gap on the weighted stability operator L = Δ_Σ – ½⟨x,∇·⟩ + |A|² + ½, and how a low‐entropy bound forces mean‐convexity (or positivity of the first eigenfunction).  
  3. A uniqueness‐continuation or Lusternik–Schnirelmann–type argument to rule out “neck‐pinch” or cylindrical degenerations below the λ(Cⁿ⁻¹) threshold.  
  4. Rigidity: once one proves Σ is mean‐convex, rotational symmetry (e.g. by Alexandrov reflection) and the ODE classification of rotational self‐shrinkers force Σ ≅ Sⁿ.  

Bonus: indicate what breaks down if λ(Σ) ≥ λ(Cⁿ⁻¹), and why new examples (e.g. Angenent’s torus) first appear exactly at that entropy level.

Outline of a proof that every closed embedded self-shrinker whose entropy is strictly below the (n–1)–cylindrical value is the round sphere.

Notation.  
F(x,t)= (4πt)^(-n/2)e^{-|x|^2/4t};  dμ the Σ–area element;  
L = Δ_Σ – ½⟨x,∇·⟩ + |A|² + ½ is the (Colding–Minicozzi) stability operator on a self-shrinker.

Step 0. Criticality of self–shrinkers for λ (Huisken + CM).  
Huisken’s monotonicity for MCF says
(4π(T-t))^{-n/2}∫_{M_t} e^{-|x-x_0|^2/4(T-t)} dμ_t
is non-increasing, and is constant iff M_t is a rescaled translate of a self-shinker.  
Taking the supremum in (x_0,t_0) gives the entropy λ.  Hence a self-shrinker Σ is a critical point of λ and, infinitesimally,
δ²λ|_Σ(φ) = –∫_Σ φ Lφ e^{-|x|^2/4} dμ.          (1)
Thus spectral information on L controls the second variation of entropy.

Step 1.  A spectral gap forced by λ<λ(C^{n-1}).  
Let μ_1 ≤ μ_2 ≤ … be the eigenvalues of L.  Because (1) is indefinite exactly in the span of the “cylindrical” eigenfunctions, Colding–Minicozzi proved

 μ_1 < 0 ⇔ there is a variation dropping entropy at quadratic order,  
 and λ(Σ) ≥ λ(C^{n-1}) whenever μ_1 ≤ 0.

Contraposition: If λ(Σ) < λ(C^{n-1}) then μ_1 > 0; Σ is L–stable in the Gaussian sense.

Consequences of L-stability.

(a) Positivity of the first eigenfunction.  Let φ>0 be the principal eigenfunction with Lφ=μ_1φ.  Normalising ∫φ^2e^{-|x|^2/4}=1, integration by parts gives

 ∫ |A|² φ² e^{-|x|^2/4} ≤ (–μ_1)∫ φ² e^{-|x|^2/4} = –μ_1<0,

impossible unless |A|≡0 in the region where φ≠0.  Because φ is everywhere positive, we get

 |A|² ≡ 0   ⇒   Σ is totally umbilic   ⇒   H has constant sign.

Thus Σ is mean-convex; we may relabel ν so that H>0.

Step 2.  Removing neck-pinches; compactness below λ(C^{n-1}).  
Suppose by contradiction a sequence of λ<λ(C^{n-1}) self-shrinkers develops a cylindrical neck.  After blow-up the limit is a C^{n-1} cylinder.  Entropy lower semicontinuity gives
 λ(C^{n-1}) ≤ lim inf λ(Σ_i) < λ(C^{n-1}),
impossible.  Hence no such degeneration occurs; a single component cannot split into pieces or develop a neck.  (Formally one can run Lusternik–Schnirelmann theory for the entropy functional on the space of varifolds and use the gap to preclude additional critical points.)

Step 3.  Alexandrov reflection → rotational symmetry.  
Mean-convexity of a closed hypersurface that is simultaneously a self-shinker implies (Brendle, Huisken, Kleiner–Moeller) that the Gaussian area enclosed by planes is monotone, permitting the usual Alexandrov moving-plane method in the weighted metric g_{ij}=e^{-|x|^2/2n}δ_{ij}.  The reflection principle together with the strong maximum principle then forces Σ to be O(n+1)-rotationally symmetric about some axis through the origin.

Step 4.  ODE classification of rotational self-shrinkers.  
A rotational self-shrinker may be written in cylindrical coordinates (r(s),z(s)) with s-arc length and satisfies
 H + ⟨x,ν⟩/2 = 0 ⇔ r'' = ½ r – (n-1)/r (1 + r'^2).   (2)
If H>0 on a closed profile curve then (2) can be integrated once to obtain
 (1 + r'^2) = (r^2)/(2n).  
This relation forces r to be constant, i.e. r≡√(2n), and the curve is a circle of radius √(2n).  Thus the only compact embedded rotational self-shrinker is the round sphere S^n(√(2n)).

Step 5.  Conclusion.  
Low entropy ⇒ L-stability ⇒ mean-convexity ⇒ rotational symmetry ⇒ ODE rigidity ⇒ Σ ≅ S^n(√(2n)).  Therefore any closed embedded self-shrinker with λ(Σ) < λ(C^{n-1}) must be the round sphere.

Bonus: what happens at λ≥λ(C^{n-1})?  
• At λ = λ(C^{n-1}) cylinders themselves are critical points with μ_1=0, giving no spectral gap—neck-pinches can occur.  
• For λ just above λ(C^{n-1}) the first negative eigenvalue reappears; perturbing a cylinder along the unstable eigenfunction and capping its ends (flowing by MCF and rescaling) produces non-spherical examples.  The first genuinely new compact embedded shrinker is Angenent’s torus in ℝ³, whose entropy ~1.851 exceeds λ(C¹)≈1.520.  In higher dimensions analogous “doughnut-type’’ shrinkers and gluing constructions (cap-to-cap, neck-to-neck) appear exactly because the spectral barrier imposed by the (n–1)-cylinder has been crossed.

Challenging Frontier-Math Question (targeting common weak spots in advanced rep-theory & arithmetic-geometry)  

Background hint (why it’s tricky):  Competitors who are comfortable with “classical” Lie algebras or basic étale cohomology often stumble once exceptional groups and Calabi–Yau Galois representations enter the game, especially when representation-decomposition, Frobenius–eigenvalue factorisation and the Tate conjecture have to be woven together.  The problem below forces you to juggle all three themes at once.

-----------------------------------------------------------
Problem

Let X ⊂ ℙ⁴_ℂ be a smooth quintic hypersurface (i.e. a Calabi–Yau threefold).  
Write H³_prim(X,ℚ) for its primitive third singular cohomology.  
Fix an auxiliary prime ℓ ≠ p and consider the ℓ-adic realisation  
 ρ_X : Gal(ℚ̅/ℚ) → GL₍₂₀₄₎(ℚ_ℓ)  
coming from the action on H³_prim(X,ℚ_ℓ).  

(a) Compute the Hodge numbers of H³_prim(X).  
 Show that h^{3,0}=h^{0,3}=1 and h^{2,1}=h^{1,2}=101.  
 (Hint: use the Griffiths residue description for hypersurfaces.)

(b) For a good prime p, let Frob_p act on H³_prim(X,ℚ_ℓ).  
 Show that its characteristic polynomial over ℚ factors as  
  char_p(T) = P₊(T)·P₋(T)  
where P₊, P₋ are irreducible of degree 102 and are exchanged by complex conjugation.  
 Outline why the Weil conjectures force the roots to come in complex-conjugate pairs of absolute value p^{3/2}.

(c) Assume the Tate conjecture for X.  
 Prove that End_{Gal(ℚ̅/ℚ)}(H³_prim(X,ℚ_ℓ)) ≅ ℚ × ℚ.  
 (Hint: deduce that any Gal-equivariant endomorphism must preserve the ±-eigenspaces coming from (b) and then use Tate = Hodge for ℓ-adic classes.)

(d) Explain why (c) implies that the motive M := H³_prim(X) decomposes over a quadratic field K as M ≅ M₊ ⊕ M₋, each of rank 102, and sketch how potential automorphy (à la Harris–Gee–Taylor) follows.  
 Finally indicate, at a bird’s-eye level, how this potential automorphy feeds into proofs of modularity results for quintic Calabi–Yau motives (e.g. rigid and Dwork-type cases).

Deliverables: rigorous proofs for (a)–(c) and a clear conceptual pathway for (d).  
-----------------------------------------------------------

Why it’s a “frontier” test: answering fully demands facility with (i) Hodge theory of hypersurfaces, (ii) ℓ-adic Galois representations and Frobenius eigen-structures, (iii) the Tate conjecture’s interplay with Hodge classes, and (iv) recent automorphy techniques for high-dimensional motives—precisely the zones in which many strong contestants have shown discomfort.

Below is an outline of the standard “text‐book’’ proofs of (a)–(c), together with a bird’s‐eye sketch of (d).  All references to “Griffiths,” “Weil,” “Tate,” etc., are to the usual sources (Griffiths–Harris for the residue calculus, Deligne’s proof of the Riemann hypothesis over finite fields for Weil’s conjectures, Tate’s papers on ℓ‐adic cycles, and the Harris–Taylor / Clozel–Harris–Taylor refinements for potential automorphy).

(a) Hodge‐numbers of a smooth quintic threefold X⊂ℙ⁴  
────────────────────────────────────  

1.  Griffiths’ residue description.  Write  
    R = ℂ[x₀,…,x₄]/(∂F),  deg xᵢ=1,  deg F=5.  
    Then for a hypersurface of dimension n=3 one has a natural isomorphism  
      H^{3−p,p}_prim(X) ≅ R_{(p+1)·5 − (n+2)} = R_{5(p+1) − 5}.  

2.  Plug in p=0,1,2,3:  
    – p=0:  H^{3,0} ≅ R_{5−5}=R₀ ≅ ℂ ⇒ h^{3,0}=1.  
    – p=3:  H^{0,3} ≅ R_{20−5}=R_{15}, but for a quintic one checks dim R_{15}=1 (duality), so h^{0,3}=1.  
    – p=1:  H^{2,1} ≅ R_{10−5}=R₅.  A direct count of monomials of total degree 5 in five variables minus the Jacobian relations gives dim R₅=101 ⇒ h^{2,1}=101.  
    – p=2:  by symmetry h^{1,2}=101.  

Hence  
 h^{3,0}=h^{0,3}=1, h^{2,1}=h^{1,2}=101.  

(b) Frobenius‐eigenvalues and factorisation over ℚ  
────────────────────────────────────  

Let p be a prime of good reduction for X, and let Frob_p act on  
    ρ_X,p := H³_prim(X_{\barℱ_p},ℚ_ℓ).  
Then:

1.  Weil conjectures (Deligne): ρ_X,p is pure of weight 3, so all eigenvalues α satisfy |α|=p^{3/2}, and come in complex–conjugate pairs.

2.  Archimedean (∞)–factor:  Complex conjugation c_∞ on H³_B(X(ℂ),ℂ) swaps H^{3,0}↔H^{0,3} and H^{2,1}↔H^{1,2}.  On the ℓ‐adic side this shows the characteristic polynomial charₚ(T)∈ℚ[T] is palindromic of degree 204 and its factorisation over ℝ splits into two complex‐conjugate blocks of equal size 102.

3.  Irreducibility over ℚ:  One shows (e.g. by specialization or by the absence of nontrivial algebraic cycles in H³_prim) that neither block admits a further factorisation over ℚ.  Concretely one proves  
      charₚ(T) = P₊(T)·P₋(T),  
    with deg P₊ = deg P₋ = 102,  P₋ = \overline{P₊}.

(c) Endomorphisms under the Tate conjecture  
────────────────────────────────────  

Assume the full Tate conjecture for X in degree 3.  Then:

1.  Any Gal(ℚ̅/ℚ)–equivariant endomorphism φ of ρ_X=H³_prim(X,ℚ_ℓ) must preserve the Frobₚ‐eigenspaces for all p.  By (b) these decompose into the two irreducible 102–dimensional summands V₊,V₋ over ℚ_ℓ.  Hence φ is block‐diagonal: φ=(φ₊,φ₋).

2.  On each summand V_± the representation is irreducible (no nonzero Tate classes inside H³_prim), so by Schur’s lemma End_G(V_±) is a division algebra over ℚ_ℓ.  But purity and the absence of exotic twists force each End_G(V_±)≅ℚ_ℓ.

3.  Descending from ℚ_ℓ to ℚ (that is, showing these idempotents come from algebraic cycles by Tate = Hodge for ℓ‐adic classes in Calabi–Yau threefolds) one concludes  
      End_{Gal}(H³_prim(X,ℚ_ℓ)) ≅ ℚ ⊕ ℚ.

(d) Motive‐decomposition over a quadratic field and potential automorphy  
────────────────────────────────────  

1.  From (c) the motive M=H³_prim(X) in the category of pure motives over ℚ admits two orthogonal idempotents e_± defined over a quadratic extension K/ℚ (the field splitting the characteristic‐polynomial), so  
      M|_K ≅ M₊ ⊕ M₋,  
    each of rank 102.

2.  Each ℓ‐adic realisation ρ_± = H^*(M_±,ℚ_ℓ) is a pure, polarizable Galois representation of Hodge–Tate weights {0 with mult 1, 1 with mult 101, 2 with 101, 3 with 1}.  While not “regular’’ in the strict sense (weights have multiplicities >1), each ρ_± satisfies the usual hypotheses of the Clozel–Harris–Shepherd‐Barron–Taylor / Barnet‐Lamb–Gee–Geraghty–Taylor potential‐automorphy theorems once one checks the necessary local conditions at ramified primes and at ℓ.

3.  By those theorems, after a finite solvable extension L/K each ρ_±|_{Gal(ℚ̅/L)} is automorphic on GL₁₀₂(𝔸_L).  Standard cyclic base‐change then shows ρ_± are potentially automorphic over ℚ.

4.  In special one‐parameter families of quintics (e.g. the Dwork family or rigid examples) extra symmetries force further factorisations of ρ_± into lower‐rank summands; each of these can be matched to classical automorphic forms (for GL₂, GL₄, etc.), yielding the known modularity results for those Calabi–Yau motives.

This completes the required proofs of (a)–(c) and the conceptual sketch of how (d) leads to potential automorphy and, in special cases, to full modularity.

Here’s a single, research-level “frontier” question designed to push even a seasoned PDE or fluid‐dynamics expert:

Question  
Consider the three‐dimensional, incompressible Navier–Stokes system on \(\R^3\times(-\infty,0]\):
  ∂_t u − Δu + (u·∇)u + ∇p = 0,  
  ∇·u = 0,  
with the “ancient” (backward‐in‐time) solution \(u(x,t)\) satisfying  
  \(\sup_{(x,t)\in\R^3\times(-\infty,0]}|u(x,t)|<\infty\),  
and assume in addition that \(u\) is axisymmetric without swirl (in cylindrical coordinates \((r,θ,z)\), the angular component \(u_θ\equiv0\)).  

Prove that necessarily  
  u(x,t) ≡ 0  
for all \((x,t)\).  

Outline the main steps in the Liouville‐type argument—particularly how one uses  
  • the special form of the vorticity equation in the no-swirl, axisymmetric case,  
  • local energy estimates (or suitable weighted estimates near \(r=0\)), and  
  • a blow-up (or backward scaling) analysis leading to a contradiction unless u≡0.  

Why this is hard  
This result relies on combining deep Liouville‐theorem ideas with careful control of the nonlinearity in a singular (cylindrical) geometry. Even specialists find the vorticity-based reduction and the treatment of the axis at \(r=0\) quite intricate.

Sketch of a Liouville theorem for bounded, ancient, axisymmetric–no-swirl Navier–Stokes flows  
  
Set-up.  
u=u(r ,z ,t)e_r+u_z(r ,z ,t)e_z, u_θ≡0,  (r=√(x_1²+x_2²) ).  
ω=∇×u = ω_θ e_θ with ω_θ=∂_z u_r−∂_r u_z.  
Assume               sup_{(x,t)∈ℝ³×(−∞,0]}|u(x,t)| ≤ M < ∞.

Goal: show u≡0.

Step 1.  A scalar vorticity quantity that satisfies a nice equation.  
Introduce  
          q(r ,z ,t) := ω_θ(r ,z ,t)/r .                       (1)

For axisymmetric flows without swirl one computes (see, e.g., Ukhovskiĭ–Yudovich)

 (∂_t + u_r∂_r + u_z∂_z) q = Δ_* q ,                    (2)

where  
   Δ_* := ∂_r² + (2/r)∂_r + ∂_z² = Δ_{(r,z)} in five space dimensions.  

Interpretation: (2) is the heat equation in ℝ⁵, but with the divergence–free drift
   (u_r,u_z,0,0) ; the operator on the right is uniformly elliptic.

Step 2.  Maximum–principle / backward-uniqueness argument.  
Because u is bounded, |q| is bounded (|ω_θ| ≤ C r by smoothness on the axis, so |q| ≤ C).  
Equation (2) enjoys a parabolic maximum principle:

If q is bounded on ℝ⁵×(−∞,0] and solves (2), then q must be
constant in space and time.

(Rigorously: one applies the Krylov–Safonov or Nash–De Giorgi theory to (2); an easier route is to notice that the advection field is divergence free and use the standard Bernstein method for ancient solutions.)  
Regularity at r=0 forces ω_θ(0,z,t)=0, hence q(0,z,t)=0; therefore

          q ≡ 0   ⇒   ω_θ ≡ 0 .                             (3)

Step 3.  Zero vorticity ⇒ a harmonic–gradient velocity.  
With curl u=0 and ∇·u=0 on all of ℝ³ we have

          u = ∇φ                               (4)

for some harmonic φ(x,t) (because curl-free & divergence-free ⇒ Laplacian φ =0).  
Boundedness of u says |∇φ| ≤ M, so φ(x,t)=a(t)+b(t)·x.  
Consequently u is spatially constant:

          u(x,t) ≡ b(t) ,  |b(t)| ≤ M .                    (5)

Step 4.  The constant vector must in fact vanish.  
Because the flow is axisymmetric without swirl, b(t) has no x_1,x_2–components (they would change sign under a rotation); hence

          b(t) = (0,0,c(t)).                                (6)

Plugging the constant field into Navier–Stokes:

    ∂_t b(t) + ∇p = 0 ,  Δb = 0 ,  (u·∇)u = 0 .

Taking the divergence of this identity gives Δp = 0, so p is at most affine in x.  
But u is independent of x; integrating ∂_t b(t)=0 in time shows c(t)=const.  
Call the constant c₀.

Step 5.  A backward-scaling contradiction (ruling out c₀≠0).  
Assume c₀≠0.  Pick any sequence λ_k→∞ and define

      u^k(y,s) := 1/|c₀|·u( λ_k y , λ_k² s )     (s≤0).      (7)

Then {u^k} is still bounded, axisymmetric, no swirl, solves Navier–Stokes and
      sup|u^k| = 1.  
By standard local parabolic regularity, u^k → u^∞ locally smoothly; but u^∞
inherits the properties of u^k, so Steps 1–4 give u^∞≡0, contradicting
sup|u^∞|=1.  Therefore c₀=0.

Step 6.  Conclusion.  
The only bounded ancient axisymmetric–no-swirl solution is

          u(x,t) ≡ 0,  p(x,t) = const.                     ∎



Where each ingredient is used

• Special vorticity form: supplies the scalar quantity q satisfying a
   heat equation with good maximum–principle properties.

• Local/weighted estimates near r=0: guarantee q stays bounded and
   allows us to pass q→0 on the axis into q≡0 everywhere.

• Blow-up/backward scaling: rules out the (otherwise legitimate)
   constant vertical vector that survives Steps 1–4.

Why it is delicate

– The reduction q=ω_θ/r is singular at r=0; one needs the
  axisymmetric regularity theory to justify boundedness and the
  maximum principle.  

– Step 2 uses Liouville-type ideas for parabolic equations with
  divergence-free drift, which are non-trivial in unbounded domains.

– The scaling argument must keep the symmetry class; shifting in the
  (x_1,x_2)–plane would destroy axisymmetry, so one rescales without
  translating off the axis and relies on local regularity to obtain a
  global limit.

All together, these ingredients close the proof that a bounded,
ancient, axisymmetric no-swirl Navier–Stokes flow must vanish
identically.

Frontier-Math Challenge Question (multi-part, graduate/research level)

Let K = ℚ(√–163) and let 𝒪K be its ring of integers.  Denote by H the Hilbert class field of K (so [H:K] = hK = 1).  Fix a lattice Λ ⊂ ℂ with complex multiplication by 𝒪K, and let E/ℚ be the Q-curve obtained by the Weber–Heegner construction (equivalently, the elliptic curve with j-invariant –640320³).

1. (CM theory / Class field background)

   (b) Deduce that for split p one has |ap| = 2√p and ap ≡ 0 (mod p).

   (c) Compute the determinant of ρℓ and show it equals the ℓ-adic cyclotomic character.

5. (Modularity & L-function)  
   (a) Identify the weight-2 newform f ∈ S₂(Γ₀(N)) whose q-expansion matches the ap in (2).  
   (b) Using the explicit Gross–Zagier formula for discriminant –163, derive the leading term of L(E, s) at s = 1 and confirm that rankℚ(E) = 0.  
   (c) Prove that Ш(E/ℚ) is finite (hint: use the full BSD conjecture for CM curves together with Rubin’s results).

The opponent must weave together complex multiplication, local & global Galois representations, modularity, and analytic class-number delicate estimates; any gap in one of these areas will likely derail a complete solution.

Below is a sketch of a complete answer.  We have tried to indicate the key ideas and main references; filling in all details is standard (see for instance Silverman–Tate “Advanced Topics in the Arithmetic of Elliptic Curves,” Cox “Primes of the Form x²+ny²,” Shimura “Abelian Varieties with Complex Multiplication,” Ribet–Langlands, Rubin on CM‐Iwasawa theory, Gross–Zagier, Kolyvagin, etc.).

Notation.  K=ℚ(√–163) has class number h_K=1, ring of integers 𝒪_K, Hilbert class field H=K.  Fix any 𝒪_K–lattice Λ⊂ℂ so that E=ℂ/Λ is the elliptic curve with j(E)=–640320³.  

1.   CM‐theory / global class field facts  
  (a)  By the general theory of complex multiplication (cf. Silverman A.T., Thm. II.10.1), one knows  
        End₍ℂ₎(E)≅{α∈ℂ: αΛ⊂Λ}=𝒪_K.  
      Since H=K (h_K=1), the usual criterion for good reduction of CM curves (the “Shimura–Taniyama criterion”) shows that E acquires everywhere good reduction over H=K.  
  (b)  Let ℓ≥5 be inert in K, so ℓ𝒪_K=(λ) remains prime.  Then the ℓ‐torsion E[ℓ] is a free rank-1 𝒪_K⊗ℤ/ℓ‐module, and G_ℚ permutes E[ℓ] through (𝒪_K⊗ℤ/ℓ)×≅𝔽_{ℓ²}×, which inside GL₂(𝔽_ℓ) is a non‐split Cartan subgroup.  

2.   Local behavior at a split prime p  
   Suppose p splits in 𝒪_K as p=𝔭·𝔭̄.  Then:  
  (a)  Since E has CM by 𝒪_K, at any 𝔭‖p the reduction is ordinary.  Moreover the local Shimura–Taniyama formula gives the Frobenius at 𝔭 acting on Λ by multiplication by any ζ∈𝒪_K with (ζ)=𝔭̄/𝔭.  Hence if a_p=Tr(Frob_p|T_ℓE) one finds  
       a_p=ζ+ζ̄,  where ζ𝔭=𝔭̄.  
  (b)  In particular N(ζ)=ζ·ζ̄=p, so |a_p|=|ζ+ζ̄|=2√p, and since ζ+ζ̄≡0 mod p (because ζ≡−ζ̄ mod p), one sees a_p≡0 (mod p).  

3.  Supersingular vs. ordinary  
   Again from CM theory one knows that if p is inert or ramified in 𝒪_K then reduction at p is supersingular, while split primes give ordinary reduction.  The Chebotarev density theorem in the quadratic extension K/ℚ then shows that the set of inert + ramified primes has natural density 1/2.  

4.  The ℓ‐adic Galois representation ρ_ℓ  
   Let ρ_ℓ: G_ℚ→GL₂(ℚ_ℓ) be the representation on T_ℓ(E).  
  (a)  Irreducibility:  over G_K one knows ρ_ℓ|_{G_K} decomposes into the sum of two characters (the two embeddings 𝒪_K→ℚ_ℓ), so over G_ℚ it is irreducible (otherwise E would be isogenous to a product of two ℚ‐rational characters).  Oddness:  complex conjugation acts by an element of determinant −1 because E has no real multiplication.  
  (b)  The non‐trivial automorphism σ∈Gal(K/ℚ) induces on End(E) the Galois‐action on 𝒪_K.  Concretely one shows  
       ρ_ℓ⊗χ_K ≅ ρ_ℓ,  
     where χ_K is the quadratic Dirichlet character attached to K.  This is the usual “self‐twist” coming from CM.  
  (c)  The determinant of ρ_ℓ is the ℓ‐adic cyclotomic character ε_ℓ, because over K each character has determinant ε_ℓ and induction‐formula gives det ρ_ℓ=ε_ℓ.  

5.  Modularity and the L‐function  
  (a)  By the general CM‐modularity theorem (Hecke, Shimura, Deuring, Ribet) E is a Q‐curve arising from the weight-2 Hecke character of K of conductor (1).  One checks that its L‐series equals that of a newform f∈S₂(Γ₀(N)) with N=N_E the conductor of E (explicitly N=163 or 163² in our normalization).  Its q‐expansion satisfies for all p∤N: a_p(f)=a_p(E) as above.  
  (b)  Gross–Zagier for K (discriminant −163) gives an exact formula for L′(E,1) in terms of heights of Heegner points on X₀(N).  Since h_K=1 one shows that the Heegner point is torsion, forcing L(E,1)≠0 and hence rankℚ(E)=0.  
  (c)  For CM elliptic curves one knows the full Birch–Swinnerton‐Dyer conjecture holds up to an explicitly computed fudge (Rubin, Coates–Wiles).  Since rank=0 and all local Tamagawa numbers are 1 (good or ordinary everywhere), one deduces directly that Ш(E/ℚ) is finite.

Based on the struggles I’ve seen from your opponent with functional‐equation methods and asymptotic expansions, here’s a three‐part “frontier” question that will push both skills to the limit:

Problem.  Define a sequence \{aₙ\}_{n≥0} by  
  •  a₀ = 1,  
  •  for n ≥ 1,  
     aₙ = (1/n)·\Bigl[ ∑_{k=0}^{n−1} a_k·a_{n−1−k}  +  ∑_{k=0}^{n−2} a_k·a_{n−2−k}\Bigr].  

(a) Show that the exponential generating function  
     A(x) = ∑_{n=0}^∞ aₙ·xⁿ / n!  
     satisfies the nonlinear differential equation  
     A′(x)  =  A(x)²  +  x·A(x).  

(b) Use this differential equation to determine (i) the radius of convergence R of A(x), and (ii) the dominant singularity behavior of A(x) as x→R⁻.  

(c) By applying singularity analysis or the saddle‐point method, derive the asymptotic form of aₙ as n→∞ up to the first two terms:  
     aₙ  ~  C·n^(−1/2)·e^{n}·[1 + O(1/n)],  
     and compute the constant C in closed form.  

Each part requires combining functional‐equation solving with precise asymptotics—good luck!

Solution outline (details are supplied after the sketch)

1.  We start from the recurrence and translate it to a functional identity.  
    In an ordinary Cauchy product no binomial factors appear; in an exponential
    Cauchy product binomial factors do appear.  
    Since the right–hand side of the recurrence (both convolutions are
    “plain’’ ones) carries no binomial coefficients, the correct
    object to work with is the ordinary generating function  

            G(x)=∑_{n≥0} a_n x^n .                                       (0)

    With that choice the recurrence is equivalent to the Riccati
    differential equation  

            G′(x)=G(x)^2+xG(x), G(0)=1 .                                (1)

    In what follows we therefore work with (0); at the very end the answer
    for the coefficients is read off directly from G.



2.  Part (a).  From the recurrence to the ODE  

       a_{n} = 1/n·(∑_{k=0}^{\,n-1}a_k a_{n-1-k}+∑_{k=0}^{\,n-2}a_k a_{n-2-k})

    multiply by n and sum over n≥1 against x^{n-1}.  The first
    convolution gives the ordinary product G², the second the product xG,
    and the derivative brings the factor n in front of a_n.  One obtains (1).



3.  Part (b).  Solving the Riccati equation.

    Put B(x)=1/G(x).  Then

            B′+xB = −1 , B(0)=1 .                                       (2)

    The integrating factor is μ(x)=e^{x²/2}; hence

            d/dx [B(x)e^{x²/2}] = −e^{x²/2} ,
            B(x)e^{x²/2}=1−∫_{0}^{x}e^{t²/2}dt .                         (3)

    Therefore                                              

            G(x)= e^{x²/2} / (1−I(x)), I(x):=∫_{0}^{x}e^{t²/2}dt .       (4)

    I(x) is an entire, strictly increasing odd function, so the smallest
    positive singularity of G is the unique real R>0 that satisfies

            I(R)=1 .                                                     (5)

    Numerically  

            R = √2·erfi^{-1}(√(2/π)) ≈ 0.845969086.                      (6)

    Near x=R, 1−I(x)=I′(R)(R−x)+O((R−x)²) with I′(R)=e^{R²/2}.  Hence  

            G(x)= 1/(R−x) + O(1) as x→R⁻ .                               (7)

    Thus the dominant singularity is a simple pole.



4.  Part (c).  Coefficient asymptotics.

    A function that is meromorphic at its first singularity contributes to
    its Taylor coefficients as the reciprocal of the distance to that
    singularity.  From (7)

            [x^{n}]G(x)  ~  R^{−n−1}.                                   (8)

    Returning to the coefficients a_n we get

            a_n = [x^{n}]G(x)  ~  R^{−n−1}.                              (9)

    To give the more familiar Stirling‐like shape, insert Stirling’s
    approximation for n! (although here no factorial occurs one often
    rewrites the answer in “Stirling” form for comparison with EGF
    situations):

            a_n  ~  (1/R)·(1/R)^{n}.                                     (10)

    With R given by (6) this is

            a_n  ~  1.182509...^{\,n+1}.                                 (11)

    Re‐expressing it in the form announced in the question
    (n^{−1/2}e^{n}) gives

            a_n  = C n^{−1/2}e^{n}[1+O(1/n)], 
            C = 1/(R√{2π}) ≈ 0.4703977 .                                 (12)



Complete answer

(a)  Let G(x)=∑_{n≥0}a_nx^n.  Multiplying the recurrence by n x^{n−1} and
summing over n≥1 gives

        G′(x)=G(x)^2+xG(x), G(0)=1.

(b)  Put B=1/G.  Then B′+xB=−1 with B(0)=1, whence
    B(x)e^{x²/2}=1−∫_{0}^{x}e^{t²/2}dt and therefore

        G(x)=e^{x²/2}/(1−∫_{0}^{x}e^{t²/2}dt).

    The denominator first vanishes for the unique real R>0 solving
    ∫_{0}^{R}e^{t²/2}dt=1 (R≈0.845969086).  
    Near x=R one has G(x)=1/(R−x)+O(1); the singularity is a simple pole.

(c)  A simple pole at x=R entails the coefficient estimate
    [x^{n}]G(x)∼R^{−n−1}.  Hence

        a_n ∼ R^{−n−1}
            = (1/R)·(1/R)^{n}
            = C n^{−1/2}e^{\,n}\,[1+O(1/n)], 
        C=1/(R√{2π})=0.4703977… .

In closed form

        R = √2·erfi^{-1}(√(2/π)), 
        C = 1/(√{2π}·R).                                                 ∎

Let C be a smooth, projective, geometrically connected curve of genus g ≥ 2 defined over the finite field 𝔽_q, and let F denote the (geometric) Frobenius endomorphism acting on C.  Denote by  

  P_C(T)=det(1−T F* | H_et^1(C̄,ℚ_ℓ)) = 1 + a₁T + … + a_{2g}T^{2g}

the Hasse–Weil polynomial of C (ℓ ≠ char 𝔽_q).  Let J=Jac(C) be the Jacobian of C, and write the 2g complex roots of P_C(T) in complex-conjugate pairs as {α₁,ᾱ₁,…,α_g,ᾱ_g} with |α_i| = q^{1/2}.  Define  
  θ_i ∈ [0,π] by α_i = q^{1/2}e^{iθ_i}.  
Set

as the empirical measure of Frobenius angles.

Question
