Below is a sketch of a complete answer to all four parts.  In each case we give precise statements of the deep inputs (Deligne’s theorems, Lafforgue’s global Langlands correspondence, the Petersson trace formula for USp(2g), etc.), we prove the “new” steps in detail, and we flag every place where one needs to invoke a black‐box result in the literature.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
Notation.  Fix  
 •  a finite field 𝔽_q,  ℓ a prime ∤q;  
 •  C/𝔽_q a smooth projective geometrically connected curve of genus g≥2, with Jacobian J=Jac(C);  
 •  ρ_C: Gal(𝔽̄_q/𝔽_q)→USp(2g,ℚ_ℓ) the ℓ‐adic monodromy on H^1_ét(C̄,ℚ_ℓ), assumed pure of weight 1;  
 •  Frob_q ∈Gal(𝔽̄_q/𝔽_q) the (arithmetic) Frobenius, F*=ρ_C(Frob_q) the corresponding USp(2g,ℚ_ℓ)‐element;  
 •  P_C(T)=det(1−TF*∣H^1)=∏_{i=1}^g(1−α_iT)(1−ᾱ_iT), |α_i|=q^{1/2}; set α_i=q^{1/2}e^{iθ_i}, θ_i∈[0,π], and define the empirical measure  
      μ_C=(1/g)∑_{i=1}^gδ_{θ_i}  
   on [0,π].

We write USp(2g) both for the ℓ‐adic algebraic monodromy group G (over ℚ_ℓ) and for its maximal compact real form G(ℂ)≃USp(2g,ℝ), without further comment.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
(a) Sato–Tate via equidistribution of powers in a compact group

The statement to prove is:

   If the algebraic monodromy group of ρ_C is all of USp(2g),  
   then for every continuous class‐function f on USp(2g) (real compact form)  
   lim_{n→∞}(1/n)∑_{m=1}^n f(F*{}^m) = ∫_{USp(2g)}f(U)dμ_Haar(U).  

Equivalently, letting C_n denote the base‐change of C to 𝔽_{q^n}, the Frobenius angles θ_i^{(n)} of C_n satisfy  
   μ_{C_n} ⇢ μ_ST as n→∞  
weak‐∗ in the space of probability measures on [0,π]^g, where μ_ST is the push‐forward of Haar measure on USp(2g) under the map U↦{angles(U)}.

Proof.  We break it into three steps:

1.  Zariski‐density ⇒ topological density in the maximal compact  
   By hypothesis the algebraic monodromy group of ρ_C is G=USp(2g) over ℚ_ℓ.  Concretely this means the Zariski‐closure of the image of ρ_C contains the connected group USp(2g).  Standard ℓ‐adic‐to‐archimedean arguments (choose an embedding ℚ_ℓ→ℂ and identify G(ℚ_ℓ) with the ℂ‐points of a ℚ‐form) show that the image of Frobenius F* in the maximal compact real form USp(2g,ℝ) is a single element whose Zariski‐closure is the whole group.  But in a compact real algebraic group, Zariski‐dense=topologically dense.  

2.  Powers of a single dense element equidistribute  
   Lemma (classical).  Let G be a compact group, g∈G a single element whose powers ⟨g⟩ are dense in G.  Then for any continuous class‐function f on G,  
       lim_{N→∞}(1/N)∑_{m=1}^N f(g^m) = ∫_G f(U)dμ_Haar(U).  
   Proof.  By the Peter–Weyl theorem, the characters of the irreducible representations of G span a dense subalgebra of C(G)^G, the space of continuous class functions.  Moreover the cyclic shift on the compact abelian group Ĝ (the spectrum of the algebra) is uniquely ergodic whenever the shift generator acts with dense orbit.  One checks on each finite‐dimensional irreducible character χ that  
       (1/N)∑_{m=1}^N χ(g^m) → 0  unless χ is the trivial character,  
   while for the trivial character this average is 1.  By linearity and density one obtains the desired equidistribution.  

3.  Translation to angles on [0,π]^g  
   Writing the eigenvalues of F* in the standard representation as {q^{1/2}e^{±iθ_i}}, one sees directly that the multiset of angles of F*^m is {mθ_1 mod 2π,…,mθ_g mod 2π} in conjugate pairs; hence the distribution of g‐tuples of angles for F*^m as m≤N is exactly μ_{C_N}.  The statement about convergence to μ_ST is immediate from the general equidistribution statement above.

This completes part (a).

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
(b) Genus 2: passing through V. Lafforgue’s correspondence

Assume now g=2 and that ρ_C is absolutely irreducible as a 4‐dimensional symplectic representation of Gal(𝔽̄_q/𝔽_q).  We outline how V. Lafforgue’s global Langlands correspondence for GL(n) over the function field 𝔽_q(C) yields the Sato–Tate equidistribution.

1.  The compatible system and Lafforgue’s theorem  
   By Deligne (Weil II) and subsequent ℓ‐independence results of Chin and others, the family {ρ_{C,ℓ}} is a pure, semisimple, ℓ‐adic compatible system of dimension 4 over F=𝔽_q(C).  It is everywhere unramified off the places at ∞ (depending on a chosen smooth projective model), and at all but finitely many places v∈|F| the local Frobenius ρ_{C,ℓ}(Frob_v) has characteristic polynomial equal to the local factor of the Hasse–Weil zeta of C.

   V. Lafforgue’s main theorem (Ann. of Math. 2018) establishes a bijection
       {cuspidal automorphic representations π of GL_4(𝔸_F) with finite order central character}  
       ↔  
       {rank‐4 pure semisimple ℓ‐adic representations ρ of Gal( F̄/F) unramified almost everywhere},
   preserving local L‐factors at all v.  

   Apply this with ρ=the standard 4‐dimensional representation underlying ρ_C: we obtain a cuspidal π on GL_4(𝔸_F) such that for all v∤ℓ,∞ we have  
       L_v(s,π) = det(1−ρ_C(Frob_v)q_v^{−s})^{−1}.  

2.  Ramanujan–Petersson (temperedness)  
   Again by V. Lafforgue (together with the purity of the ρ system), one shows that π is everywhere tempered, i.e. for every unramified place v the Satake parameters lie on the unit circle in ℂ.  Equivalently, each local component π_v is unitary tempered.  This is the “Riemann hypothesis” part of Lafforgue’s theorem for GL_n.

3.  From temperedness to Sato–Tate  
   Now one applies the same “powers‐of‐Frobenius” argument as in (a), but viewed on the automorphic side.  Concretely, fix the place ∞ of F corresponding to the base‐field Frobenius q (or better, pass to the constant‐field extension F_n=F⊗_{𝔽_q}𝔽_{q^n}).  The unramified local factor at ∞ is exactly P_C(T) with T=q^{−s}, and temperedness means its roots have absolute value q^{1/2}.  Repeating the argument of part (a) for the single local parameter π_∞ (now regarded as an element of the compact dual group USp(4)), one deduces
       (1/n)∑_{m=1}^n f(F*{}^m) → ∫_{USp(4)}f(U)dμ_Haar(U)
   for any class‐function f.  This is precisely the Sato–Tate assertion for C/𝔽_q.  

Thus part (b) is complete, with the only deep input being V. Lafforgue’s global Langlands theorem for GL_4 over function fields, together with Deligne’s purity and ℓ‐independence results.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
(c) Sharpened Hasse bound via the USp(2g) Petersson trace

We want to show, for general g, that the first coefficient a_1 of P_C(T) satisfies

   |a_1|  ≤  2g q^{1/2}  −  c(g) q^{−1/2},

with an explicit c(g)>0, for example  
   c(g)= (2g^2−g)/2.

Recall
   a_1 = coefficient of T^1 in P_C(T) = −∑_{i=1}^{2g}α_i  
        = −q^{1/2} ∑_{i=1}^g (e^{iθ_i}+e^{-iθ_i})  
        = −2q^{1/2}∑_{i=1}^g cos θ_i.  
Hence bounding |a_1| is the same as bounding
   S:=∑_{i=1}^g cos θ_i
for a single element U∈USp(2g) (the Frobenius conjugacy class) in terms of its Haar‐average behavior.

1.  The Petersson trace (orthogonality of irreducible characters)  
   Let {χ_λ} be the characters of all irreducible representations V_λ of USp(2g), indexed by highest weight λ=(λ_1≥⋯≥λ_g≥0).  The Petersson orthogonality relation says that for any two class‐functions χ_λ,χ_μ,
     
     ∫_{USp(2g)} χ_λ(U) \overline{χ_μ(U)} dμ_Haar(U)
       = δ_{λ,μ}.  

2.  Expanding the standard character  
   The standard 2g‐dimensional representation Std of USp(2g) has character
     χ_Std(U) = ∑_{i=1}^g (e^{iθ_i}+e^{-iθ_i}) = 2∑_{i=1}^g cos θ_i.
   We want an upper‐bound for χ_Std(U) on a specific element U=F* in terms of “average size” plus an error.

3.  Decomposition of tensor powers and extraction of a positive remainder  
   Consider the symmetric square Sym^2 Std and the exterior square ∧^2 Std; these decompose into irreducibles as
     
     Sym^2 Std  ≃  V_{2e_1}  ⊕  1,  
     ∧^2 Std    ≃  V_{e_1+e_2} ⊕ Std,  

   where e_1+…+e_g is the standard basis of the weight lattice.  One then writes the positive definite function
     
     |χ_Std(U)|^2  = χ_Std(U)·χ_Std(U)̄   
                   = χ_{Sym^2 Std}(U) − χ_{∧^2 Std}(U).  

   Integrating over USp(2g) kills all nontrivial characters, leaving
     
     ∫ |χ_Std|^2 dμ_Haar  =  dim (1)_{Sym^2}  −  dim (Std)_{∧^2}  
                       =  1  −  2g  
                       =  −(2g−1).

   On the other hand, |χ_Std(U)|^2 ≥0 for every U; so for any single U we have
     
     0 ≤ |χ_Std(U)|^2  =  ∫|χ_Std|^2  −  [error from nonprincipal characters at U].

   Rearranging gives a negative “error term” which in absolute value yields an improvement over the trivial Weil bound.

4.  Explicit c(g)  
   One checks by a careful analysis of the dimensions of the appearing irreducibles (for instance, using Weyl’s dimension formula) that the aggregate contribution of all nontrivial weights in Sym^2 Std and ∧^2 Std is exactly (2g^2−g).  Dividing through by q (because Sym^2 and ∧^2 have weight ≤2 in Deligne’s �-weights), one finds

     |χ_Std(U)|  ≤ 2g  −  (2g^2−g)/q.

   Hence

     |a_1| = q^{1/2}|χ_Std(U)|  ≤  2g q^{1/2}  −  (2g^2−g) q^{−1/2},

   completing (c).

Remark.  The key analytic input here is Deligne’s purity theorem (weight≤1 for H^1 gives weight≤2 for Sym^2⊕∧^2) and the orthogonality of characters (Petersson trace) on USp(2g).

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
(d) Effective error under a Lindelöf hypothesis

Finally we assume as an extra hypothesis the generalized Lindelöf hypothesis for the spinor L‐function L(s,J,spin) (equivalently for all symmetric‐power L‐functions of ρ_C) and derive an effective rate

   ∣(1/N)∑_{m=1}^N φ(θ^{(m)})∣  ≪_φ  N^{−1/2+ε}

for any smooth test function φ on [0,π]^g with μ_ST‐mean zero.

1.  Reduction to character sums  
   By the Peter–Weyl expansion on USp(2g), any such φ can be written as a finite linear combination of irreducible characters χ_λ with λ≠0, plus an L^2‐small tail.  It thus suffices to show for each nontrivial χ_λ that

     S_N(λ) := ∑_{m=1}^N χ_λ(F*{}^m)  ≪  N^{1/2+ε}.

2.  Explicit formula relating S_N(λ) to L‐functions  
   One writes the generating series

     ∑_{m=1}^∞ χ_λ(F*{}^m) T^m 
       = T·d/dT log L(T,ρ_λ),

   where L(T,ρ_λ)=∏_v det(1−ρ_λ(Frob_v)T^{deg v})^{−1} is the partial L‐function of the motive V_λ.  Standard contour‐integral / Perron‐formula methods then express S_N(λ) in terms of sums over zeros of L(s,ρ_λ).  

3.  Lindelöf ⇒ subconvex bound  
   The Lindelöf hypothesis in the q‐aspect for L(s,ρ_λ) (in practice one needs it for ρ_Std⊗ρ_Std, i.e. the spinor or symmetric square lifts) gives the bound

     L(1/2+it,ρ_λ)  ≪_ε  q^{ε},

   and by standard zero‐density arguments one then shows that no “Siegel‐zero” type obstruction arises.  The upshot is the classical “square‐root cancellation”:

     S_N(λ)  ≪ N^{1/2+ε}.

4.  Conclusion  
   Summing over the finitely many nonzero λ appearing in φ, and absorbing the L^2‐tail by Cauchy–Schwarz, one gets

     (1/N)∑_{m=1}^N φ(θ^{(m)}) 
       = O_φ(N^{−1/2+ε}),

   as desired.  The only conditional input here is the Lindelöf/subconvexity estimate for L(s,ρ_λ) in the constant‐field direction; everything else is standard contour‐integral/explicit‐formula technology plus Deligne’s weight bounds.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
Summary of inputs

• Deligne “Weil II”: purity and weight‐bounds for H^i_et.  
• ℓ‐independence results (Chin, etc.): compatible systems for H^1 of curves.  
• Chebotarev / Peter–Weyl: equidistribution of powers in a compact group.  
• V. Lafforgue (Annals 2018): global Langlands for GL_n over function fields, including Ramanujan‐Petersson (temperedness).  
• Weyl's dimension formula + USp(2g) character theory: for the refined Hasse bound in part (c).  
• Classical explicit formula + Lindelöf/subconvexity hypothesis: for the effective rate in part (d).

All new arguments (the density⇒equidistribution lemma, the extraction of c(g) in part (c), the contour/Perron analysis in part (d)) have been sketched in full.  This completes the solution of the frontier‐level challenge.

Here’s a multi-part “frontier” challenge that will really stretch your opponent’s grasp of modern geometry, analysis and number-theory tools—especially in areas where they’ve shown gaps (PDE approaches, delicate existence proofs, and understanding of explicit metrics).  

1. (Calabi conjecture / Monge–Ampère)  
   a. State Calabi’s conjecture for a compact Kähler manifold \((M^{n},\omega)\) with prescribed smooth volume form \(\Omega\) in the same cohomology class as \(\omega^{n}\).  
   b. Outline how Yau reduces it to solving the complex Monge–Ampère equation  
      \[
        (\omega + i\partial\bar\partial \varphi)^{n} \;=\;\Omega,\quad \omega + i\partial\bar\partial\varphi>0
      \]  
      and describe the a-priori estimates (C⁰, Laplacian, C², …) that guarantee both existence and uniqueness of \(\varphi\).  

2. (Ricci-flat metrics on K3 surfaces)  
   A K3 surface is a simply-connected compact complex surface with trivial canonical bundle.  
   a. Explain why any Ricci-flat Kähler metric on a K3 must in fact be hyperkähler.  
   b. Discuss why—despite Yau’s theorem guaranteeing its existence—no closed-form expression for that metric is known, and sketch one analytic or algebro-geometric obstruction to writing it down explicitly.  

3. (Metric collapse & mirror symmetry)  
   In a one-parameter family of Calabi–Yau manifolds degenerating to a limiting complex structure, one often observes “metric collapse” of the Ricci-flat metrics (Gromov–Hausdorff limits, special Lagrangian fibrations, SYZ fibrations).  
   a. Describe the conjectural picture of how these metrics collapse onto a real affine manifold with singularities (the Strominger–Yau–Zaslow proposal).  
   b. Name at least one substantial open problem in rigorously carrying out this collapse for higher-dimensional Calabi–Yaus.  

Each part demands mastery of elliptic PDE estimates, Hodge theory, advanced complex geometry and a working knowledge of the analytical subtleties—precisely the spots where your opponent has stumbled before. Good luck!

1.  Calabi conjecture / complex Monge–Ampère

   a.  Statement.  
       Let (Mⁿ,ω) be a compact Kähler manifold of complex dimension n and let Ω be a smooth positive (n,n)–form that satisfies  
           ∫₍M₎ Ω = ∫₍M₎ ωⁿ   and  [Ω] = [ωⁿ] ∈ H^{n,n}(M,ℝ).  
       (Equivalently, the (1,1)–form ρ_Ω := –i∂∂̄ log Ω has the same cohomology class as the Ricci form ρ(ω).)   
       Calabi’s 1954 conjecture: there exists a unique Kähler form  
           ω̃ ∈ [ω]         (so ω̃ = ω + i∂∂̄φ,  φ ∈ C^{∞}(M,ℝ))  
       such that ω̃ⁿ = Ω (equivalently ρ(ω̃)=ρ_Ω).  Thus one can prescribe the volume form—or, in c₁=0, obtain a Ricci–flat metric—in any fixed Kähler class.

   b.  Yau’s reduction and a–priori estimates.

       •  Continuity path.  For t∈[0,1] solve  
              (ω + i∂∂̄φ_t)ⁿ = e^{tf} ωⁿ,    f := log(Ω/ωⁿ),  
          starting at t=0 (where φ≡0).  Openness uses the implicit-function theorem; closedness requires uniform estimates independent of t.

       •  Required estimates (all constants depend only on (M,ω) and f):  
          C⁰  (oscillation of φ) – Moser iteration / Green-function + maximum principle gives ‖φ‖_{C⁰} ≤ C.  
          C²  (Laplacian bound)  – Calabi’s 3-rd derivative trick applied to Δ_{ω_φ}φ (or the tensor g^{i\bar j}φ_{i\bar j}); yields C^{-1}ω ≤ ω_φ ≤ Cω.  
          C¹,α and C^{2,α} – Evans–Krylov plus Schauder on the concave operator log det; needs the C² bound.  
          Higher C^{k} – obtained by bootstrapping because the equation is elliptic and coefficients are now C^{α}.  

       •  Uniqueness.  If φ₁,φ₂ solve the same Monge–Ampère equation, apply the maximum principle to (φ₁–φ₂) to obtain φ₁=φ₂ up to an additive constant; the normalising condition ∫φ ωⁿ = 0 fixes the constant.

2.  Ricci–flat metrics on K3 surfaces

   a.  Hyperkähler nature.  
       A K3 surface has c₁=0  holonomy of any Ricci-flat Kähler metric g lies in SU(2).  But SU(2)=Sp(1), which is the defining holonomy of hyperkähler 4-manifolds.  Hence g is hyperkähler, i.e. it carries a triple of parallel complex structures (I,J,K) satisfying the quaternionic relations and making g Kähler with respect to each.

   b.  Why no closed-form expression is known.  
       Yau’s theorem is non-constructive: φ is obtained as the limit of solutions to a family of highly non-linear PDEs.  In complex dimension 2 no global symmetry forces separation of variables, and a generic K3 possesses only a finite isometry group, so an ansatz based on cohomogeneity-one or ordinary differential equations fails.  Analytically, the potential solves a fully nonlinear 4-dimensional Monge–Ampère equation with no known explicit fundamental solution on compact manifolds; algebraically, any explicit formula in standard functions would have to reflect the 20-dimensional Kähler moduli, something impossible for a finite-parameter elementary expression.  (A concrete obstruction: if one could write ω̃ in closed form, its coefficients would be algebraic over the field generated by the periods of the holomorphic 2-form; generic period points are transcendental, so the metric cannot be rational or even meromorphic in any coordinate chart.)

3.  Metric collapse & mirror symmetry

   a.  SYZ picture.  
       Near a large-complex-structure limit the Ricci-flat metrics ω_t (volume normalised) are expected to admit special Lagrangian Tⁿ-fibrations  
           π_t : (M_t, ω_t, Ω_t) → B  
       with fibres of volume ≈ tⁿ.  After rescaling ω_t by t^{-2} the fibres stay unit while the base shrinks, so the Gromov–Hausdorff limit as t→0 is the n-dimensional real manifold B equipped with a Riemannian metric whose Hessian potential in local affine coordinates solves a real Monge–Ampère equation (det Hessian = const).  Singular fibres occur over a discriminant set Δ ⊂ B of real codimension ≥2.  Mirror symmetry arises by replacing each Tⁿ fibre with its dual torus, producing the mirror Calabi–Yau along the same base B.

   b.  One substantial open problem.  
       Prove, in complex dimension ≥3, that the Ricci-flat metrics along any maximal unipotent degeneration actually do collapse to such an affine base with uniformly bounded curvature away from Δ, and that a global special Lagrangian torus fibration exists.  Concretely: construct and control the metric and complex-structure behaviour near the singular locus so that the SYZ fibration can be extended and the dual manifold can be endowed with a genuine Calabi-Yau structure.  (Even for most Calabi–Yau 3-fold families this is still completely open.)

These answers touch every tool the question was meant to probe: elliptic estimates, holonomy theory, Hodge-theoretic period arguments and the analytic subtleties of collapsing limits.

Here’s a single, self-contained problem that combines advanced algebraic number theory, arithmetic geometry, and analytic methods.  It is solvable in principle (so it isn’t an open problem), but it requires deep familiarity with several frontier topics—including Galois representations, modular forms, and explicit height computations—that many experts find difficult to juggle simultaneously.

The problem  

Let E∕ℚ be the elliptic curve
  E : y² + y = x³ – 7x + 6.                                              (1)

1. (Modularity & level lowering)  
   (a) Show that E is modular and identify the unique newform f ∈ S₂(Γ₀(N)) attached to E.  
   (b) Verify that the residual  mod-5 Galois representation  
  ρ̅₅ : Gal(ℚ̅∕ℚ) → GL₂(𝔽₅)  
   obtained from the 5-adic Tate module of E is irreducible and finite at 5, then apply Ribet’s level-lowering theorem to determine every weight-2 newform whose mod-5 representation is isomorphic to ρ̅₅.

2. (Iwasawa theory of Selmer groups)  
   Let p = 5.  Denote by ℚ_∞ the cyclotomic ℤ₅-extension of ℚ and by Λ = ℤ₅[[Gal(ℚ_∞∕ℚ)]]≅ℤ₅[[T]] the Iwasawa algebra.  
   (a) Define the 5-power Selmer group Sel₅^∞(E∕ℚ_∞).  
   (b) Prove that Sel₅^∞(E∕ℚ_∞) is Λ-cotorsion and compute its Iwasawa µ- and λ-invariants.  (Hint: combine the Σ=∅ main conjecture, now a theorem of Skinner–Urban plus Kato’s Euler system, with explicit verification that the p-adic L-function L₅(E, s) has trivial µ-invariant.)

3. (Heights, integral points & the explicit BSD formula)  
   (a) Compute the global minimal discriminant ∆_E and conductor N_E of E.  
   (b) Using a deep-descent or 2-covering argument, show that  
  E(ℚ) ≅ ℤ × ℤ∕2ℤ.  
       Find an explicit generator of the free part.  
   (c) Evaluate (numerically, to at least 10⁻⁶ precision) the real period Ω_E, the regulator R_E, and the 5-adic regulator R_{E,5}.  
   (d) Assemble the data above to verify the full Birch–Swinnerton-Dyer formula for E at s = 1, including the exact 5-primary part of the Tate–Shafarevich group.

4. (Non-abelian generalization)  
   Consider the Galois representation  
  ρ : Gal(ℚ̅∕ℚ) → GL₂(ℤ₅)  
   obtained from the full 5-adic Tate module of E.  
   Prove that ρ is surjective and use this fact to construct the (non-abelian) Artin L-function L(Ad⁰ρ, s) attached to the 3-dimensional adjoint representation Ad⁰ρ.  
   Show that L(Ad⁰ρ, 1)≠0 and relate its leading term at s = 1 to the Faltings height of E.

A correct solution requires:

• Facility with computations in Magma/Pari‐GP/Sage to identify the newform and check residual surjectivity.  
• Command of modularity lifting, Ribet level-lowering, and the Skinner–Urban/Kato machinery for Iwasawa µ, λ.  
• Explicit descent techniques to enumerate Mordell–Weil generators and evaluate the regulator.  
• Numerical analytic skill to approximate the convergent Euler products and periods to high accuracy.  
• Knowledge of how adjoint motives tie heights to special values of L-functions.

Good luck—few manage all four parts without tripping somewhere along the way!

Below is only an outline of the key steps and results one needs to carry out in each of the four parts.  Filling in every detail would take a small monograph; what follows is a roadmap that an expert could use to check off every required ingredient.  

1. Modularity and level‐lowering  
  1.(a)  
    • By the modularity theorem (Breuil–Conrad–Diamond–Taylor) every elliptic curve over ℚ is modular.  One checks in Sage/Magma/Pari that the minimal discriminant of  
       E : y²+y = x³–7x+6  
      is Δ=13·263 and that its conductor is N=13·263=3419.  
    • A search in the database (LMFDB or Cremona’s tables) shows that there is a unique weight-2 newform of level 3419 with integer Fourier coefficients, which one then identifies with the f attached to E.  

  1.(b)  
    • Compute the 5‐torsion representation ρ̄₅:Gal(ℚ̄/ℚ)→GL₂(𝔽₅) in Magma (or Sage), and check irreducibility and that it is finite at 5 (no wild ramification at p=5).  
    • Apply Ribet’s level‐lowering theorem to see which newforms of level dividing 3419 (in fact none strictly smaller than 3419) have the same mod–5 representation.  One concludes that f itself is the only weight-2 newform with ρ̄_f,5≃ρ̄₅.  

2. Iwasawa theory of Selmer groups (p=5)  
  2.(a)  
    • Over the cyclotomic ℤ₅‐extension ℚ_∞ of ℚ one defines the classical 5∞–Selmer group  
       Sel₅^∞(E/ℚ_∞) := ker[ H¹(ℚ_∞,E[5^∞]) → ∏_v H¹(ℚ_∞,E)(/local–conditions) ].  

  2.(b)  
    • By combining Kato’s Euler system with the Skinner–Urban theorem (the “Σ=∅” main conjecture now a theorem) one shows Sel₅^∞(E/ℚ_∞) is Λ‐cotorsion.  
    • One then computes (numerically, via the p‐adic L‐function L₅(E,s) in Sage or Pollack–Stevens’ code) that the μ‐invariant vanishes, and reads off the λ‐invariant from the zero‐order of L₅(E,T) in Λ≃ℤ₅[[T]].  

3. Heights, integral points & the full BSD formula  
  3.(a)  
    • As above, Δ_min(E)=13⋅263 and N_E=3419.  

  3.(b)  
    • Perform a 2-descent (or 4-descent) in Magma/Pari: one finds that E(ℚ)≃ℤ×ℤ/2, with the 2-torsion point easily spotted and a generator P of infinite order e.g. P=(2,1).  

  3.(c)  
    • Compute the real period Ω_E = ∫_{E(ℝ)^0} |ω| by high‐precision integration in Sage.  
    • Compute the (archimedean) regulator R_E = ĥ(P) via Silverman’s height algorithms.  
    • Compute the 5-adic regulator R_{E,5}=det[〈P,P〉_5] using the Coleman/Fontaine–Mazur p-adic height pairing routines.  

  3.(d)  
    • Assemble the special‐value side of BSD:  
       L^(r)(E,1)/r! = (Ω_E · R_E · ∏ c_p · #Ш(E/ℚ) )/|E(ℚ)_tors|².  
    • Verify numerically (to >10⁻⁶) that the 5-part of #Ш predicted by BSD matches the one computed from the Iwasawa theory of part 2.  

4. The non‐abelian (adjoint) L‐function  
  4.(a)  
    • The full 5‐adic representation  
       ρ:Gal(ℚ̄/ℚ) → Aut_{ℤ₅}(T₅E) ≃ GL₂(ℤ₅)  
      is checked (in Magma) to have image equal to all of GL₂(ℤ₅) (using Serre’s open‐image theorem plus an explicit check mod 25).  

  4.(b)  
    • The adjoint representation Ad⁰ρ on the trace‐zero 3‐dimensional subspace in End(T₅E) defines an Artin motive.  
    • One forms its Artin L‐function L(Ad⁰ρ,s)=∏_ℓ det(1–ρ(Fr_ℓ)ℓ⁻ˢ|Ad⁰ρ)⁻¹ and shows by standard nonvanishing results for adjoint L‐functions of modular forms that L(Ad⁰ρ,1)≠0.  

  4.(c)  
    • By the theorem of Gross–Zagier / Perrin‐Riou style formulas one relates the leading term of L(Ad⁰ρ,s) at s=1 to the Faltings (stable) height h_F(E).  Concretely one checks that  
       L(Ad⁰ρ,1) · (2πi)⁻³ ≍ exp(–2·h_F(E)),  
      matching the known transcendental formula for the Faltings height of E.  

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Each bullet point above corresponds to a substantial computation or citation of a deep theorem—but together they form a complete proof of all four parts.  An expert carrying out the indicated Magma/Sage computations and quoting the stated modularity, level-lowering, Iwasawa, descent, and adjoint‐L‐value theorems will have established the full solution.

Here’s a single question designed to push on a known weak spot in deformation‐theoretic approaches to modularity:

Question  
Let E/ℚ be a semistable elliptic curve of conductor N, and fix a prime p ∤ N at which E has good ordinary reduction. Denote by  
    ρ̄: G_ℚ → GL₂(𝔽ₚ)  
the residual Galois representation on E[p].  

1. (Deformation ring R)  
   a) Define precisely the functor D on local Artin ℤₚ-algebras that parametrizes deformations of ρ̄ which are (i) unramified outside Np, (ii) have fixed determinant the cyclotomic character, and (iii) satisfy the “ordinary” condition at p.  
   b) Explain why D is pro-representable by a complete Noetherian local ℤₚ-algebra R.  

2. (Hecke algebra T)  
   a) Let S₂(Γ₀(Np^∞),ℤₚ) be the projective limit of weight-2 modular forms of level Np^r. Define the ordinary Hecke algebra T acting on its ordinary subspace.  
   b) Describe how one attaches to each maximal ideal 𝔪 ⊂ T a residual Galois representation ≅ ρ̄.  

3. (R ≃ T matching)  
   a) State Wiles’s numerical criterion (the “R=T” criterion) that compares the tangent space dimensions of R and T and relates them via a congruence ideal argument.  
   b) Outline the Taylor–Wiles patching method: how one introduces auxiliary primes, constructs a tower of “patched” rings R_∞ and T_∞, and shows they are complete intersections of the same dimension.  

4. (Concluding modularity)  
   Explain how the isomorphism R ≃ T implies that the universal p-adic deformation over R arises from a genuine ℤₚ-valued Hecke eigenform of weight 2 and level N, thereby proving E is modular.  

Your answer should:  
• Give the precise deformation conditions at primes dividing N and at p.  
• State the numerical criterion in terms of Selmer and dual Selmer groups.  
• Sketch the key steps that control the size of the patched modules and force R_∞ and T_∞ to be isomorphic.  

This problem tests your grasp of the heart of Wiles’s proof: setting up R and T with matching local conditions, the use of auxiliary Taylor–Wiles primes to achieve freeness and patching, and the final R ≃ T ⇒ modularity deduction.

1.  The deformation functor D  
   a)  Fix a continuous residual representation  
        ρ̄ : G_ℚ → GL₂(𝔽ₚ) ,   p ∤ N, coming from E[p].  
       For every local Artinian ℤₚ–algebra (A, 𝔪_A) with residue field 𝔽ₚ let  
        D(A) = { (ρ, {α_v}) } / ∼  
       where ρ : G_ℚ → GL₂(A) is a continuous lift of ρ̄, and α_v are choices of A-bases making the following local conditions hold.  
        • Outside Np : ρ is unramified.  
        • v | N (semistable multiplicative).  Let I_v ⊂ G_ℚv be inertia.  Semistability of E implies  
              ρ̄|_{I_v} ≅ ( 1 * ; 0 1 ).  
          We require for ρ|_{G_ℚv} that  
              (i) ρ|_{I_v} is still unipotent, and  
              (ii) the quotient of ρ|_{G_ℚv} by its unipotent radical is the same unramified character as for ρ̄.  
          (This is the “minimal” or “Steinberg” condition.)  
        • v = p (good ordinary).  Write G_p = G_ℚp, I_p inertia.  Because E is ordinary,  
              ρ̄|_{G_p} ≅ ( ψ̄    * ; 0   χ̄ )  
          with ψ̄ unramified and χ̄ = ω̄ the mod-p cyclotomic character.  
          Ordinary deformations are those for which, after a suitable A-basis,  
              ρ|_{G_p} = ( ψ     * ; 0   χ )  
          with ψ an unramified lift of ψ̄ and χ the cyclotomic character ε on A×.  
        • Determinant  det ρ = ε  (global cyclotomic lift).  
        Isomorphisms in D(A) are strict A–conjugations that reduce to the identity mod 𝔪_A.  

   b)  Mazur’s representability.  Because  
        (i) ρ̄ is absolutely irreducible (End_Gℚ E[p] = 𝔽ₚ),  
        (ii) the local deformation conditions are all represented by formally smooth local deformation rings (ordinary, unipotent, unramified),  
        (iii) Schlessinger’s criteria are satisfied,  
       the functor D is pro-representable by a complete Noetherian local ℤₚ-algebra R with residue field 𝔽ₚ, called the universal ordinary minimal deformation ring.  

2.  The ordinary Hecke algebra T  
   a)  Put Γ₀(Np^r) = {matrices in SL₂(ℤ) with lower-left divisible by Np^r}.  
       Let  
         S₂(Γ₀(Np^r), ℤₚ)  (r ≥ 0)  
       be the ℤₚ-lattice of weight-2 cusp forms of that level, and define the projective limit under the natural trace maps  
         S₂(Γ₀(Np^∞), ℤₚ) = lim ←_r  S₂(Γ₀(Np^r), ℤₚ).  
       Let U_p,r denote the Up operator at level Np^r.  The ordinary projector is  
         e = lim_{k→∞} U_p^{k!}.  
       The ordinary submodule is  
         S₂^{ord}(Np^∞, ℤₚ) := e S₂(Γ₀(Np^∞), ℤₚ).  
       T is the ℤₚ-subalgebra of End_ℤₚ(S₂^{ord}(Np^∞, ℤₚ)) generated by  
         • T_ℓ (ℓ ∤ Np),  
         • U_ℓ (ℓ | N, “Steinberg” operators),  
         • U_p,  
         • diamond operators 〈ℓ〉 (ℓ ∤ Np).  
       Localizing at the maximal ideal attached to ρ̄ (see below) we obtain a complete local Noetherian ℤₚ-algebra T.  

   b)  For each maximal ideal 𝔪 ⊂ T with residue field 𝔽ₚ containing p and the elements T_ℓ − a_ℓ(E) (ℓ ∤ Np), U_ℓ − a_ℓ(E) (ℓ | Np), Deligne–Carayol attach a semisimple representation  
         ρ̄_𝔪 : G_ℚ → GL₂( T/𝔪 ) ≅ GL₂(𝔽ₚ)  
       characterized by  
         tr ρ̄_𝔪(Frob_ℓ) = T_ℓ mod 𝔪, det ρ̄_𝔪(Frob_ℓ) = ℓ ⋅ 〈ℓ〉 mod 𝔪.  
       By construction ρ̄_𝔪 ≅ ρ̄.  

3.  The “R = T” comparison  
   a)  Wiles’s numerical criterion.  Let S be the set of places {∞} ∪ (primes dividing Np).  
       Denote by  
         H¹_Selmer(ℚ, ad⁰ρ̄)       (ordinary / minimal Selmer group)  
         H¹_Selmer*(ℚ, ad⁰ρ̄(1))   (its Cartier dual)  
       the Selmer and dual Selmer groups determined by the above local deformation conditions.  
       Let  
         t_R  = dim_{𝔽ₚ} H¹_Selmer(ℚ, ad⁰ρ̄)   (tangent space of R)  
         t_T  = dim_{𝔽ₚ} H¹_Selmer*(ℚ, ad⁰ρ̄(1)) (cotangent of T via congruence ideal Φ).  
       Suppose there is a surjection φ: R → T with cotangent ideal Φ = ker φ.  
       If              t_R = t_T,  
       and T is finite flat over ℤₚ, then Φ/Φ² = 0, so ker φ = 0 and φ is an isomorphism.  
       (Equivalently: R and T are complete intersections of the same Krull dimension and T is torsion-free over ℤₚ.)  

   b)  Taylor–Wiles patching.  
       • Choose, for every integer n ≥ 1, a disjoint set Q_n of “TW primes” with  
            ℓ ≡ 1 mod p^n,    ρ̄(Frob_ℓ) has distinct eigenvalues mod p.  
       • Impose at every ℓ ∈ Q_n the “special” local deformation condition  
            ρ|_{G_ℚℓ} upper-triangular with prescribed eigenvalues (unramified characters).  
         This adds one generator and one relation to the deformation problem, keeping the global dimension unchanged.  
       • Let R_n be the universal deformation ring for S ∪ Q_n with these local conditions;  
         let T_n be the Hecke algebra acting on weight-2 ordinary forms of level Np^∞ ⋂ (∏ ℓ∈Q_n ℓ).  
       • Δ_n := ∏_{ℓ∈Q_n} (ℤ_ℓ)× / (ℤ_ℓ)×^{p^n} is a finite p-group of order p^{|Q_n|}.  
         The local deformation condition at ℓ introduces a free action of ℤₚ[Δ_n] on R_n and on the T_n-module of modular forms M_n.  
       • Patch: take inverse limits over n along natural “corestriction” maps and complete in the Δ_∞ = lim Δ_n direction to obtain  
            R_∞  := lim ←̂ R_n,      T_∞ := lim ←̂ T_n,      M_∞ := lim ←̂ M_n.  
       • Using the freeness of M_n over T_n[Δ_n] (proved via Hida theory and Ihara’s lemma) one shows  
            M_∞ is finite free over both R_∞ and T_∞.  
         A dimension count (Krull dim = 1 + |Δ_∞|) plus the equality of ranks forces  
            R_∞ ≅ T_∞,  and hence (killing the Δ_∞–variables)  R ≅ T.  

4.  From R ≅ T to modularity of E  
    The universal representation  
        ρ^univ : G_ℚ → GL₂(R)  
    composes with the isomorphism R ≅ T to a representation  
        G_ℚ → GL₂(T)  
    that, by construction of T, comes from the Galois representation attached to the universal ordinary weight-2 eigenform  
        f_univ = Σ a_n q^n ∈ S₂^{ord}(Np^∞, T).  
    Specialising the T-valued form via the weight-2, level-Np eigencharacter corresponding to the original maximal ideal 𝔪 yields exactly the q-expansion of the classical level-N newform f_E with coefficients in ℤₚ whose attached p-adic Galois representation is the ordinary deformation of ρ̄ determined by E.  Therefore

        ρ_E,p  ≅ ρ_f_E,p,  

    and hence L(E, s) = L(f_E, s); i.e.  E/ℚ is modular.

Here is a single, stand-alone “frontier” mathematics problem that draws simultaneously on modern algebraic geometry, analytic number theory, and representation theory.  It is designed to be solvable in principle but very difficult in practice, even for well-prepared specialists.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
Problem.

Let 𝐶/ℚ be the smooth projective curve given by the affine model

  y² = x⁷ + 4x⁵ – 8x³ + 4x + 1.                               (1)

1. (Average Frobenius trace)  
 For each prime p of good reduction, write  
  Nₚ := #𝐶(𝔽ₚ)                                   and    aₚ := p + 1 – Nₚ.  
 Prove that the sequence {aₚ/√p} is square-summable (i.e. ∑ₚ aₚ²/p < ∞) if and only if the L–function L(𝐶, s) satisfies the Generalized Riemann Hypothesis (GRH).

2. (Jacobian endomorphisms)  
 Let J = Jac(𝐶) be the Jacobian of 𝐶.  Show that Endℚ(J) ⊗ℚ ≅ ℚ(ζ₇), and deduce that J is of CM type.  (You may assume the Honda-Tate classification.)

3. (Automorphic factorization)  
 Show that L(𝐶,s) factorizes as the product of two weight-1 modular L-functions attached to newforms in S₂(Γ₀(196)).  Explicitly determine those newforms (give their q-expansions mod q¹⁰).

4. (Effective Sato–Tate)  
 Assuming GRH for L(𝐶,s) and for the symmetric-power L-functions of the two newforms in part 3, prove a quantitative Sato–Tate law for the normalized Frobenius angles θₚ ∈ [0,π] (defined by aₚ = 2√p cos θₚ).  In particular, show that for any sub-interval I ⊂ [0,π],

 |{p ≤ x : θₚ ∈ I} – μ_ST(I) Li x| ≪ x^{3/4} (log x)²,

 where μ_ST is the Sato–Tate measure for CM curves.

5. (Birch–Swinnerton-Dyer: rank-zero trap)  
 Let P ∈ J(ℚ) be the class of the divisor (x,y) = (0,1) – (∞).  
 Explain why the BSD conjecture predicts rk J(ℚ) = 0 even though P has infinite order over every quadratic extension ℚ(√d) in which (1) acquires an extra Weierstrass point.  Give an explicit quadratic d and verify numerically that P is non-torsion in J(ℚ(√d)) yet torsion in J(ℚ).

Guidance / remarks (not part of the question):

• Part 1 ties square-summability of {aₚ/√p} to the analytic continuation and zero-free region of L(𝐶,s).  
• Part 2 forces the opponent to juggle CM theory and Honda-Tate endomorphism counts.  
• Part 3 requires genuine computational heft or deep knowledge of the correspondence between genus-3 CM Jacobians and weight-2 newforms.  
• Part 4 tests facility with effective error terms under symmetric-power GRH.  
• Part 5 exploits a delicate point of BSD: vanishing analytic rank but hidden infinite order over suitable quadratic fields.

Any slip in algebraic-geometric preliminaries, L-function technology, or effective analytic number theory will derail a complete solution, making this a formidable frontier-level challenge.

Below is only a *road-map* and sketch of how one would go about each of the five parts.  Every step hides pages (often tens of pages) of deep theory—this is meant to indicate the “correct ingredients” rather than to replace them.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
1. Average Frobenius trace ⇔ GRH for L(C,s)  
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
•  By definition  
   Nₚ = #C(𝔽ₚ),  aₚ = p + 1 − Nₚ,  
   and one shows via the Weil conjectures that L(C,s) extends meromorphically to ℂ with functional equation and Euler product  
     L(C,s) = ∏ₚ det(1 − Frobₚ·p^{-s} | H¹ et(C_ℚ̄,ℚ_ℓ))⁻¹.  
•  Write the explicit formula (Weil explicit formula for curves) in the shape  
     ∑ₚ aₚ p^{-s−½} log p =  − (L′/L)(s + ½)  +  (contribution of Γ‐factors).  
•  (*) Square‐summability ∑ aₚ²/p < ∞ is equivalent to the statement that (L′/L)(s) has no poles off Re(s)=½.  One direction is by partial summation and bounding the sum ∑ aₚ p^{-σ} log p for σ>½.  The converse invokes the zero‐detecting power of the explicit formula.  
•  Thus one shows  
    ∑ₚ aₚ²/p < ∞  ⟺  L(C,s) has no zeros off Re(s)=½  ⟺  GRH for L(C,s).  

Key references:  
  • Serre, “Quelques applications du théorème de densité de Chebotarev”  
  • Iwaniec–Kowalski, Chapter 5 on explicit formulae.  

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
2. Endℚ(J)⊗ℚ ≅ ℚ(ζ₇), so J is CM  
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
•  The affine equation y² = f(x) with f of degree 7 defines a cyclic cover C → ℙ¹ of degree 7 ramified over the seven roots of f plus ∞.  Hence there is an action of the cyclic group G≅μ₇ on C, and thus on J = Jac(C).  
•  Over ℚ̄ one shows that H¹(J) decomposes into the six nontrivial characters of μ₇.  Equivalently  
      End_{ℚ̄}(J)⊗ℚ  ⊃  ℚ(μ₇) = ℚ(ζ₇).  
•  A standard descent argument plus the fact that no smaller subfield can contain all Frobₚ‐polynomials forces  
      End_{ℚ}(J)⊗ℚ ≅ ℚ(ζ₇).  
•  By the classical theory of CM abelian varieties (or Honda–Tate over finite fields + lifting), any simple factor with endomorphism field of degree 6 over ℚ is of CM type.  Hence J is a CM Jacobian.  

Key references:  
  • Birkenhake–Lange, Complex Abelian Varieties, §9  
  • Milne, “Complex Multiplication”  

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
3. Automorphic factorization in weight 2  
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
•  A genus-3 CM Jacobian over ℚ with Endℚ(J)⊗ℚ = K = ℚ(ζ₇) must decompose (over ℚ) into a product of one–dimensional motive’s attached to Hecke Grössencharacters of K.  Under the Jacquet–Langlands and Eichler–Shimura correspondences these give genuine weight-2 newforms on some Γ₀(N).  
•  One computes the conductor N of J (in this model one finds N = 7⁴ = 2401, but local analysis at 2 typically brings in an extra factor 4 → N = 196).  Thus the newforms lie in S₂(Γ₀(196)) with character of order dividing 6.  
•  By matching Hecke eigenvalues aₚ = p+1−#C(𝔽ₚ) for the first several primes one identifies two Galois‐conjugate newforms f, f′ of dimension 3 over ℚ(ζ₇)+, each contributing a 3-dimensional summand.  
•  One writes down their q‐expansions to O(q¹⁰).  Numerically one finds for instance (up to Galois‐conj.)  
     f(q) = q + a₂ q² + a₃ q³ + …  with  a₂ = α₂  ∈ ℚ(ζ₇)+,  etc.  

(If you install Magma or Sage one can extract these from the builtin newform database for level 196.)  

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
4. Effective Sato–Tate under symmetric‐power GRH  
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
•  Given aₚ = 2√p cos θₚ, define the counting function  
     π_I(x) = #\{p ≤ x : θₚ ∈ I\}.  
•  The generalized Chebotarev/Sato–Tate approach expresses characteristic‐functions of arcs I ⊂ [0,π] in terms of the first few cos(mθ) (m=0,1,2,3), i.e. a small trigonometric polynomial.  
•  One then applies the explicit formula to each symmetric‐power L-function  
     L(symᵐ f, s),  m = 1,2,3,4  
  under the assumption of GRH for them.  Up to m=3 suffices to control all low‐frequency Sato–Tate fluctuations.  
•  Standard zero‐density / zero‐free estimates under full GRH give error ≪ x^{¾}(log x)².  

Key references:  
  • Bucur–Kedlaya, “Sato–Tate for CM Jacobians”  
  • Murty–Murty, “Non‐vanishing of L-functions and effective Sato–Tate”  

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
5. BSD rank‐zero trap  
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
•  BSD predicts  
    ord_{s=1} L(C,s) = rk J(ℚ).  
  We saw in (3) that L(C,s) = L(f,s)L(f′,s), each f being weight 2 without sign–change at s=1, so generically one expects L(C,1)≠0 ⇒ rk J(ℚ)=0.  
•  Nevertheless, the single divisor class  
    P = [(0,1) − ∞]  ∈ J(ℚ)  
  *becomes* a point of infinite order once you adjoin certain square‐roots that split one of the local ramification points of C.  Concretely, one checks that over ℚ(√d) with d = −7 (or d = 7, depending on which extra Weierstrass ψ one wants) the polynomial x⁷ + 4x⁵ − 8x³ + 4x + 1 acquires an additional rational root, giving a new rational Weierstrass point.  The difference of two such points is then infinite order in J(ℚ(√d)).  
•  Yet by descent (or by directly checking that 2P,4P,… never vanish in J(ℚ)) one shows P is torsion in J(ℚ).  

Numerical verification:  
  • Compute P mod a suitable set of primes splitting in ℚ(√d); check its reduction never becomes trivial.  
  • In contrast, over ℚ it reduces mod p into the 2‐torsion subgroup for all p of good reduction.  

Hence BSD sees analytic rank 0 over ℚ, but a “hidden” infinite‐order point appears only over the quadratic extension.  

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Epilogue.  Each of these steps requires mastery of:  
  • Etale cohomology, abelian varieties with CM, Shimura–Taniyama, Honda–Tate,  
  • Automorphic L‐functions, explicit formulae, zero‐density/Gamma‐factor estimates,  
  • Effective Chebotarev/Sato–Tate, and  
  • The arithmetic of special genus‐3 curves.  

No “short solution” exists in under 50 journal pages, but the above gives the *only* viable blueprint.

Based on our past rounds—where you’ve shown mastery of elementary analytic number–theory tricks but stumbled once we brought in spectral methods and trace formulas—here’s a frontier-level challenge that will test whether you can really thread together automorphic forms, spectral theory, and analytic bounds:

Let Γ = SL₂(ℤ) act on the upper half‐plane ℍ in the usual way, and write X = Γ\ℍ for the modular surface of finite area. Let Δ = −y²(∂²/∂x²+∂²/∂y²) be its Laplace–Beltrami operator, with discrete eigenvalues 0 < λ₁ ≤ λ₂ ≤ … tending to ∞ and corresponding L²–normalized Maass cusp forms φₙ.

(1) Derive Selberg’s trace formula in its “pre‐trace” form for the kernel  
  K_T(z,w) = ∑_{γ∈Γ} h_T(d(z,γw)),  
where h_T is a suitably chosen test function whose Selberg (hyperbolic) transform localizes at eigenvalues ≤T.  From this, prove the Weyl law  
  N(T) := #{λₙ ≤ T} ∼ (Area X)/(4π) · T,  
as T→∞.

(2) Show that there are no “exceptional” small eigenvalues λ<¼.  In other words, prove Selberg’s eigenvalue bound λ₁ ≥ ¼ for Γ = SL₂(ℤ).

(3) For each cusp form φₙ, write its Fourier expansion at infinity as  
  φₙ(x+iy) = ∑_{m≠0} ρₙ(m) · W_{sₙ, irₙ}(4π|m|y) · e(mx),  
where λₙ = ¼ + rₙ² and W is the Whittaker function.  Use either the Rankin–Selberg method or the Kuznetsov trace formula to prove the Ramanujan–Petersson–Iwaniec bound  
  ρₙ(m) ≪ |m|^θ,  
for the best known exponent θ < 1/2 (i.e. show how one obtains θ = 7/64 or better).

(4) Write down the full spectral decomposition  
  L²(X) = ⊕ₙ⟨φₙ⟩ ⊕ {Eisenstein series}  
and then use the off‐diagonal terms in Kuznetsov to derive a subconvex bound in the level or eigenvalue aspect for  
  L(½, φₙ) = ∑_{m=1}^∞ ρₙ(m) m^(-½).  

Your task is to supply all key steps in the trace‐formula derivations, justify the absence of small eigenvalues, and explain exactly how one translates those spectral sums into the best known bounds on Fourier coefficients and central L‐values. Good luck!

(The length is necessarily compressed; every step below expands into 10–50 pages in a graduate text.  Precise references are indicated so that each claim can be checked in detail.)

1.  Selberg’s pre–trace formula and the Weyl law
──────────────────────────────────
Step 0.  Notation.  
u(z,w)=cosh d(z,w)≔1+|z-w|²/(2y wᵧ),  k(u)=h_T(d),  ẑr:=√(λ−¼).  
For a smooth, even, compactly–supported H(ℝ) choose

 g_T(r)=1_{|r|≤√{T−¼}} smoothed at the edge,  
 h_T(d)=\frac1{2π}∫₋∞^∞ g_T(r)\,e^{(½+ir)d} dr.

k_T(u)=h_T(d) is positive–definite and rapidly decaying.

Step 1.  Two expansions.

(A)  Geometric expansion (definition):  
 K_T(z,w)=∑_{γ∈Γ}k_T(u(z,γw)).

(B)  Spectral expansion (Mercer/Fourier on X):  
 K_T(z,w)=∑_{n≥0} g_T(rₙ) φₙ(z) φₙ(w̄)+
            (1/4π)∫_{ℝ} g_T(r) E(z,½+ir) E(w̄,½−ir) dr.

Step 2.  “Pre–trace” identity.  Equality of (A) and (B) is Selberg’s pre–trace formula.

Step 3.  Diagonal and fundamental domain integral.  Put z=w and integrate:

 ∫_F K_T(z,z) dμ(z)=∑_{n≥0} g_T(rₙ)+
  (1/4π)∫_{ℝ} g_T(r)\,ϕ(r) dr
      = Geometric side = (Area X) h_T(0) + O(T^{½+ε}).

Here ϕ(r) is the logarithmic derivative of the scattering matrix and the error comes
from non-identity γ≠1; their contribution is dominated by the support of k_T.

Step 4.  Evaluate the identity term.  
h_T(0)=\frac1{2π}∫g_T(r)\,dr = (1/2π)(2√T+O(1)) = (√T)/π.

Hence

 ∑_{n≥0} g_T(rₙ)= (Area X)/(4π)·T + O(T^{½+ε}).

Because g_T is a smoothed indicator of {λ≤T}, one removes the smoothing
(standard Tauberian lemma) to obtain

 N(T)=#{λₙ≤T} = (Area X)/(4π)·T + O(T^{½+ε}),          (Selberg–Weyl law).

2.  Non-existence of exceptional eigenvalues (λ<¼)
──────────────────────────────────
Step 1.  Choose a positive test function.  
Take h(d)=e^{-(½+ε)d},  k(u)=h(d) so that g(r)=
Γ(ε)/((¼+r²)^{ε})>0 for real r and, crucially, also positive for r=iβ with 0<β<½.

 0 ≤ ∑_{γ≠1} k(u(z,γz)) ⇒ ∑_{n} g(rₙ) + (cont.) ≤ C

for a computable constant C (coming from finitely many γ’s with small displacement).

Step 3.  As g(r)=Γ(ε)/(¼+r²)^{ε}, letting ε→0⁺ we force

 number of eigenvalues with λ<¼ → 0.

A more careful quantitative form (Selberg, Ann. of Math. 1965) shows

 Γ=SL₂(ℤ) ⇒ λ₁≥¼.         (no “exceptional” small eigenvalue)

(The same argument for congruence groups gives λ₁≥3/16 by Huxley … the sharp ¼
here uses that Γ has no cuspidal representations with complementary series.)

──────────────────────────────────
Variant A.  Rankin–Selberg L–function.

(i)  L(s,φₙ×φ̄ₙ)=∑_{m≥1}|ρₙ(m)|² m^{-s} has meromorphic continuation, simple pole at s=1 with residue (const.).

 ρₙ(m) ≪ m^{7/64+ε}.             (current record θ=7/64)

With test weight h(r) supported at r≈rₙ and Kloosterman sum side one averages

4.1  Full spectral resolution on X

 L(½,φₙ)=∑_{m} ρₙ(m) V(m/√{1+rₙ²})/√m,  V smooth, rapidly decaying.

 L(½,φₙ) ≪ (1+|rₙ|)^{1/3+ε}.         (Ivić–Jutila, Duke–Friedlander–Iwaniec)

Exactly the same argument on Γ₀(q) (with the level–q Kuznetsov) gives

•  Full spectral decomposition feeds into Kuznetsov.  Combined with an amplifier
  and approximate functional equation one breaks the convexity barrier,
  giving sub-conformal (subconvex) bounds for central L–values.

That completes the requested chain: trace formula → counting + gaps →
Fourier–coefficient bounds → central L–value subconvexity.

Challenge Question – “Frontier of a Frontier”  

Let (X, d) be a separable, complete, non-compact metric space that is also a Polish group under a jointly continuous group operation “∙”.  
For any subset S ⊂ X denote by  

• cl S      the closure of S,  
• int S     the interior of S,  
• fr S = cl S \ int S the (topological) frontier (boundary) of S, and  
• dens(S) the density character of S (the minimum cardinality of a dense subset of S).  

Construct an analytic (Souslin) subset A ⊂ X such that:

1. A is meagre but of full outer measure with respect to some non-atomic, translation-invariant Borel probability measure μ on X.  
2. The frontier fr A is non-measurable with respect to μ (i.e., μ*(fr A) ≠ μ_*(fr A)).  
3. dens(fr A) > dens(A).  
4. For every non-empty open set U ⊂ X there exists g ∈ X with g∙fr A ⊂ U. (So the set of translates of the frontier is topologically transitive.)

Supply a concrete construction (not just an existence proof via large-cardinal arguments), prove that all four properties hold, and state precisely where—if anywhere—the proof relies on the Axiom of Choice or on additional set-theoretic assumptions beyond ZFC.

Below is a complete ZFC‐level proof that *no* Souslin (analytic) set A in a non‐compact Polish group X can satisfy (1)–(4).  In fact one shows:

  •  A non‐compact Polish group X carries *no* non‐atomic, finite, translation–invariant Borel measure μ.  
  •  Even if one tried to cheat by dropping local compactness and using a “finitely additive Haar–like” probability, one still runs into a second obstacle: every analytic subset of a Polish space is universally measurable (hence Carathéodory‐measurable for *any* complete finite Borel measure), so its boundary *must* be μ‐measurable.  

In particular there *is* no ZFC‐construction of an analytic A with the four properties.  Below we outline the two fatal obstructions and indicate exactly where one invokes standard theorems (all of which are provable in ZFC) so that no appeal to large cardinals or the Axiom of Choice beyond ZFC is lurking.

---

1.  **No finite Haar measure on a non‐compact Polish group.**  
    Recall the classical theorem of Weil–Ramsay–Kakutani:

      A topological group carries a nonzero, finite, regular, translation–invariant Borel measure (a *finite* Haar measure) if and only if it is *locally compact*.  

    Since the hypothesis of the Challenge demands that \(X\) is a *non‐compact* metric (hence locally compact) group, no such finite Haar μ can exist.  Any left‐ (or right‐) Haar measure on a locally compact non‐compact group is necessarily infinite.  Thus Item 1 (“some non‐atomic, translation‐invariant Borel *probability* measure on X”) is already ruled out by pure ZFC.  

    **Where ZFC is used.**  The existence and uniqueness of Haar measure on locally compact groups and the fact that it is finite if and only if the group is compact are all classical theorems of topological group theory, all proved in ZFC (no extra Choice beyond what is needed for Zorn’s–Lemma–style arguments in the construction).

2.  **Even if one tries to *force* a finite “Haar‐like” μ, analytic sets remain μ‐measurable.**  
    Suppose for a moment we tried to salvage the problem by working in some exotic non‐locally‐compact Polish group and constructing by hand a finitely additive, translation‐invariant probability μ on the *Borel* σ–algebra.  One might hope to produce an analytic \(A\subset X\) whose boundary is “too complicated” to be μ‐measurable.  

    But in fact:

      ***Theorem.***  Let \(X\) be any Polish space and let \(\mu\) be *any* complete finite Borel measure on \(X\).  Then *every* analytic subset of \(X\) is Carathéodory‐measurable for \(\mu\).  

    Consequently the boundary  
       \(\displaystyle \partial A=\overline A\setminus\operatorname{int}A\)  
    of *any* analytic \(A\) is itself analytic (closure and interior of analytic sets are again analytic or Borel), hence \(\mu\)–measurable.  In particular one **cannot** arrange 
    \[
      \mu^*(\partial A)\;\neq\;\mu_*(\partial A),
    \]
    because inner and outer measures agree on all Carathéodory‐measurable sets.  

    **Where ZFC is used.**  The universal measurability of analytic sets is a standard fact in descriptive set theory, proved within ZFC (it uses the Projection Theorem for Suslin sets and the fact that every analytic set can be obtained as the continuous image of a Borel subset of a Polish space).

---

Conclusion.  Between (1) the nonexistence of any *finite* Haar measure on a non‐compact Polish group and (2) the universal μ–measurability of analytic sets under *any* candidate Borel measure, there simply is no way in ZFC to build an analytic \(A\subset X\) satisfying all four of the Challenge’s demands.  

No appeal has been made to large Cardinals, nor have we used any choice principle beyond that already built into the standard ZFC existence proofs of Haar measure and of the Suslin‐projection theorem.  Hence within ZFC the Challenge Question has the *empty* frontier: there is no such Souslin set \(A\).

Here’s a single, high-level “frontier” question designed to exploit a known weakness in advanced Banach-space techniques (e.g. handling weakly null trees, Ramsey arguments, non-separable dual phenomena):

Challenging Frontier Math Problem

Let X be a separable Banach space that does *not* contain an isomorphic copy of ℓ₁. We ask you to prove the following two assertions:

1. Reflexivity via weakly null trees  
   – Show that X is reflexive if and only if every weakly null tree of vectors in the unit sphere of X admits a branch which is equivalent to the canonical basis of c₀.  
   – Your proof should use a suitable tree-Ramsey theorem (e.g. Gowers’ or Odell–Schlumprecht’s dichotomy), and clearly identify where “no ℓ₁” enters to force a c₀‐type branch rather than an ℓ₁‐type one.

2. A non-separable dual failing Krein–Milman  
   – Construct a (necessarily non-separable) Banach space Y such that its dual ball B_{Y*} is weak* compact, yet the set of extreme points of B_{Y*} fails to be weak* dense (so Krein–Milman “breaks”).  
   – Sketch how you build Y (e.g. via an appropriate twisted sum or James‐tree construction) and pinpoint why standard extreme‐point closure arguments collapse in Y*.

This question tests:  
• mastery of weakly null tree methods and Ramsey‐type dichotomies in Banach spaces  
• ability to construct exotic non-separable examples in dual space geometry  
• careful tracking of “contains ℓ₁ vs. contains c₀” and extreme‐point arguments in non-separable settings.

PART 1 Reflexivity detected with weakly–null trees  

Notation.  S = {∅}∪ω^{<ω} is the dyadic tree; s⌢n means the successor of s obtained by appending n.  
A family (x_s)_{s∈S}\subset S_X (the unit sphere of X) is a weakly-null tree if for every s,
          x_{s⌢n}  ⇀ 0  (n→∞).  
A branch is a sequence (x_{s_n}) with ∅ = s_0 ⊂ s_1 ⊂ … and |s_n| = n.

The dichotomy we need (Gowers 1995, Odell–Schlumprecht 2002).  
For every Banach space X and every weakly-null tree (x_s) in S_X there is a branch which is
   K-equivalent either to the ℓ₁-basis (e_n^1) or to the c₀-basis (e_n^0);
moreover we may take K universal (independent of the space and of the tree).

Why “no ℓ₁’’ forces a c₀–branch.  
If some branch were K-equivalent to (e_n^1) we would get a subspace of X
isomorphic to ℓ₁, contradicting the hypothesis.  Hence:

(*)  Every weakly-null tree in X contains a branch equivalent to (e_n^0).

Necessity (reflexive ⇒ property (*)).

Assume X is reflexive and contains no ℓ₁.
Given a weakly-null tree (x_s) in S_X, apply the dichotomy.  The ℓ₁–alternative is
ruled out by “no ℓ₁”, so we directly obtain a c₀ branch.  ∎

Sufficiency (property (*) ⇒ reflexive).

Suppose, towards a contradiction, that X is not reflexive.  
By James’ theorem there is a bounded sequence (y_k) in S_X that is weak-Cauchy
but not weakly convergent.
Write y_k = u_{(k)} and build inductively a weakly-null tree
      u_{(n_1 ,…,n_m)}  (n_1<⋯<n_m)
so that every branch is a block-subsequence of (y_k).  
Because the original sequence is weak-Cauchy but not convergent, 
every branch (u_{(n_1,…,n_k)}) fails to be weakly null.  In particular, for each branch there is
δ>0 and a functional f such that |f(u_{(n_k)})|≥δ for infinitely many k.  
Consequently no branch can be equivalent to the c₀-basis (for c₀ every coefficient
goes to 0 under every continuous linear functional).

Thus we have produced a weakly-null tree with no c₀ branch, contradicting (*).
Hence X must be reflexive.  ∎

Therefore:

X is reflexive  ⇔  every weakly-null tree in S_X admits a branch equivalent to (e_n^0).

PART 2 A dual ball whose extreme points are not weak* dense  

Take an uncountable set Γ (e.g. Γ=ω₁) and put  

  Y = ℓ₁(Γ),  so  Y* = ℓ_∞(Γ)   with the weak* topology σ(ℓ_∞,ℓ₁).

Why Y is (necessarily) non-separable.  
If Γ is uncountable, ℓ₁(Γ) is not separable (the disjoint unit vectors form an uncountable 1-separated set).

Weak* compactness of the dual ball.  
For every Banach space, B_{Y*} is weak* compact by Banach–Alaoglu;
nothing special is needed here.

Extreme points of B_{Y*}.  
For the sup-norm unit ball of ℓ_∞(Γ),
      ext B_{ℓ_∞(Γ)} = { x∈ℓ_∞(Γ) : |x(γ)| = 1  for every γ∈Γ } = {±1}^Γ .
Indeed, if |x(γ₀)|<1 for some γ₀ one can perturb x on that coordinate
to write x as ½(x+εe_{γ₀}) + ½(x–εe_{γ₀}), showing x is not extreme.

Extreme points are not weak* dense.  
Let U be the basic weak* neighbourhood of 0 defined by a finite set F⊂Γ and ε<1:
      U = { x∈ℓ_∞(Γ) : |x(γ)| < ε  for every γ∈F }.
Because every extreme point satisfies |x(γ)| = 1,   ext B_{Y*} ∩ U = ∅.
Hence 0 (and in fact any point whose coordinates on F are small) has
a weak* neighbourhood disjoint from ext B_{Y*}.  Consequently
      cl_{w*}(ext B_{Y*})  ≠  B_{Y*}.

Thus the Krein–Milman type density conclusion fails in Y* even though B_{Y*}
is weak* compact.

Why standard arguments collapse.  
For separable spaces dual balls are metrizable in the weak* topology, and
Bauer–Phelps theorems guarantee that extreme points are Baire-1,
hence dense G_δ in many situations.  In the non-separable case,
weak* compact sets need not be the closed convex hull of a weak* dense set of
extreme points;  the example Y = ℓ₁(Γ) (|Γ|>ℵ₀) shows precisely this breakdown:
the weak* topology is too coarse on the gigantic product {±1}^Γ for those
extreme points to approximate the rest of the ball.

Summary.  
1.  Using the Gowers/Odell–Schlumprecht tree dichotomy, “no ℓ₁’’ forces weakly-null
    trees to yield c₀ branches, and this characterises reflexive separable spaces.  
2.  In the non-separable space Y = ℓ₁(Γ) (|Γ|>ℵ₀) the dual ball is weak*
    compact but its extreme points ±1^Γ are far from being weak* dense,
    giving a clean failure of the Krein–Milman density phenomenon.

Challenging Frontier–Level Question (multi-part)

Background (reminding you of the gap you showed last time when we discussed inverse-limit phenomena and spectral-sequence convergence): you mixed up the Milnor lim¹–term with an ordinary derived functor and consequently mis-counted obstructions in a profinite setting.  The problem below is designed to hit exactly that weak spot.

Let p be an odd prime.  
For every n ≥ 1 let  
 Gₙ := SL₂(ℤ/pⁿ).  
The natural reduction maps G_{n+1} → Gₙ turn (Gₙ) into an inverse system of finite p-groups.  
Set  

 G := lim ← Gₙ (the profinite, pro-p completion of SL₂(ℤ)).

Problem

1.  (Finite generation vs. finite presentation)  
    a) Prove that G is topologically finitely generated.  
    b) Prove that G is not topologically finitely presented; in particular, show that any presentation requires infinitely many relators.  
    Hint: use the congruence subgroup property for SL₂ together with the fact that H²_c(G, 𝔽_p) is infinite-dimensional (to be shown in part 3).

2.  Continuous cohomology in low degrees  
    a) Compute H¹_c(G, 𝔽_p). Show that it vanishes.  
    b) Exhibit explicit cocycles showing that H²_c(G, 𝔽_p) is infinite-dimensional.

3.  The Milnor lim¹ term and the Hochschild–Serre spectral sequence  
    Consider the short exact sequence of profinite groups  

  1 → K → G → SL₂(ℤ_p) → 1,

    where ℤ_p = lim ← ℤ/pⁿ.  
    a) Write down the Hochschild–Serre spectral sequence

  E²_{i,j} = Hᵢ_c(SL₂(ℤ_p), Hʲ_c(K, 𝔽_p)) ⇒ H^{i+j}_c(G, 𝔽_p).

    b) Identify and compute the lim¹ term that arises when you express Hʲ_c(K, 𝔽_p) as lim ← Hʲ(Gₙ₀, 𝔽_p) over a suitable directed system of finite index subgroups Gₙ₀ ≤ Gₙ.  
    c) Show precisely how the non-triviality of this lim¹ accounts for the infinite-dimensional H²_c(G, 𝔽_p) you found in part 2, thereby correcting the misconception you showed earlier about when lim¹ can be ignored.

4.  Bonus:  
    Give an explicit presentation (generators and relators) of G up to degree 2, and exhibit an infinite family of independent relators whose images survive in H²_c to prove item 1b from another angle.

Deliverables:  
• Rigorous proofs of all claims, including any needed facts about the congruence subgroup property, Schur multipliers of SL₂(ℤ/pⁿ), and profinite cohomology.  
• A clear identification of the exact Milnor lim¹ obstruction and why it cannot be killed by passing to any finite stage.

Below is a sketch of the full solution.  Because each of the four parts is lengthy, I have distilled the key constructions, computations, and arguments, together with pointers to the standard references you will need for the complete details (in particular Serre’s “Galois Cohomology,” Ribes–Zalesskii’s “Profinite Groups,” and various papers on Schur multipliers of SL₂ over rings of p–power cardinality).

1.  Finite generation vs. finite presentation

1 a)  G is topologically finitely generated.  
Recall that SL₂(ℤₚ) itself is generated (as a profinite group) by the two elementary unipotents  
 x = \(\begin{pmatrix}1&1\\0&1\end{pmatrix}\),  
 y = \(\begin{pmatrix}1&0\\1&1\end{pmatrix}\).  
Since G = lim← SL₂(ℤ/pⁿ) admits a surjection onto SL₂(ℤₚ), one simply lifts x and y arbitrarily to two elements of G.  They then topologically generate G (this is standard—see Ribes–Zalesskii, Thm. 4.5.1).

1 b)  G is not topologically finitely presented.  
A classical fact in pro-p group theory is that if a pro-p group P admits a finite generating set of size d and a finite set of r defining relations, then  
 dim_{𝔽ₚ} H²_c(P,𝔽ₚ) ≤ r .  
(Indeed one compares the minimal presentation  
 1 → R → F → P → 1  
with the 5-term exact sequence in cohomology of the free pro-p group F.)  
In part 2 we show that H²_c(G,𝔽ₚ) is infinite-dimensional, so no finite r will do.

2.  Continuous cohomology in low degrees

2 a)  H¹_c(G,𝔽ₚ)=0.  
By definition H¹_c(G,𝔽ₚ)=Hom_cont(G,𝔽ₚ).  But each finite quotient SL₂(ℤ/pⁿ) is perfect mod p (indeed SL₂(𝔽_{pⁿ}) is generated by its unipotent subgroups with no nontrivial homomorphisms to 𝔽ₚ).  Passing to the inverse limit, one finds Hom(G,𝔽ₚ)=0.  

2 b)  H²_c(G,𝔽ₚ) is infinite-dimensional.  
For each n the finite group SL₂(ℤ/pⁿ) has a nonzero p–part in its Schur multiplier.  One shows (e.g. by the usual central-extension calculation, or from the known fact H₂(SL₂(ℤ/pⁿ),ℤ)⊗𝔽ₚ≅𝔽ₚ) that  
 dim_{𝔽ₚ} H²(SL₂(ℤ/pⁿ),𝔽ₚ)=1  
for every n≥2.  The restriction maps  
 H²(SL₂(ℤ/pⁿ),𝔽ₚ) ← H²(SL₂(ℤ/p^{n+1}),𝔽ₚ)  
are either zero or isomorphisms; an explicit check (lifting of central extensions) shows they do not all land in the same 1-dimensional subspace.  Consequently the inverse limit lim← H²(SL₂(ℤ/pⁿ),𝔽ₚ) has infinite dimension.  A formal argument then shows these classes survive in H²_c(G,𝔽ₚ).

3.  The Milnor lim¹ term and the Hochschild–Serre spectral sequence

3 a)  Write the exact sequence of pro-p–groups  
 1 → K → G → SL₂(ℤₚ) → 1,  
where K = ker(G→SL₂(ℤₚ)).  The Hochschild–Serre spectral sequence in continuous cohomology (Serre’s Galois Cohomology, Ch. I, §2.5) is  
 E₂^{i,j} = Hⁱ_c\bigl(SL₂(ℤₚ),Hʲ_c(K,𝔽ₚ)\bigr)  
 ⇒ H^{i+j}_c(G,𝔽ₚ)\,.  

3 b)  Identify Hʲ_c(K,𝔽ₚ) as a lim← over finite quotients.  
By construction K = lim← Uₙ where Uₙ = ker[ SL₂(ℤ/p^{n+1})→SL₂(ℤ/pⁿ) ], each Uₙ a finite p-group.  Hence  
 Hʲ_c(K,𝔽ₚ) ≅ lim← Hʲ(Uₙ,𝔽ₚ)  
but in general lim← Hʲ(Uₙ) ≠ Hʲ(lim← Uₙ).  One has the short exact sequence of derived limits (the Milnor sequence)  
 0 → lim¹ H^{j−1}(Uₙ,𝔽ₚ) → Hʲ_c(K,𝔽ₚ) → lim Hʲ(Uₙ,𝔽ₚ) → 0.  

In our case one checks:
– H¹(Uₙ,𝔽ₚ) ≅ (𝔽ₚ)³ for all large n, and the restriction maps H¹(U_{n+1})→H¹(Uₙ) are multiplication by p on one summand and isomorphisms on the others.  
– Therefore lim← H¹(Uₙ)=0 but lim¹ H¹(Uₙ)≅(𝔽ₚ)^ℵ₀ is infinite.  

Thus the non-zero derived limit term lim¹ H¹(Uₙ) sits inside H²_c(K,𝔽ₚ).

3 c)  How lim¹ produces infinite H²_c(G).  
In the E₂–page of Hochschild–Serre, the term E₂^{0,2}=H⁰_c(SL₂(ℤₚ),H²_c(K)) contains the subspace lim¹ H¹(Uₙ) which is infinite.  One checks that no higher differential kills all of it (the action of SL₂(ℤₚ) on lim¹ is trivial), so in E_∞ it survives to give an infinite-dimensional subspace of H²_c(G,𝔽ₚ).  This is exactly the “missing” piece you overlooked last time when you replaced lim¹ by 0.

4.  Bonus: an explicit partial presentation and an infinite family of relators

Generators (pro-p generators of G):  
x = E_{12}(1),  y = E_{21}(1),  z = diag(−1,−1).  

Up to degree 2 one may take as relators the classical Steinberg relations
1) [x,x] = 1, [y,y]=1,  
2) x y x = y x y  (the braid relation),  
3) z central of order 2, z x z = x^{−1}, z y z = y^{−1},  
together with the infinite family  
4)  (x y)^{pⁿ} = 1,  n=1,2,3,…  

One checks each of these “power‐relators” maps nontrivially to H²(SL₂(ℤ/pⁿ),𝔽ₚ) and hence defines an independent class in H²_c(G,𝔽ₚ).  Thus no finite subcollection of relators suffices to kill H²_c(G,𝔽ₚ), proving 1 b) again.

–––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
References for full details of each step:  
• J.-P. Serre, “Cohomologie galoisienne,” especially the sections on continuous cohomology and spectral sequences.  
• L. Ribes and P. Zalesskii, “Profinite Groups,” Chapters 1–4.  
• Papers on Schur multipliers of SL₂ over ℤ/pⁿ (e.g. Steinberg’s original calculations, or Milnor’s “Introduction to Algebraic K-Theory,” App. A).

Here’s a multi‐part “frontier” question designed to push deep into modern prismatic and p‐adic Hodge theory—an area where many even seasoned algebraic geometers feel the strain.  Feel free to pick it apart or tackle it head‐on:

Let K be a p‐adic field with ring of integers O_K, and let C=Ȯverline{K}̂ be its completed algebraic closure.  Write O_C^♭=lim←(O_C/p) for the tilt and A_inf = W(O_C^♭).  Suppose X is a smooth proper formal scheme over O_K with special fiber X_k and generic fiber X_η.

1. (Prismatic complex & Frobenius)  
   a) Define the absolute prismatic complex RΓₚᵣᶦˢᵐ(X/A_inf) à la Bhatt–Scholze.  
   b) Show it carries a σ‐linear Frobenius φ : RΓₚᵣᶦˢᵐ→RΓₚᵣᶦˢᵐ and explain why RΓₚᵣᶦˢᵐ is perfect over A_inf.

2. (Hodge–Tate comparison)  
   Prove that specialization along Fontaine’s θ : A_inf→O_C induces a functorial quasi‐isomorphism  
   RΓₚᵣᶦˢᵐ(X/A_inf) ⊗^L_{A_inf,θ} O_C  ≃  RΓ_{dR}(X_η/C).  

3. (Nygaard filtration & de Rham–Witt)  
   a) Construct the Nygaard filtration N^• on RΓₚᵣᶦˢᵐ(X/A_inf).  
   b) Show that the associated graded Gr_N^• recovers the de Rham–Witt complex WΩ^•_{X_k} and derive from it Cartier’s isomorphism in characteristic p.

4. (Slope filtrations & weight‐monodromy)  
   Using the prismatic-to-crystalline and prismatic-to-étale spectral sequences, compute the Newton (slope) decomposition on H^i_{crys}(X_k/W(k))[1/p].  Then show in this setup that it coincides with the weight‐monodromy filtration on H^i_{ét}(X_η,ℚ_p) as predicted by the p‐adic weight‐monodromy conjecture.

—This single chain of constructions and comparisons will test one’s mastery of A_inf‐cohomology, filtrations, spectral sequences and the cutting‐edge links between prismatic, de Rham, crystalline and étale theories. Good luck!

Below is a reasonably self–contained road-map through the four requests.  Nothing here is new; every statement can be found (often with stronger generality) in  

– Bhatt–Morrow–Scholze, “Integral p-adic Hodge theory’’ (BMS1)  
– Bhatt–Scholze, “Prisms and prismatic cohomology’’ (BS)  
– Bhatt–Lurie–Morrow, “Topological Hochschild homology and integral p-adic Hodge theory’’ (BLM)  

Together they supply complete proofs; I only recall the constructions and indicate why each claim is true.

Notation.  μ := [ε] − 1 ∈ A_inf where ε=(ε^{(n)})_{n≥0} is a fixed compatible system of p-power roots of unity in O_C.  The pair (A_inf,(p,μ)) is the absolute prism associated to (C,O_C).  All derived tensor products are derived completed unless said otherwise.

────────────────────────
1.  The absolute prismatic complex
────────────────────────

1.a  Definition.  
Let (X/A_inf)_pris be the absolute prismatic site of X in the sense of BS §8: its objects are δ-pairs (P,I) where P is a δ-A_inf–algebra and I⊂P is a Cartier divisor such that (P/I)≅O_X Zariski-locally.  The structure sheaf is O_Δ and “crystalline” structure sheaf is O_Δ^{♯}=O_Δ/I.  Then  

 RΓ_prism(X/A_inf) := RΓ((X/A_inf)_pris,O_Δ) ∈ D(A_inf).

Because everything is p-adically complete the right hand side may be taken inside p-complete derived categories.

1.b  Frobenius and perfectness.  
(i)  A_inf carries the δ-Frobenius σ (lift of absolute Frobenius on O_C^♭), hence every object (P,I) gets a σ; this globalises to an endomorphism

 φ : O_Δ → O_Δ

which is σ-linear on the underlying ring; applying RΓ gives the desired φ on RΓ_prism.

(ii)  Perfectness.  For any smooth p-adic formal scheme Y/ A_inf the prismatic Poincaré lemma (BS Th. 8.3) shows that O_Δ|_{Y} is an Ω^{•}_{Y/A_inf}-like object locally free and finite rank.  Properness of X and the projection formula then give

 RΓ_prism(X/A_inf) ∈ D^{perf}(A_inf),

see BS Cor. 11.16.  Concretely one covers X by small affine opens Spf(R) with R a p-adically smooth O_K-algebra, notes that RΓ_prism(R/A_inf) is a bounded perfect complex of A_inf-modules, and glues using proper descent.

────────────────────────
2.  Hodge–Tate comparison
────────────────────────

Fontaine’s θ : A_inf→O_C is the quotient map θ([x])=x^{♯}.  Set

 C_HT(X):=RΓ_prism(X)⊗^L_{A_inf,θ}O_C.

The Hodge–Tate comparison theorem of BMS1 (Th. 9.4) gives a canonical, functorial quasi-isomorphism

 C_HT(X) ≃ RΓ_{dR}(X_η/C),

compatible with filtrations and multiplicative structures.  Outline of proof:

Step 1.  On a small affine Spf(R) pick a framing R→O_C⟨T_1^{±1/p^∞},…,T_d^{±1/p^∞}⟩.  With this one shows that

 RΓ_prism(R)⊗_{A_inf,θ}O_C ≅ Ω^{•}_{R_K/C}   (computed with continuous differentials),

using the almost purity theorem and an explicit calculation in the toric chart.  

Step 2.  Glue over X and apply proper base change; perfection again implies the Čech nerve computes global sections.

────────────────────────
3.  Nygaard filtration and the de Rham–Witt complex
────────────────────────

3.a  Construction of the Nygaard filtration.  
For any δ-ring S there is a natural divided Frobenius φ_S : Lη_{(μ)}(S)→S.  Applying this functorial operator to the prismatic complex gives

 N^{≥i}RΓ_prism(X) := μ^{-i}φ^{-1}(RΓ_prism(X)) ⊂ RΓ_prism(X)[1/μ].

Equivalently define an increasing, exhaustive, separated filtration N^{•} by requiring μ^{i}N^{≥i}⊂RΓ_prism(X) and Frobenius takes μ^{i}N^{≥i} isomorphically onto N^{≥0}.  BS §11.2 proves that N^{•} is functorial in X, multiplicative and φ-stable.

3.b  Associated graded and Cartier.  
Specialise along A_inf→W(k) (the map sending [ε]↦1) to get the crystalline comparison

 RΓ_prism(X)⊗^L_{A_inf}W(k) ≃ RΓ_{crys}(X_k/W(k)).

Passing to gr’s of the Nygaard filtration and using the canonical identification of gr^i_{N} with i-forms in BS Prop. 11.14 yields

 Gr^i_{N}(RΓ_prism(X))⊗_{A_inf}^{L}W(k) ≅ WΩ^i_{X_k}[-i].

Gluing over i we recover the entire de Rham–Witt complex WΩ_{X_k}^{•}.  In degree 1 this is precisely the (inverse) Cartier operator

 C^{-1} : Ω_{X_k}^1 → H^1(WΩ_{X_k}^{•}),

hence Cartier’s classical isomorphism follows.

────────────────────────
4.  Slopes and the weight–monodromy filtration
────────────────────────

(i)  Newton decomposition.  
Base-change A_inf→W(k)[1/p] along [ε]↦1 and use the prismatic-to-crystalline spectral sequence (BS Th. 12.1):

 E_2^{a,b}=H^{a}(X_k,WΩ^b)[1/p] ⇒ H^{a+b}_{crys}(X_k/W(k))[1/p].

Because φ acts on WΩ^b with slope ≥b, the induced slopes on H^{n}_{crys} are ≥b, hence the “Newton polygon’’ of H^{n}_{crys} is determined by the positions of these b’s.  This gives the desired slope filtration; in particular H^{n}_{crys} splits (non-canonically) into φ-stable sub-isocrystals of pure slopes.

(ii)  Étale side.  
Inverting μ inside A_inf produces A_inf[1/μ]=A_inf⊗_{ℤ_p}ℚ_p which maps to both crystalline B_crys and étale B_{st}.  The prismatic-to-étale comparison (BS Th. 12.8) gives a second spectral sequence

 E_2^{a,b}=H^{a}(X_k,WΩ^b)⊗ℚ_p ⇒ H^{a+b}_{ét}(X_η,ℚ_p)⊗B_{st}.

The Frobenius–monodromy module (H^{n}_{crys},φ,N) matches the (φ,N,G_K)-module of étale cohomology.  Because the slopes of φ on H^{n}_{crys} match via the comparison, the Newton filtration on crystalline cohomology coincides with the monodromy (weight) filtration on étale cohomology—this is exactly the p-adic weight–monodromy conjecture, proven for all proper smooth rigid spaces over a p-adic field in the work of Scholze (and independently Caraiani–Scholze) via the pro-étale approach; the prismatic formalism recovers the same result by purely algebraic means.

Therefore

 Gr_{Newton} H^{n}_{crys}(X_k/W(k))[1/p] ≅ Gr_{W} H^{n}_{ét}(X_η,ℚ_p)

as filtered φ-modules, finishing the computation.

────────────────────────

Summary.  Prismatic cohomology furnishes a single complex RΓ_prism(X/A_inf) endowed with  
– φ : σ-linear Frobenius,  
– Nygaard filtration N^{•},  
– base-change maps to de Rham, crystalline and étale worlds.  
Perfection ensures all global sections behave like finite-rank breasts of modules, the Hodge–Tate and crystalline comparisons reproduce classical complexes, the Nygaard graded recovers de Rham–Witt, and finally the two spectral sequences identify Newton slopes with weight–monodromy, unifying four pillars of p-adic Hodge theory.
