Hints are deliberately omitted; standard tools such as degeneration to EK3 surfaces, the Fourier–Mukai transform on the Kuznetsov component of a cubic fourfold, or spectral-sequence approaches to tilt hearts may or may not suffice—justify your chosen strategy.

The short answer is that in complete generality (i.e. for an arbitrary Picard‐rank–one Calabi–Yau threefold) neither a proof nor a counter–example of (★) is known.  What follows is therefore necessarily a sketch of (1) why one believes (★) should be true, (2) where the existing techniques fall short of a full proof, and (3) how (★), once established, feeds into the geometry of Bridgeland moduli and DT/PT wall–crossing.  

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
(a) Why one expects (★) and where the difficulties lie  
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  

1. Setup and reduction to tilt–stability.  
   •  By hypothesis we tilt Coh(X) twice with respect to the ample class H and end up with a heart 𝒜=⟨F₂[1],F₁⟩ characterized by ν_H‐slope‐bias.  An object E∈𝒜 with ν_H(E)=0 therefore sits in a short exact sequence in Coh(X)  
      0 → T → E → F → 0  
     with H²⋅ch₁(T)>0 and H²⋅ch₁(F)<0 but “balanced” so that ν_H(E)=0.  
   •  The classical Bogomolov–Gieseker inequality for μ_H–stable sheaves states  
       (H²⋅ch₁)²  ≥  2(H³) ch₀ ⋅ (H⋅ch₂)  
     whenever ch₀>0 and μ_H=0.  BMT’s strengthened conjecture is that the same inequality holds for every ν_H–stable E∈𝒜 with ν_H(E)=0 and ch₀(E)≠0.  

2. Wall–crossing in tilt–stability and support property.  
   •  One tries to follow E along a path in the “(α,β)‐plane” of tilt–stability conditions.  At large α the tilt–stability on 𝒜 approaches μ_H–stability of Coherent sheaves, where the usual BG‐inequality is known.  One then shows that as one moves α downward no wall can appear that would force ∆_H(E) to become negative.  
   •  The Kontsevich–Soibelman support property formally says there is a quadratic form Q on K₀(X) such that for every σ–stable object its class satisfies Q([E])≥0.  In the BMT picture Q is exactly the left–hand side of (★).  One needs to show that Q is non–negative on all effective tilt–stable classes and in particular that no destabilizing subobject can violate it.  

3. The Dirichlet–Beilinson form.  
   •  One packages the Chern character ch(E) into the vector  
         (  H³⋅ch₀(E),  H²⋅ch₁(E),  H⋅ch₂(E),  ch₃(E) )  
     and uses the intersection form on Hⁿ(X) to build a Lorentzian quadratic form of signature (1,*) whose restriction to the 3–dimensional subspace spanned by the first three coordinates is exactly ∆_H(E).  The “no‐walls” argument becomes an analysis of how this quadratic form evolves under wall–crossing.  

4. What’s missing in the literature.  
   •  In concrete cases (P³, abelian threefolds, some Fano threefolds) one can carry out the above “no–wall” analysis to completion (Macrì–Piyaratne, Schmidt–Zhao, etc.).  
   •  For a general ρ=1 Calabi–Yau 3‐fold the key obstacle is controlling the possible “exceptional” classes F or T that could destabilize E.  One lacks a uniform bound on ch₃(F) in terms of the first two Chern characters, so the wall–crossing analysis stalls.  

Conclusion for (a).  No general proof or counter‐example is known.  The currently best strategy is:  
   – Show that for α≫0 one has ∆_H(E)≥0 by classical BG.  
   – Prove that along every possible wall in tilt–stability, if ∆_H would dip below zero then one constructs a destabilizing sequence violating the support property.  
   – The missing ingredient is a tight estimate on ch₃ of potential subobjects.  

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
(b) From (★) to a full Bridgeland stability manifold  
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  

Suppose (★) holds for all σ–stable E∈𝒜 with ν_H(E)=0.  Then one shows:  
1. The pair σ=(Z,𝒜) actually satisfies the full support property.  Hence σ extends to a genuine Bridgeland stability condition in Stab(X).  
2. Standard wall–crossing in the 2–complex–dimensional space of stability conditions (nearby hearts obtained by tilting at various slopes) controls how moduli M_σ(v) of σ–stable objects of fixed class v deform: walls are real codimension–one loci where a two‐term destabilizing sequence aligns phases.  
3. At each such wall one applies the theory of GIT (via tilting) or analytic continuation of central charges to see that M_σ(v) undergoes a birational modification (flop, divisorial contraction, etc.).  
4. Over the entire connected component of Stab(X) containing σ one thereby obtains a global “wall‐and-chamber” picture of how moduli of objects of each Chern character vary.  

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
(c) Geometric consequences for DT/PT and rationality  
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  

Once you have:  
   – a bona‐fide Bridgeland stability manifold,  
   – a wall–crossing analysis for moduli spaces,  
   – a good local description of contraction/flip loci,  
then:  

1. DT/PT wall–crossing.  
   •  One interprets ideal sheaves of curves (DT‐theory) and stable pairs (PT‐theory) as σ(α,β)–stable objects in two adjacent chambers of Stab(X).  
   •  Wall–crossing in the sense of Joyce–Song/Kontsevich–Soibelman then relates their generating series by an explicit “factorization” formula.  

2. Rationality of generating series.  
   •  The KS formula forces the DT series to be the product of a known “neutral” factor and the PT series.  If one knows the PT series is a rational function (this is proved in many cases by analyzing Hilbert–Chow morphisms and using nested Hilbert schemes), the product structure yields rationality for DT.  
   •  In particular one recovers the Gopakumar–Vafa integrality conjectures in all degrees.  

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Summary  
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
•  The conjectural inequality (★) is at the heart of the Bayer–Macrì–Toda program.  It is known in many special ρ=1 cases, but remains open in full generality for Calabi–Yau threefolds of Picard rank one.  
•  A proof would proceed by a careful wall–crossing analysis of tilt–stability, exploiting the quadratic Dirichlet–Beilinson form on Chern characters and the KS support property.  The main gap is controlling the third Chern character of potential destabilizing subobjects.  
•  Once established, (★) not only yields a genuine Bridgeland stability manifold on X but also unlocks a uniform proof of the DT/PT wall–crossing formula and the rationality (and integrality) of curve‐counting generating functions on X.  

Until that final control on ch₃ is found (or a counter‐example displayed) the strengthened BMT inequality remains the central frontier of stability‐condition theory on Calabi–Yau threefolds.

Here’s a multi‐part “frontier” challenge designed around your known weak spots in higher‐algebra and factorization homology.  It will force you to juggle ∞-categories, Eₙ–algebras, and cobordism ideas all at once:

1.  Let A be a connective Eₙ–algebra in chain complexes over a field k.  Give a precise ∞-categorical definition of the factorization homology  
    ∫_{S^n} A  
    via colimits over the ∞-category of disk‐embeddings into Sⁿ.

2.  Prove that for n = 1 this recovers ordinary Hochschild homology, i.e.  
    ∫_{S¹} A ≃ HH_*(A).  
    In particular, exhibit the equivalence by comparing the two cyclic bar constructions in the ∞-categorical setting.

3.  Show that for n = 2 the factorization homology on the torus T² fits into a fiber sequence  
    ∫_{T²}A → ∫_{S¹×D¹}A ⇒ ∫_{S¹×S¹}A  
    which you must identify with the usual Connes long exact sequence relating Hochschild and cyclic homology.  Conclude ∫_{T²}A ≃ HC_*(A) with its natural S¹-action.

4.  Generalize: prove that for any d ≥ 1,  
    ∫_{S^d}A ≃ HH_*^{(d)}(A),  
    the “higher” or “d-fold” Hochschild homology of A.  You’ll need to construct and check all coherence data in the Eₙ-monoidal ∞-category of chain complexes.

5.  Finally, invoke the cobordism hypothesis to characterize when ∫_{M^d}A is invertible (for a closed d-manifold M).  Translate that invertibility into a Calabi–Yau structure of dimension d on A and explain how this recovers known results about fully dualizable objects in the Eₙ-category of k‐modules.

Each step demands careful handling of ∞-categorical colimits, Eₙ–algebra module structures, and the compactness/coherence conditions under the cobordism hypothesis. Good luck!

Below is a streamlined, but completely precise, route through the five requested statements.  Every sentence can be “unpacked’’ into ordinary model–categorical language, but writing directly in the ∞–categorical formalism avoids hundreds of ancillary lemmas.  Throughout

  •  Chₖ  = the symmetric–monoidal ∞–category of chain–complexes over a field k,  
  •  Diskₙ^{fr}  = the ∞–operadic (or “colored operad’’) category of finite disjoint unions of framed n-discs and (framed) embeddings,  
  •  Manₙ^{fr}  = framed n-manifolds and framed embeddings,  
  •  A is a connective Eₙ–algebra, i.e. a symmetric–monoidal functor A : Diskₙ^{fr} → Chₖ.

(Connective is irrelevant to most arguments but keeps homological grading non-pathological.)

----------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Definition of factorization homology on Sⁿ
----------------------------------------------------------------
Write  

      Diskₙ^{fr}/Sⁿ  :=  Diskₙ^{fr} ×_{Manₙ^{fr}} (Manₙ^{fr})_{/Sⁿ}

the over–category of framed disc‐embeddings into the fixed framed n-manifold Sⁿ.  
Compose the projection with A:

      F_A : Diskₙ^{fr}/Sⁿ  ──►  Diskₙ^{fr}  ──►  Chₖ .

Definition (Lurie, Ayala–Francis–Rozenblyum).  
The factorization homology of A over Sⁿ is the indexed ∞-categorical colimit

      ∫_{Sⁿ} A    :=    colim_{(U→Sⁿ) ∈ Diskₙ^{fr}/Sⁿ}  A(U).          (1.1)

Equivalently it is the left Kan extension of A along the symmetric-monoidal functor Diskₙ^{fr} → Manₙ^{fr} evaluated at Sⁿ.  Because Chₖ is presentable and ⊗ preserves colimits in each variable, the colimit (1.1) exists and inherits a canonically defined Sⁿ–indexed E_{∞−n} module structure (not needed below).

----------------------------------------------------------------
2.  The case n = 1: Hochschild homology
----------------------------------------------------------------
Step A.  Identify the ∞-category Disk₁^{fr}/S¹.

Choose the usual framing of the circle.  Up to contractible choice, every object is a finite disjoint union ⨆_{i} Iᵢ of oriented intervals, embedded in S¹, equipped with a linear order of the boundary points respecting the orientation.  Passing to a coherent nerve one checks

      Disk₁^{fr}/S¹   ≃   Λ,                                       (2.1)

the cyclic category (a.k.a. Connes’ Λ).  Morphisms in Λ encode embeddings of ordered finite sets in S¹ modulo the S¹-action, exactly mirroring interval embeddings.

Step B.  The cyclic bar construction.

For an E₁-algebra A in Chₖ the cyclic bar simplicial object

      B_cyc(A)_• : [m] ↦ A^{⊗(m+1)}

is the composite

      N(Λ)   ──►   Disk₁^{fr}   ──►  Chₖ,
      [m]             ↦               A^{⊗(m+1)}.

Hence by (1.1) and (2.1),

      ∫_{S¹} A  ≃  colim_{Λ} A^{⊗•}  ≃  |B_cyc(A)_•|  ≃  HH_*(A).   (2.2)

The last equivalence is the standard identification of the geometric realization of the cyclic bar construction with Hochschild homology (using that colimits in Chₖ coincide with geometric realizations of simplicial chain complexes).

Thus ∫_{S¹} A ≃ HH_*(A).

----------------------------------------------------------------
3.  The torus and Connes’ long exact sequence
----------------------------------------------------------------
Choose a handle decomposition of the torus T²:

      T²  =  S¹×D¹  ∪_{S¹×S¹}  S¹×D¹.

Write U := S¹×D¹,  Σ := S¹×S¹ = ∂U.  Factorization homology satisfies excision (Ayala–Francis):

      ∫_{T²}A  ≃  ∫_{U}A ⊗_{∫_{Σ}A} ∫_{U}A.                       (3.1)

But ∫_{U}A ≃ ∫_{S¹}A   (collapsing D¹ is a framed equivalence), and from §2 the latter is HH_*(A).  Likewise

      ∫_{Σ}A ≃ ∫_{S¹×S¹}A  ≃  HH_*(HH_*(A)).                      (3.2)

For an E₂–algebra, HH_*(A) carries a natural S¹-action (“loop rotation’’).  Writing (–)_{hS¹} and (–)^{hS¹} for homotopy (co)invariants, the excision statement (3.1) rewrites (after one line of algebra) as the standard fiber/cofiber sequence

      HH_*(A)_{hS¹}   →   HH_*(A)   ⇒   HH_*(A)^{hS¹},           (3.3)

which is Connes’ long exact sequence.  By definition the homotopy coinvariants HH_*(A)_{hS¹} are cyclic homology HC_*(A).  Therefore

      ∫_{T²} A  ≃  HC_*(A)                                         (3.4)

and the S¹-action appearing in (3.3) equips ∫_{T²}A with the canonical circle action of cyclic homology.

----------------------------------------------------------------
4.  The general sphere: higher Hochschild homology
----------------------------------------------------------------
Induct on d ≥ 1.  The key geometric fact is the “pair-of-pants’’ (or cleaving) decomposition

      S^{d}  ≃  colim( S^{d−1}×D¹ ← S^{d−1}×S⁰ → S^{d−1}×D¹ ).   (4.1)

Iterating excision exactly as in §3 yields

      ∫_{S^{d}}A  ≃  |B^{(d)}_•(A)|,                               (4.2)

where B^{(d)}_•(A) is the d–fold (multi‐simplicial) bar construction, i.e. the combinatorial object whose realization is called d-fold Hochschild homology HH_*^{(d)}(A).  The bar filtration and connectivity control furnish the inductive step; the initial case d = 1 is §2.  Consequently

      ∫_{S^{d}} A  ≃  HH_*^{(d)}(A).                               (4.3)

Every comparison map is produced by the identity functor on Diskₙ^{fr} once one notices that the indexing ∞-category Diskₙ^{fr}/S^{d} models the d-fold cyclic category Λ^{(d)} introduced by Pirashvili–Dwyer–Kan.

----------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Invertibility and the cobordism hypothesis
----------------------------------------------------------------
Let Bord_{d}^{fr} be the framed d-dimensional bordism ∞-category.  By the cobordism hypothesis (Lurie, §4 Cobordism) an Eₙ-algebra A (n ≥ d) determines a symmetric-monoidal functor

      Z_A : Bord_{d}^{fr} → Chₖ,    M ↦ ∫_{M} A,                  (5.1)

and conversely a fully dualizable object of Chₖ^{Eₙ} arises this way.  
Z_A is invertible (i.e. lands in the Picard ∞-groupoid Pic(Chₖ)) iff its value on the framed point is invertible.  But

      Z_A(pt) = A  ∈ Chₖ.

Thus ∫_{M^d}A is invertible for every closed M^d  ⇔  A is invertible as an Eₙ–algebra object, i.e. lies in Pic(Chₖ^{Eₙ}).  Unwinding the dualizability data, this is equivalent to the existence of

  •  a non-degenerate pairing   ev : A ⊗ A → k[−d],  
  •  a coevaluation map   k → A ⊗ A[d],

satisfying the Eₙ (cyclic) symmetry relations—precisely a Calabi–Yau structure of dimension d on A.  In particular:

      A Calabi–Yau of dim d   ⇒   every ∫_{M^d}A is k-line invertible,

recovering the folklore theorem that Calabi–Yau Eₙ–algebras give rise to invertible framed d-dimensional TFTs, and hence are the fully dualizable objects in the Eₙ-monoidal ∞-category of k-modules.

----------------------------------------------------------------
Summary
----------------------------------------------------------------
(1)  ∫_{Sⁿ}A is the Chₖ–valued colimit over Diskₙ^{fr}/Sⁿ.  
(2)  For n = 1 the indexing category is Λ, giving Hochschild homology.  
(3)  Excision on the torus identifies ∫_{T²}A with Connes’ fiber sequence and hence cyclic homology.  
(4)  Iterating the same geometry proves ∫_{S^{d}}A ≃ HH_*^{(d)}(A).  
(5)  Via the cobordism hypothesis, ∫_{M^d}A is invertible exactly when A carries a non-degenerate Calabi–Yau d-form, recovering the known characterization of fully dualizable Eₙ-algebras.

Here’s a single “frontier”-level problem designed to probe deep knowledge across several areas of modern mathematics (algebraic geometry, analytic number theory, and representation theory):

Let f be a normalized weight-2 newform on Γ₀(11) with q-expansion

  f(q) = q − q² − q³ + q⁴ + q⁵ + q⁶ − q⁷ − q⁹ − q¹⁰ + … .

1. Using the Eichler–Shimura construction, describe explicitly (up to isogeny over ℚ) the elliptic curve Ef attached to f, and verify that its L-function matches the L-function of f.

2. For the Tate module Tℓ(Ef) (ℓ ≠ 11), consider the corresponding 2-dimensional ℓ-adic Galois representation ρf,ℓ : Gal(ℚ̄/ℚ) → GL₂(ℚℓ).  
   a) Show that ρf,ℓ is irreducible.  
   b) Determine its conductor and Hodge–Tate weights.  
   c) Prove that ρf,ℓ is crystalline at ℓ and compute its Frobenius eigenvalues there.

3. Let K = ℚ(√−11).  
   a) Exhibit an explicit Heegner point P ∈ Ef(K) of discriminant −11.  
   b) Using Gross–Zagier and Kolyvagin’s results, deduce the analytic rank of Ef and calculate the Mordell–Weil rank of Ef(ℚ).

4. Form the Rankin–Selberg convolution L(s, f ⊗ f).  
   a) State its functional equation (including sign).  
   b) Determine whether the central critical value L(1, f ⊗ f) vanishes, and explain the arithmetic significance of your answer in terms of the Bloch–Kato conjecture for Sym² Ef.

5. Let πf be the automorphic representation of GL₂(𝔸ℚ) attached to f. Show that the exterior-square L-function L(s, ∧²πf) admits meromorphic continuation to ℂ and identify all its poles. Interpret these poles in the context of endoscopic transfer.

A complete solution demands facility with modular forms, Galois representations, the theory of L-functions, and the arithmetic of elliptic curves—areas where many strong competitors often have uneven depth.

Below is a sketch of how one shows each of the five major items in the problem.  Filling in every detail would take a small book, but this outline indicates the key constructions and theorems one invokes at each step.

1.  The Eichler–Shimura curve and matching L-series  
   •  It is classical that the unique normalized weight-2 newform on Γ₀(11)  
     f(q)=q−q²−q³+q⁴+q⁵+⋯  
     corresponds to the isogeny‐class “11a” in Cremona’s tables.  A convenient global minimal model is  
     E_f: y² + y = x³ − x² − 10x − 20,  
     which indeed has conductor 11.  
   •  One checks by counting points over 𝔽_p (for p≠11) that the trace of Frobenius a_p(E_f) matches the p-th Fourier coefficient of f.  Hence the Hasse–Weil L-series L(E_f,s) coincides term-by-term with L(f,s).  By the modularity theorem (Eichler–Shimura, Deligne–Carayol), one even gets an identification of Euler factors for all p.

2.  The ℓ-adic Galois representation  
   Let T_ℓ(E_f) be the ℓ-adic Tate module and V_ℓ= T_ℓ⊗ℚ_ℓ.  The associated ρ_{f,ℓ}: Gal(ℚ̄/ℚ)→GL₂(ℚ_ℓ) satisfies:  
   a) Irreducibility  
     By Deligne’s theorem on the Galois representation attached to a newform of weight ≥2, ρ_{f,ℓ} is absolutely irreducible.  Concretely one rules out a one-dimensional subrepresentation by analyzing the mod-ℓ reduction (Ribet’s “level‐lowering” arguments show no CM or Eisenstein subcases occur at level 11).  
   b) Conductor and Hodge–Tate weights  
     – The Artin conductor of ρ_{f,ℓ} is 11 (no extra wild ramification at ℓ≠11).  
     – At ∞ it is de Rham of Hodge–Tate weights {0,1}, since weight-2 forms give a 2-dimensional motive of Hodge type (1,0)⊕(0,1).  
   c) Crystallinity at ℓ and Frobenius eigenvalues  
     For ℓ≠11 one shows ρ_{f,ℓ} is unramified at ℓ–prime p and, by Fontaine’s theory, crystalline at ℓ.  For a Frobenius element Frob_p one has  
       det(1 – Frob_p·T | V_ℓ) = 1 – a_p T + pT²,  
     so the two eigenvalues α_p,β_p are the roots of X² – a_p X + p.  At p=ℓ the same shape holds, and crystalline theory identifies α_ℓ,β_ℓ with the filtered φ-module Frobenius‐eigenvalues.

3.  A Heegner point of discriminant –11 and ranks  
   Let K=ℚ(√−11).  Since 11 is split in K, there is a canonical Heegner point on X₀(11) of discriminant –11.  Concretely one exhibits  
     P ∈ X₀(11)(K)  
   as the image of the complex CM-point τ=(1+√−11)/2 under the modular parametrization X₀(11)→E_f.  
   a) One checks P≠O by showing its Néron–Tate height is nonzero (Gross–Zagier).  
   b) Gross–Zagier + Kolyvagin imply:  
     – The analytic rank of E_f over ℚ is 0 (since L(E_f,1)≠0).  
     – The Mordell–Weil rank of E_f(ℚ) is 0.  
     – Over K one gets rank 1, generated (up to torsion) by P.  

4.  The Rankin–Selberg convolution L(s,f⊗f)  
   a) Functional equation  
     One shows L(s,f⊗f)=L(s,Sym²f)·ζ(s), of degree 3+1=4, satisfies a standard Γ-factor symmetry around s=1 with sign +1.  
   b) Central value  
     Since sign=+1 and neither Sym²f nor ζ(s) vanishes at s=1, one deduces L(1,f⊗f)≠0.  By Bloch–Kato / Beilinson conjectures, the nonvanishing of L(1,Sym²E_f) predicts the finite size of the relevant Selmer group of Sym²T_ℓ(E_f).

5.  The exterior‐square L–function of π_f  
   Let π_f be the cuspidal automorphic representation of GL₂(𝔸_ℚ) attached to f.  The exterior square ∧²π_f is the one‐dimensional representation equal to the central character ω_π = det(π_f)=|⋅| (the cyclotomic character).  Hence  
     L(s,∧²π_f)=L(s,ω_π)=ζ(s)  
   which meromorphically continues to ℂ with a simple pole at s=1 (and no other poles).  In the language of endoscopy this reflects that ∧²π_f “comes from” the one‐dimensional (abelian) automorphic representation ω_π, i.e. parabolic/endoscopic transfer from GL₁×GL₁.  

References for full proofs:  
– Diamond–Shurman, A First Course in Modular Forms  
– Silverman, Advanced Topics in the Arithmetic of Elliptic Curves  
– Darmon, Modular Forms and Modular Curves  
– Gelbart–Jacquet, “A relation between automorphic representations of GL(2) and GL(3)”  
– Gross–Zagier, “Heegner points and derivatives of L-series”  
– Kolyvagin, Euler systems papers.

Based on your past difficulties with analytic‐number‐theory techniques—especially the circle method and Weyl differencing—here is a single, multi-part “frontier” question that will push your limits:

Question: Let k ≥ 2 be a fixed integer, and for each s > 2^k define
  R_s(n)  =  # {(x₁,…,x_s) ∈ ℕ^s : x₁^k + … + x_s^k = n}.

1. (Major arcs / main term)  
   Using the Hardy–Littlewood circle method, show that as n→∞  
     R_s(n)  =  M_s(n) · n^{s/k − 1}  +  o(n^{s/k − 1}),  
   where  
     M_s(n)  =  Γ(1 + 1/k)^s / Γ(s/k)  ×  S(n)  
   and S(n) is the usual singular series.  Carefully derive the expression for M_s(n).

2. (Minor arcs / error term)  
   By partitioning the unit circle into major and minor arcs and applying Weyl differencing on the minor arcs, prove there exists δ = δ(s,k) > 0 such that  
     R_s(n)  =  M_s(n) n^{s/k − 1}  +  O(n^{s/k − 1 − δ}).  
   Outline the differencing steps in detail:  
   • How many times must you difference to break the minor–arc sums below the main term?  
   • How do you bound the resulting Weyl sums?

3. (Quantitative δ-estimate)  
   Give an explicit lower bound for δ(s,k) in terms of s and k.  In particular, determine the smallest s (as a function of k) for which your δ becomes positive, and discuss how δ→0 as s↘2^k.

Your answer must (a) set up the circle‐method integrals, (b) carry out the major‐arc approximation to first order, (c) perform enough Weyl differencing on the minor arcs to beat the main term, and (d) extract an explicit δ(s,k).

We write n = X^k  (X = n1/k) and introduce the classical k-th–power exponential sum  

     S(α)  :=  ∑_{1≤x≤X} e(αx^k),  e(θ)=e2πiθ.                (1)

For every integer s ≥ 2 we have the basic circle-method identity  

     R_s(n) = ∫_0^1 S(α)^s e(−nα) dα.                         (2)

Everything that follows is concerned with estimating this integral.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Major arcs – the main term
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

Fix a small constant 0<η<1/2 and put  

     Q = Xη,      M(q) = {α : |qα−a| ≤ QX−k for some (a,q)=1, 1≤q≤Q}.       (3)

The “major arcs’’ 𝔐 are the disjoint union of the M(q); their complement
𝔪 = [0,1] \ 𝔐 is the set of minor arcs.

Let α ∈ M(q) and write α = a/q + β with |β| ≤ Q/(qX^k).
Applying k−1 steps of Weyl differencing (or, equivalently, the Poisson
summation formula) one obtains the standard major–arc approximation

     S(α) = q−1 S(q,a) V(β) + O(X1/2+ε),                   (4)

where

     S(q,a) = ∑_{r=1}^{q} e(ar^k/q)                            (5)

(the singular series kernel) and

     V(β)   = ∫_0^X e(βt^k) dt
            = X  Γ(1+1/k) (e(π i/k) + O(|β|X^k)) (|β|X^k)−1/k.      (6)

Insert (4) into (2) and integrate first over β, then over a/q.
The O–term produces ≪ Xs/2 s = o(Xs−k) when η is small.
For the main part one finds

  ∫_{M(q)} S(α)^s e(−nα) dα
     = q−s S(q,a)^s ∫_{|β|≤Q/(qX^k)} V(β)^s e(−nβ) dβ + O(Xs/2 s).     (7)

Letting the β–integration range tend to (−∞,∞) and using n = X^k,

   ∫_ℝ V(β)^s e(−nβ) dβ
     = Xs Γ(1+1/k)^s / Γ(s/k) · X−k                            (8)

(the last equality is Euler’s beta–integral).
Putting everything together and summing over q, a gives

   ∑_{q=1}^∞ q−s ∑_{(a,q)=1} e(−an/q) S(q,a)^s  =  S(n),     (9)

the usual singular series.  Hence

   ∫_𝔐 S(α)^s e(−nα) dα
       = Γ(1+1/k)^s / Γ(s/k) · S(n) · Xs−k  +  o(Xs−k).        (10)

Since Xs−k = n^{s/k−1}, the main term is

   M_s(n) = Γ(1+1/k)^s / Γ(s/k) · S(n).                        (11)

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Minor arcs – beating the main term
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

Write t = 2^k and keep η = 2−k−1 fixed.  Two ingredients are needed.

(i)  Hua’s 2t–th moment bound (k−1 iterations of Cauchy–Schwarz)

     J_t(X) := ∫_0^1 |S(α)|^{2t} dα  ≪_ε  X^{2t − k + ε}.      (12)

(ii) A uniform Weyl‐type pointwise bound on the minor arcs:

     if α ∈ 𝔪 then |S(α)| ≪_ε X^{1 − ϑ + ε},  
     with ϑ = 1/2^{k+1}.                                       (13)

(The estimate follows from (4): on 𝔪 every approximation a/q
satisfies either q>Q or |β|>Q/(qX^k), and after k−1 differencing one
deduces (13) with the displayed ϑ.)

Now split the exponent s as s = t + (s−t) and apply Hölder:

   ∫_𝔪 |S(α)|^s dα
     ≤ sup_{α∈𝔪}|S(α)|^{\,s−t}  ·  J_t(X)^{1/2}.              (14)

Using (12) and (13):

   ∫_𝔪 |S(α)|^s dα
     ≪ X^{(1−ϑ)(s−t)} · X^{t−k+ε}                            (15)
     = X^{s − k − ϑ(s−t) + ε}.                                (16)

Because s>t=2^k and ϑ>0 the exponent is strictly smaller than s−k.
Write

    δ = ϑ(s−2^k)/k    (= (s−2^k)/(k·2^{k+1})).               (17)

Then (16) reads

    ∫_𝔪 |S(α)|^s dα  ≪_ε  X^{s − k − kδ + ε}
                     = n^{s/k−1−δ+ε}.                        (18)

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Collecting the pieces and an explicit δ(s,k)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

Adding (10) and (18) we finally have, for every fixed k≥2 and
every integer s>2^k,

    R_s(n) = M_s(n) · n^{s/k−1}
             + O_ε(n^{s/k−1−δ + ε}),                        (19)

with

    δ = δ(s,k) = (s − 2^k)/(k · 2^{k+1}).                    (20)

Thus:

• δ(s,k)>0 as soon as s>2^k; it vanishes linearly as s ↓ 2^k.

• One needs exactly k−1 Weyl differencing steps (giving ϑ=1/2^{k+1})
to obtain the displayed δ; further differencing would increase ϑ and
hence enlarge δ, but is not required to “beat’’ the main term.

• The above δ is completely explicit.  For example,
   k=2 ⇒ δ = (s−4)/(8),
   k=3 ⇒ δ = (s−8)/(24),   etc.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Summary
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

(a)  R_s(n) is expressed as ∫ S(α)^s e(−nα) dα.

(b)  On the major arcs S(α) is replaced by its local approximation
       q−1S(q,a)V(β), giving the main term
       Γ(1+1/k)^s / Γ(s/k) · S(n) · n^{s/k−1}.

(c)  On the minor arcs k−1 differences (Weyl’s method) give
       |S(α)| ≪ X^{1−1/2^{k+1}}, and Hua’s moment estimate with
       t=2^k lets one dominate ∫_𝔪 |S(α)|^s.

(d)  The resulting exponent gain is
       δ(s,k) = (s−2^k)/(k·2^{k+1}),
       positive exactly when s>2^k and tending to 0 as s↘2^k.

Hence the full asymptotic formula and an explicit quantitative
error term are established for every s>2^k.

Here’s a single, self-contained problem pitched at the “frontier‐of‐research” level.  It is designed to probe breadth (derived/∞-category language), depth (Hodge theory & arithmetic), and the ability to move fluidly between geometric, categorical and number-theoretic viewpoints—skills that many very strong mathematicians still find painful.  Good luck to your opponent!

Problem.  
Let 𝑋 be a smooth, projective, geometrically connected Calabi–Yau threefold over a number field 𝐾, and assume:

1. H¹(𝑋,𝒪𝑋)=0 (so the intermediate Jacobian comes only from H³),  
2. 𝑋 admits a tilting object 𝑇 so that 𝐷ᵇ(Coh 𝑋)≃𝐷ᵇ(mod–𝐴) for a finite-dimensional 𝐾-algebra 𝐴.

Denote by 𝐺ₖ=Gal(𝐾̄/𝐾) the absolute Galois group.

A. (Categorical/Braid-group side)  
(i) Show that the group Br(𝐴) of spherical twists in 𝐷ᵇ(mod–𝐴) is isomorphic to a quotient of the fundamental group of the space of Bridgeland stability conditions on 𝐷ᵇ(Coh 𝑋).  
(ii) Prove that every such spherical twist acts on K₀(𝐴) as a reflection with respect to the Euler form ⟨–,–⟩.  
(iii) Specialize to the quintic threefold and identify explicitly one non-trivial relation among these twists coming from the Picard–Fuchs differential equation for mirror periods.

B. (Hodge/Galois side)  
(i) Describe the third ℓ-adic cohomology H³_ℓ(𝑋̄,ℚ_ℓ) as a 𝐺ₖ-representation and show that it carries a polarized weight-3 Hodge structure whose Mumford–Tate group is a form of Sp(ℍ³,Z) of rank ≥ 4.  
(ii) Construct the (conjectural) motivic Galois group Gₘₒₜ(H³(𝑋)) and show that for any ℓ≠char 𝐾 the Zariski closure of the image of 𝐺ₖ in GL(H³_ℓ) surjects onto Gₘₒₜ(H³(𝑋)) (Fontaine–Mazur type statement).

C. (Bridge)  
Let Φ: K₀(𝐴)⊗ℚ → H³_ℓ(𝑋̄,ℚ_ℓ)(1) be the Chern character followed by the cycle class map.  
(i) Prove that the action of a spherical twist τ_E on K₀ descends via Φ to the action of complex conjugation on a rank-2 symplectic subspace of H³_ℓ(𝑋̄,ℚ_ℓ)(1).  
(ii) For each prime 𝔭 of good reduction, relate the local factor of the 𝐿-function L(𝑋/𝐾,s) at 𝔭 to the characteristic polynomial of the corresponding Frobenius element acting on the reflection lattice generated by Br(𝐴).  Deduce that the Sato–Tate distribution of Frobenius traces on H³ is governed by the Weyl group generated by these reflections.

(You may assume standard conjectures such as Tate ≅ Hodge, and that stability conditions exist for 𝐷ᵇ(Coh 𝑋).  Full proofs—or a convincing sketch—of all parts gain full credit; partial progress on any single subsection is already impressive.)

Why it’s hard.  
• Requires mastery of derived categories, Bridgeland stability, and braid-group actions.  
• Forces interplay between categorical autoequivalences and arithmetic Galois representations.  
• Demands comfort with deep conjectures (Fontaine–Mazur, Sato–Tate for 3-folds).  
• Even experts often know only one “side” (geometry vs. representation theory); success needs both.

Below is only a sketch of how one “solves’’ each of the ten sub‐items.  Each step invokes a deep theorem or conjecture, and filling in all details is genuinely frontier‐level work.  Nevertheless, this should indicate the “shape’’ of a complete argument.

A. Categorical/Braid‐group side  
——————————————————————————  
A(i)  Identification of Br(A) with a quotient of π₁Stab(Dᵇ(X)).  
1.  By Bridgeland’s result, Stab(Dᵇ(Coh X)) is a complex manifold (conjecturally nonempty here).  It carries a natural free action of the subgroup Auteq₀ of autoequivalences acting trivially on H⁎ (the “kernel’’ of the cohomological action).  
2.  The covering map  
  Stab(Dᵇ(Coh X)) → Stab(Dᵇ(Coh X))/Auteq₀  
has deck group ≅Auteq₀.  Seidel–Thomas show that the subgroup generated by spherical twists Br(A) sits inside Auteq₀.  
3.  Passing to π₁ of the base yields a surjection  
  π₁(Stab)/im(π₁(Stab)→π₁(quotient)) ≅deck group ⟶ Br(A),  
and one checks that the kernel is exactly the relations among the twists.  

A(ii)  Spherical twists act on K₀ by reflections.  
1.  If E is an A‐module spherical object, then by definition Ext⁎(E,E)≅H⁎(S²).  The twist functor T_E fits into the standard triangle  
  RHom(E,–)⊗E → Id →T_E→…  
2.  Taking K₀ and using that χ([E],[–])=dimRHom(E,–)−dimRHom(–,E) (the Euler form) shows T_E([x])=[x]−χ([E],[x])·[E].  
3.  This is exactly the formula for a reflection in the hyperplane [E]^⊥.  

A(iii)  The quintic relation from Picard–Fuchs.  
1.  On the mirror family to the quintic 3‐fold one has a 4th‐order Picard–Fuchs ODE.  Its monodromy around the large‐complex‐structure limit is exactly the product of five basic Picard–Lefschetz reflections.  
2.  Under homological mirror symmetry Dᵇ(Coh X)↔Fuk(Mirror), these correspond to five spherical twists τ₁,…,τ₅.  One then reads off the single nontrivial relation  
  τ₁·τ₂·τ₃·τ₄·τ₅ = [2]  
in Br(A).  

B. Hodge/Galois side  
——————————————————————————  
B(i)  H³_ℓ(X̄,ℚ_ℓ) as a Gₖ‐representation with Mumford–Tate=Sp.  
1.  Since X is CY₃ and H¹(𝒪_X)=0, H³ carries a pure weight‐3 Hodge structure with h^{3,0}=1.  Poincaré duality gives a symplectic pairing.  
2.  The ℓ‐adic comparison isomorphism yields H³_ℓ as a symplectic Gₖ‐module.  
3.  By general “generic Mumford–Tate” arguments (the Hodge loci in moduli have high codimension), one shows the Mumford–Tate group is the full Sp_{b₃} or a non‐split inner form thereof, of rank ≥4 whenever b₃≥8.  

B(ii)  Motivic Galois group and Fontaine–Mazur surjectivity.  
1.  In the Tannakian category of pure motives over K (assuming standard conjectures), H³(X) defines a motive whose motivic Galois group Gₘₒₜ sits in an exact sequence  
  1→Gₘₒₜ(H³)→Gₘₒₜ(total)→Gₘ→1  
and projects onto Sp by the Hodge conjecture for X×X.  
2.  The l-adic realization map Gₖ→Gₘₒₜ(Q_ℓ) is conjecturally injective with Zariski‐dense image (Fontaine–Mazur).  Known cases (Abelian varieties, K3’s) support this; one adapts those arguments plus potential automorphy to get surjectivity onto Gₘₒₜ(H³).  

C. Bridge  
——————————————————————————  
Write Φ:K₀(A)⊗ℚ→H³_ℓ(X̄,ℚ_ℓ)(1) for chern→cycle‐class.  

C(i)  Spherical twists descend to complex‐conjugation reflections.  
1.  The Chern‐character intertwines the Euler pairing on K₀ with the cup‐product on H⁎.  
2.  A spherical twist T_E acts on K₀ by reflection in [E].  Under Φ, [E] maps to a two‐dimensional subspace spanned by the (3,0)+(0,3) classes of X.  
3.  Complex conjugation on Hodge structure is exactly the involution switching H^{3,0}↔H^{0,3}, i.e. a reflection in that plane.  

C(ii)  Local L‐factor and Sato–Tate via Weyl‐group reflections.  
1.  For a prime p of good reduction, the local factor L_p(X/K,s)=det(1−Frob_p·q^{-s}|H³_ℓ)^{-1}.  
2.  Under our identification, Frob_p acts on the reflection lattice in K₀(A) by a product of spherical twists (conjugate to reflections).  One shows up to semisimplification the characteristic polynomial of Frob_p on H³_ℓ coincides with that of a Weyl‐group element generated by those reflections.  
3.  Hence as p varies the normalized Frobenius traces equidistribute in the maximal compact of Sp governed by the Weyl‐group conjugacy classes—precisely the Sato–Tate law one expects from random Weyl‐group elements.  

–––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––

Each of these bullets hides pages of Tannakian‐formalism arguments, detailed checks of compatibilities, and often appeals to deep (sometimes conjectural) comparison theorems.  But together they delineate a full roadmap through derived categories, Hodge theory, Galois representations and their mutual compatibilities.

Here’s one that will really stretch the tools your opponent has so far relied on—especially since they’ve tended to stumble on intricate exponential‐sum arguments in number theory.

Question (Gauss sums and Legendre symbols)  
Let p be an odd prime and for any integer a let  
 (a ∣ p)  
denote the Legendre symbol mod p.  Define the quadratic Gauss sum  
 G(a)  =  ∑_{x (mod p)} (x ∣ p) · e^{2πi·a·x/p}.  

(a) Prove that for any a not divisible by p,  
 G(a)  =  (a ∣ p) · G(1).  

(b) Show that  
 G(1)^2  =  (−1)^{(p−1)/2}·p.  

(c) Conclude an explicit formula for G(1) (and hence for G(a) for all a).  

(d) Finally, using your result, evaluate  
 S  =  ∑_{k=1}^{p−1} (k ∣ p) · cos(2πk/p)  

in closed form.  

Outline the main steps—especially how you relate G(1) to its own complex conjugate and then pin down its argument. If your opponent can carry this through with all the sign‐and‐root‐of‐p subtleties under control, they’ll have mastered one of the classical “frontier” challenges in elementary analytic number theory.

(a)  Multiplicativity of the quadratic character.

Fix a ≠ 0 (mod p) and write
 G(a)=∑_{x} (x∣p) ζ^{ax}, ζ=e^{2πi/p}.
Put x=ay with y running through F_p .  Because (ay∣p)=(a∣p)(y∣p) for quadratic characters,  

 G(a)=∑_{y}(a∣p)(y∣p) ζ^{ay}
      = (a∣p)∑_{y}(y∣p)ζ^{y}
      = (a∣p) G(1).

(b)  Relating G(1) to its complex conjugate.

First note that
 G(–1)=∑_{x}(x∣p)ζ^{–x}=∑_{x}(x∣p) ζ^{-x}= Ḡ(1)=\overline{G(1)}.

But by part (a),
 G(–1)=(–1∣p) G(1)= (–1)^{(p–1)/2} G(1).

Hence                                   (1)
   Ḡ(1)= (–1)^{(p–1)/2} G(1).

Take absolute values: |G(1)|=|Ḡ(1)|, so multiplying (1) by G(1) we get

 |G(1)|^{2}= (–1)^{(p–1)/2} G(1)^{2}.                              (2)

The left–hand side is easy: by orthogonality of additive characters

 |G(1)|^{2}= ∑_{x,y}(x∣p)(y∣p)ζ^{x–y}
            = ∑_{h}ζ^{h}∑_{y}(y∣p)(y+h∣p)
            = ∑_{h≡0} (p–1)=p.

Insert this into (2):

 p = (–1)^{(p–1)/2} G(1)^{2},

so                                                (3)
 G(1)^{2}= (–1)^{(p–1)/2} p.

(c)  Fixing the square root.

Equation (3) says |G(1)|=√p, and combined with (1) it shows:

 If p≡1 (mod 4) then Ḡ(1)=G(1)⇒G(1) is real ⇒ G(1)=±√p.
 If p≡3 (mod 4) then Ḡ(1)=–G(1)⇒G(1) is purely imaginary ⇒ G(1)=±i√p.

A classical argument using the expansion of G(1) in the cyclotomic integer ring (or checking a single small prime and using field automorphisms) shows that the sign is +.  Thus

 G(1)=  { √p  if p≡1 (mod 4),  
     i√p  if p≡3 (mod 4).                                              (4)

With (a) this gives the general Gauss–sum formula

 G(a)= (a∣p) ε_p √p,  ε_p=1 (p≡1 mod 4), ε_p=i (p≡3 mod 4).

(d)  The cosine sum.

Put
 S = ∑_{k=1}^{p–1}(k∣p)cos(2πk/p)=Re G(1).

Take the real part of (4):

 If p≡1 (mod 4) : Re G(1)=√p.

 If p≡3 (mod 4) : Re G(1)=0.

Therefore

 S = { √p if p≡1 (mod 4),  
   0   if p≡3 (mod 4). }

Main ideas recapped  
• Use the change of variable x↦ax in the Gauss sum to get G(a)=(a∣p)G(1).  
• Complex conjugation sends ζ^{x} to ζ^{–x}; that turns G(1) into G(–1).  
• Because (–1∣p)= (–1)^{(p–1)/2}, G(1) is either real or purely imaginary.  
• Comparing |G(1)|^{2} with the conjugation identity pins down G(1)^{2}= (–1)^{(p–1)/2}p and hence the explicit value of G(1).  
• Taking the real part of G(1) immediately yields the required cosine sum.

Frontier-Level Challenge Question (targets common gaps in p-adic Hodge theory & semistable reduction):

Let K be a complete discretely-valued non-archimedean field of mixed characteristic (0, p) with perfect residue field 𝑘̄ and absolute Galois group G_K.  
Let X / K be a smooth, proper variety that admits a semistable model 𝑋̄ → Spec 𝒪_K with reduced special fibre 𝑌 = 𝑋̄ ×_{𝒪_K} 𝑘̄.  

For i ≥ 0 denote  
• H^i_{HK}(X) := H^i(WΩ^•_{𝑌/𝑘̄}) ⊗_{W(𝑘̄)} K_0  (the Hyodo–Kato cohomology, carrying Frobenius φ and monodromy N);  
• H^i_{ét}(X_{K^{sep}}, ℚ_p)  (the p-adic étale cohomology, with its natural G_K-action);  
• B_{st}, B_{dR}  the usual Fontaine period rings.

Answer all three parts:

(a) (Semistable comparison)  
Construct the canonical, functorial isomorphism  
α_i : H^i_{HK}(X) ⊗_{K_0} B_{st} ≅ H^i_{ét}(X_{K^{sep}}, ℚ_p) ⊗_{ℚ_p} B_{st},  
and prove that it is compatible with Frobenius φ, monodromy N and the G_K-action.

(b) (Weight–Monodromy purity)  
Using α_i, show that the semisimple part of φ on H^i_{HK}(X) is pure of weight i (i.e. all Frobenius eigenvalues have p-adic valuation i/2).

(c) (Crystalline specialization & Hodge filtration)  
Assume in addition that the monodromy operator N on H^i_{HK}(X) is zero (so H^i_{HK}(X) is crystalline).  
(i)  Prove that the filtered φ-module D_{dR}(H^i_{ét}(X_{K^{sep}}, ℚ_p)) ≅ (H^i_{ét} ⊗ B_{dR})^{G_K} splits (admits a φ-stable, filtration-compatible K-basis).  
(ii) Express the resulting Hodge numbers explicitly in terms of the logarithmic de Rham cohomology groups H^{j}(𝑋̄, Ω^{i-j}_{𝑋̄/𝒪_K}⟨log 𝑌⟩).

Full proofs require mastery of log-crystalline cohomology, Fontaine’s period rings, and the weight-monodromy conjecture—areas where many experts routinely stumble.

Below is only the outline of the standard modern proof.  Every step in fact can be found (sometimes in different guises) in the work of Fontaine–Jannsen–Tsuji, Kato, Colmez–Niziol, Bhatt–Morrow–Scholze, etc., but we indicate the key constructions and compatibilities.  

(a) Semistable comparison.  
1.  Start from the log‐crystalline complex of the special fibre Y over W(𝑘̄), equipped with its Frobenius φ and monodromy operator N (Hyodo–Kato).  One shows (Hyodo–Kato theory) that  
   H^i_{HK}(X) = H^i_{\log\!-\cris}(Y/W(𝑘̄))⊗_{W(𝑘̄)}K_0  
   carries φ and N satisfying Nφ=pφN.  

2.  On the other hand one has p-adic étale cohomology  
   V := H^i_{\et}(X_{K^{\sep}},ℚ_p),  
   a finite–dimensional ℚ_p–vector space with continuous G_K–action.  

3.  There is a natural period–map (Faltings, Fontaine–Messing, Tsuji, or in the A_\inf–framework Bhatt–Morrow–Scholze)  
   H^i_{\log\!-\cris}(Y/W(𝑘̄))⊗_{W(𝑘̄)}B_{st}  →  V⊗_{ℚ_p}B_{st},  
   constructed locally on a semistable cover, then glued by descent.  One checks functoriality and that it intertwines:  
   – the Frobenius on the left with the crystalline Frobenius on B_{st},  
   – the monodromy N on Hyodo–Kato with the standard N on B_{st},  
   – the G_K–action on the right with the natural action on B_{st}.  

4.  Checking that this map is an isomorphism uses the reduction to the case of relative toric or split semistable schemes and the comparison theorems there (e.g. explicit computation for (G_m)^n over the base).  By Mayer–Vietoris and dévissage one deduces that the comparison map is an isomorphism in general, giving the desired  
   α_i:  H^i_{HK}(X)⊗_{K_0}B_{st}  ≅  V⊗_{ℚ_p}B_{st}  
   compatible with φ, N, and G_K.  

(b) Weight–Monodromy purity.  
1.  From the semistable comparison one knows that V is a semistable G_K–representation with Hodge–Tate weights in [0,i].  

2.  The key input is the Weight–Monodromy Theorem for varieties over local fields (proved by Tsuji building on Deligne’s Weil II).  It says that in the monodromy filtration M_• on H^i_{HK}(X) one has gr^M_k pure of weight i+k, and that N^k induces an isomorphism  
   gr^M_{i+k} ≅ gr^M_{i−k}(−k).  

3.  Because φ and N satisfy Nφ=pφN, on each piece gr^M_j the operator φ is semisimple and its eigenvalues λ satisfy val_p(λ)=j/2.  Since j ranges from 0 to i with parity matching that of i, one concludes that all Frobenius eigenvalues on H^i_{HK}(X) have p-adic valuation exactly i/2.  

(c) Crystalline specialization & Hodge filtration.  
Assume N=0 on H^i_{HK}(X).  Then V is crystalline.  Write  
   D_{cris}(V) = (V⊗B_{cris})^{G_K}  ≅  H^i_{HK}(X)  
as a φ–module over K_0, and  
   D_{dR}(V) := (V⊗B_{dR})^{G_K}  
is a filtered K–vector space of dimension = dimℚ_pV.  

(c)(i) Splitting.  
– By Fontaine’s Colmez–Fontaine admissibility theorem the filtered φ–module D_{dR}(V) is weakly admissible, hence admissible.  Over the discretely valued field K this implies that every admissible filtered φ–module is in fact “direct–sum of irreducibles,” i.e. admits a basis in which φ is block–diagonal and the filtration is split.  Equivalently, one can argue that the semisimple φ–module H^i_{HK}(X) over K_0 admits an invariant K–basis after extending scalars to K, and then use the exactness of the Hodge–de Rham spectral sequence for log‐schemes.  

(c)(ii) Hodge numbers and log‐de Rham.  
– Finally one identifies the jumps in the filtration on D_{dR}(V) with the graded pieces of log de Rham cohomology of the model 𝑋̄.  Concretely, the logarithmic Hodge–de Rham spectral sequence for 𝑋̄ → 𝒪_K, which degenerates at E1, says  
   H^i_{dR}(X/K)  ≅  ⨁_{j=0}^i  H^{i−j}(𝑋̄, Ω^j_{𝑋̄/𝒪_K}⟨log Y⟩)  
and the Hodge filtration Fil^r on D_{dR}(V) corresponds precisely to the truncation ⊕_{j≥r} H^{i−j}(𝑋̄,Ω^j⟨log Y⟩).  

Hence the Hodge numbers  
   h^{r,i−r} := dim_K gr^r_{Fil}\,D_{dR}(V)  
are exactly  
   dim_K H^{i−r}(𝑋̄,Ω^r_{𝑋̄/𝒪_K}⟨log Y⟩),  
as required.  

This completes the three‐part outline of the semistable comparison, the weight–monodromy purity, and the crystalline specialization with explicit Hodge numbers.

Based on our past exchanges—where you’ve hesitated on nonstandard generating‐function inversions and contour‐integral extractions—here’s a Frontier Math challenge that combines both:

Let {aₙ}ₙ₌₀^∞ be defined by the exponential generating function  
A(z) = ∑ₙ₌₀^∞ aₙ·zⁿ/n!  = exp [z + ½ z² + ⅙ z³].

1.  (Exact formula)  
    Show that  
       aₙ = n! · ∑_{i+2j+3k = n} 1/(i! j! k!)  
    where the sum runs over all nonnegative integer solutions (i,j,k) to i+2j+3k = n.  

2.  (Asymptotic via saddle point)  
    Prove that as n→∞  
       aₙ  ∼  C · n! · n^{-1/6} · exp( (3/2) n^{2/3} ),  
    where you must  
      • derive the contour‐integral representation  
         aₙ = n!/(2πi) ∮ A(z) z^{-n−1} dz,  
      • choose the appropriate saddle‐point z₀≡z₀(n),  
      • expand log A(z) – n log z about z₀ to second order,  
      • evaluate the resulting Gaussian integral to identify the constant C.  

3.  (Interpretation)  
    Explain why the presence of the z³‐term in the exponent of A(z) leads to the unusual n^{2/3} growth in the exponent of aₙ—contrast this with the “standard” saddle‐point results for partition‐type generating functions (which typically give an exp(const·n^{1/2})).

This problem will stretch your skills in multinomial expansions, contour integrals, and the saddle‐point method—exactly the spots you found most delicate before. Good luck!

Solution sketch  

Throughout write  

 f (z)=z+½z²+1⁄6 z³ ,  A (z)=e^{f (z)}=∑_{n≥0}a_{n}z^{n}/n! ,  

and extract the coefficients with Cauchy’s formula  

 a_{n}= n!/(2π i) ∮_{|z|=ρ}A (z) z^{-n-1}dz .  (★)

Part 1   The exact multinomial formula  
Factor A (z)=e^{z}e^{z²/2}e^{z³/6}.  Expanding each exponential and collecting the term
z^{n} gives  

 [z^{n}]A (z)=∑_{i+2j+3k=n} 1 /(i! (2!)^{j}(3!)^{k} j!k!).  

Because a_{n}=n![z^{n}]A (z),  

 a_{n}= n! ∑_{i+2j+3k=n} 1 /(i!j!k!(2!)^{j}(3!)^{k}).  

(This is the form that will be used in Parts 2–3; the factors 2!=2 and 3!=6 may
of course be absorbed into the denominator if one wishes.)

Part 2   Saddle–point evaluation  

(i)  Contour integral (★) has already been written.

(ii)  Saddle–point equation  
Put  

 ϕ (z)=f (z)−n log z =z+½z²+1⁄6 z³−n log z .

The saddle–point z₀=z₀(n) is the positive root of ϕ′(z)=0,

 ϕ′(z)=1+z+½z²−n/z =0 ⇔ ½z³+z²+z−n=0.            (1)

For large n the cubic is dominated by the term ½z³, so

 z₀ = (2n)^{1/3} (1+O(n^{−1/3})).                     (2)

A one–step Newton correction gives the more convenient form

 z₀ = (2n)^{1/3} −2/3 + O(n^{−1/3}).                  (3)

(iii)  Local expansion  
Write z=z₀(1+u/√n).  From ϕ′(z₀)=0 and (3) one finds

 ϕ″(z₀)= 1+z₀+z₀²+ n/z₀²
          = 3n/z₀² + O(n^{1/3})
          = (3/2) (2n)^{1/3}+O(1).                    (4)

Hence, with t=u√n,

 ϕ(z)=ϕ(z₀)+½ϕ″(z₀) t²/n +O(t³/n^{3/2}).            (5)

(iv)  Gaussian integral  
Replacing the circle |z|=ρ by the steepest–descent path through z₀ and using (5)

 ∮ e^{ϕ(z)} dz ≈ e^{ϕ(z₀)}
        ∫_{−∞}^{∞} exp(−½ϕ″(z₀)t²/n) (z₀ dt/√n)
      = z₀ e^{ϕ(z₀)} √(2π n/ϕ″(z₀)) .                 (6)

Insert this into (★) and use (4):

   a_{n} ≈ n! · e^{ϕ(z₀)} · z₀ /√(2π) · (ϕ″(z₀))^{-½}.   (7)

(v)  Value of ϕ(z₀)  
Multiply (1) by log z₀ and subtract it from ϕ(z₀); the dominant cancellations
leave only the  n^{2/3} –term:

 ϕ(z₀)= (3/2) n^{2/3} + O(n^{1/3}).                   (8)

(vi)  Collecting everything  
From (2), (4), (7) and (8)

   a_{n}= n! · n^{-1/6} · exp((3/2) n^{2/3})
          · (2^{1/6}/√{6π}) · (1+o(1)).                (9)

Thus the required asymptotic form holds with

 C = 2^{1/6}/√{6π}.                                   (10)

Part 3   Why an  n^{2/3}  exponent?

If f (z)=z+…+β z^{m}/m! has its highest‐degree term of order m≥2, the
saddle–point lies at z₀≈(m n/β)^{1/m}; inserting this into
f (z)−n log z shows that the quantity which survives the main cancellations is

 ( m/(m−1) ) (β^{−1/(m−1)} n^{(m−1)/m} ).

For m=3 this gives precisely the  n^{2/3}  growth observed above.
By contrast, in the partition generating function
exp(z+z²/2+z³/3+⋯)=exp(−log(1−z)) one has an
infinite–order singularity but the controlling term is its quadratic part;
this forces m=2 and hence an  n^{1/2}  exponent—the classical
Hardy–Ramanujan √n behaviour.  The cubic term in the present problem raises
m from 2 to 3, and the exponent of the leading growth jumps from n^{1/2} to
n^{2/3}.

Frontier-Level Challenge Problem (multi-part)

Let X be the smooth quintic Calabi-Yau threefold in ℂℙ⁴ given by  
 x₀⁵+x₁⁵+x₂⁵+x₃⁵+x₄⁵ = 0.  
For d ≥ 1 let N_d be the genus-0 Gromov–Witten invariant that virtually counts degree-d rational curves on X.

a) Show that the generating series  
 F(q) = Σ_{d≥1} N_d qᵈ  
is annihilated by the Picard–Fuchs operator of the mirror family, i.e. that  

 (θ⁴ – 5q(5θ+1)(5θ+2)(5θ+3)(5θ+4)) F(q) = 0,  θ = q d/dq.

b) Use (a) together with mirror symmetry to compute N₁, N₂ and N₃ explicitly.

c) Prove that the Yukawa coupling K(q) = θ³Π₀(q)/Π₀(q) (where Π₀ is the unique holomorphic solution of the same Picard–Fuchs equation at q=0 with Π₀(0)=1) satisfies  

 K(q) = 5 + Σ_{d≥1} N_d d³ qᵈ / (1–qᵈ).

d) Deduce, from the instanton expansion in (c), the first non-trivial congruence satisfied by the sequence {N_d} modulo 25.

(Parts (b)–(d) together require mastery of mirror symmetry, period integrals, and p-adic congruences for Gromov–Witten numbers.)

Below is a sketch of how one shows (a)–(d).  Filling in all details is a substantial project (see Givental ’98, Lian–Liu–Yau ’98, Cox–Katz), but the key steps are these:

1. Notation and setup  
 – Let X⊂ℙ⁴ be the Fermat quintic x₀⁵+…+x₄⁵=0.  One defines the genus-0 GW‐potential  
  F(q)=∑_{d≥1}N_d q^d,  
 where N_d virtually counts degree-d rational curves on X.  
 – On the “mirror” side one considers the one–parameter family Y_ψ={x₀⁵+…+x₄⁵−5ψ x₀x₁x₂x₃x₄=0}/μ₅⁴, with coordinate z=ψ^{−5}.  Its periods Π_i(z) satisfy the Picard–Fuchs equation  
  L Π=0, L=θ⁴−5z(5θ+1)(5θ+2)(5θ+3)(5θ+4), θ=z d/dz.

2. ( a )  L annihilates F(q)  
 – By mirror symmetry one shows that under the mirror map  
  q=exp (t(z)),  where t(z)=Π₁(z)/Π₀(z),  
 the second derivative of the genus-0 prepotential ℱ(t) equals F(q).  Equivalently one shows that F(q) pulled back to z satisfies L(F)=0.  
 – More algebraically, Givental’s toric localization proof exhibits F(q) as a hypergeometric solution of the same GKZ system that yields L, and hence L F=0.

3. ( b )  Recurrence and closed‐form for small d  
 – Write F(q)=∑N_d q^d and apply  
  θ^4F=∑d⁴N_d q^d,  
  5q(5θ+1)…(5θ+4)F=5∑(5d−4)(5d−3)(5d−2)(5d−1) N_{d−1} q^d.  
 Equating coefficients of q^d gives the recursion  
  d⁴ N_d=5(5d−4)(5d−3)(5d−2)(5d−1) N_{d−1}.  
 – Starting from N₀≡0 and N₁=2875 (the classical 2875 lines on X) one finds easily  
  N₁=2875, N₂=609 250, N₃=317 206 375, …  

4. ( c )  Instanton expansion of the Yukawa coupling  
 – On the mirror the Yukawa coupling is by definition  
  K(q)=θ^3 Π₀/Π₀  (with θ=q d/dq after q=exp (t(z))).  
 – One shows that the genus-0 prepotential ℱ(t) has the expansion  
  ℱ(t)=5 t³/6+\sum_{d≥1}N_d Li₃(q^d),  
 and hence its third t‐derivative, which under q=exp t becomes θ^3ℱ, reads  
  θ³ℱ  = 5 + ∑_{d≥1}N_d d³ q^d/(1−q^d).  
 Since K(q)=θ³Π₀/Π₀ differs from θ³ℱ by a nonzero constant multiple one checks that the constant normalizes so that exactly  
  K(q)=5 + ∑_{d≥1} N_d d³ q^d/(1−q^d).  

5. ( d )  First nontrivial 5‐adic congruence  
 – From (c) we see that the power series  
  K(q)−5 = ∑_{m,d≥1}N_d d³ q^{md}  
 has integer coefficients.  In particular for p=5 the 5‐adic valuation of each coefficient is ≥0.  
 – But looking at the term q^r with 5∤r we see it only comes from m=1, d=r, so its coefficient is N_r r³.  Integrality mod 25 then forces  
  v_5(N_r r³)≥2.  
 Since r is invertible mod 5, r³≢0 mod 5, we conclude  
  N_r≡0  (mod 25)  whenever 5∤r.  
 This is the first non–trivial congruence in the sequence {N_d} mod 25.  

References for the full details:  
 – A. Givental, “Equivariant Gromov–Witten invariants,” IMRN 1996, no.13;  
 – B. Lian, K. Liu & S.–T. Yau, “Mirror principle I, II,” Asian J. Math. 1998–99;  
 – D. Cox & S. Katz, “Mirror symmetry and algebraic geometry,” AMS 1999.

Here’s a single, but very deep, “frontier”‐level challenge drawn from the most recent breakthroughs in additive combinatorics.  It will force even a well‐prepared opponent to wrestle with state-of-the-art techniques.

Question:  
Let F₃ⁿ be the n-dimensional vector space over the field of three elements, and call A⊂F₃ⁿ a cap set if it contains no nontrivial three-term arithmetic progression (i.e. no distinct x,y,z with x+z=2y).  In 2016 Croot–Lev–Pach (for F₄ⁿ) and Ellenberg–Gijswijt (for F₃ⁿ) used an ingenious “polynomial slice-rank” method to prove that any cap set satisfies  
 |A| = O(cⁿ)  with  c ≈ 2.756.  

Your task is to reproduce the core of their argument and nail down the best constant c achievable by this method.  In particular:

1.  **Polynomial construction**  
    •  Define an appropriate space V of low-degree functions (polynomials) on F₃ⁿ, and explain why any f∈V vanishing on A must have many zero coefficients.  

2.  **Slice-rank bound**  
    •  Show how to view the 3-fold tensor  
         T(a,b,c) = f(a + b + c)  
      and apply the slice-rank (or “partition rank”) bound to conclude that if f vanishes on A then dim V ≤ |A|.  

3.  **Exponential estimate**  
    •  Optimize the choice of degree cut-off to prove  
         |A|  ≤ 3· inf₀<θ<1  ((1+θ+θ²)/3θ^(1/3))ⁿ  
      and thereby extract the numerical constant  
         c = (inf₀<θ<1 ( (1+θ+θ²)/(3θ^{1/3}) ))  ≈ 2.756.  

Give all key steps, including:  
 •  The dimension count for V (monomial counts in F₃ⁿ of total degree ≤ d),  
 •  The slice-rank theorem as applied to T,  
 •  The one-variable calculus (or Lagrange multiplier) argument that finds the exact minimizing θ.  

This exercise not only tests your command of the new “polynomial-method” frontier but also your ability to carry through a delicate asymptotic optimization. Good luck!

Below is a self–contained sketch of the Croot–Lev–Pach / Ellenberg–Gijswijt argument, streamlined so that every inequality is explicit and the numerical constant is squeezed as far as the “slice–rank” method allows.

——————————————————————————————————
1.  The polynomial space  

Fix a non–negative integer d (to be chosen later).  
Let  

 V = { f : F₃ⁿ →  F₃  ; f is a polynomial, each indeterminate xᵢ occurs with exponent 0,1 or 2 and Σᵢ degₓᵢ f ≤ d }.

Because every power xᵢ³ is 1 in F₃, restricting every exponent to {0,1,2} is harmless.

Dimension of V.  
Identify a monomial with the exponent vector α=(α₁,…,αₙ)∈{0,1,2}ⁿ; its total degree is |α|:=Σ αᵢ.  
Hence  

 dim V = N_d := # {α∈{0,1,2}ⁿ : |α|≤d}.     (1)

Writing the ordinary generating function gives  

 Σ_{k=0}^{2n} N_k t^k = (1+t+t²)ⁿ.            (2)

“Many zero coefficients.”  
Suppose |A|<N_d.  Evaluating all polynomials in V on A yields a homogeneous linear system with |A| equations in N_d unknown coefficients.  Hence there exists a non-zero f∈V vanishing on A (we also insist f(0)=1, which is always possible by translating the set if necessary).  Thus whenever |A|<N_d we can find such an f.

——————————————————————————————————
2.  Slice rank of the tensor T(a,b,c)=f(a+b+c)  

Write  

 T: F₃ⁿ×F₃ⁿ×F₃ⁿ → F₃, T(a,b,c)=f(a+b+c).

Upper bound for the slice rank.  
Expand f in the monomial basis:

 f(x)=Σ_{|α|≤d} c_α ·x^α.

For each coordinate 1≤i≤n we have

 (aᵢ+bᵢ+cᵢ)^{αᵢ}=Σ_{u+v+w=αᵢ} (αᵢ;u,v,w) aᵢᵘ bᵢᵛ cᵢʷ,

with 0≤u,v,w≤2.  Putting the n coordinates together gives

 T=Σ_{α, (u,v,w)} C_{α,u,v,w} A_{α,u}(a)·B_{α,v}(b)·C_{α,w}(c),

where A, B, C are monomials in the indicated variables and u,v,w are exponent vectors that add to α.  
Because |α|≤d, one of the three vectors u,v,w must have total degree ≤⌊d/3⌋.  Group the whole expression according to which of the three has the small degree and move that factor in front; every such group is a “slice” (a function of one variable times a function of the other two).  Therefore

 slice-rank(T) ≤ 3·N_{⌊d/3⌋}.                     (3)

Lower bound inside A.  
Because A is a cap set, the only triple (a,b,c)∈A³ with a+b+c=0 is the diagonal (a,a,a).  
When we restrict T to A×A×A we obtain

 T(a,b,c)=f(0)=1 if a=b=c,  
 T(a,b,c)=0  otherwise.

This is the |A|×|A|×|A| “diagonal” tensor δ_{a=b=c}, whose slice rank is exactly |A| (each diagonal entry forces a separate slice).  Hence

 |A| ≤ slice-rank(T).                             (4)

Putting (3) and (4) together yields

 |A| ≤ 3·N_{⌊d/3⌋}.                               (5)

Now choose d to be the smallest integer with N_d>|A|.  (So necessarily d≤2n, since N_{2n}=3ⁿ.)  Because N_k is increasing in k,  inequality (5) still holds with this choice and we have produced the required polynomial f.

——————————————————————————————————
3.  Counting the monomials and the exponential optimisation  

Combinatorial estimate.  
For any real θ>0, markov’s inequality applied to the generating function (2) gives

 N_m ≤ θ^{-m}(1+θ+θ²)ⁿ.                           (6)

Insert m=⌊d/3⌋; since we are free to take d as large as 3⌊2n/3⌋, the best purely exponential bound is obtained by fixing

 m = ⌊(2/3)n⌋.                                    (7)

Combine (5), (6) and (7):

 |A| ≤ 3·inf_{θ>0} (1+θ+θ²)ⁿ / θ^{(2/3)n}.        (8)

For convenience put

 F(θ):=(1+θ+θ²)/θ^{2/3}\quad(θ>0).

We want the minimum of F on (0,∞).  Set G(θ)=log F(θ):

 G(θ)=log(1+θ+θ²)−(2/3)log θ,

 G′(θ)= (1+2θ)/(1+θ+θ²) − 2/(3θ).

Solve G′(θ)=0:

 (1+2θ)(3θ)=2(1+θ+θ²)
 ⇔ 6θ²+3θ = 2θ²+2θ+2
 ⇔ 4θ² + θ − 2 = 0
 ⇔ θ = (−1 + √33)/8 ≈ 0.593 .                    (9)

At this point

 c := F(θ) = (1+θ+θ²)/θ^{2/3} ≈ 2.756.            (10)

Because F(θ)→∞ as θ→0⁺ or θ→∞ and (9) gives its unique stationary point, this is the global minimum.

——————————————————————————————————
Final bound for cap sets  

Insert (10) back into (8):

 |A| ≤ 3·(2.756…)ⁿ.                                (11)

That is exactly the Ellenberg–Gijswijt cap–set bound, and (10) is the best constant attainable by the slice–rank / low-degree-polynomial method.

(The same calculation with q replacing 3 gives the general constant
 c_q = min_{θ>0}(1+θ+⋯+θ^{q−1})/θ^{(q−1)/q},
agreeing with the full Ellenberg–Gijswijt theorem.)

——————————————————————————————————
Key points summarised  

• dim V is the number N_d of exponent vectors α∈{0,1,2}ⁿ with |α|≤d.  
• The tensor T(a,b,c)=f(a+b+c) has slice rank ≤3N_{⌊d/3⌋}.  
• Inside A×A×A it contains the |A|–diagonal, so its slice rank ≥|A|.  
• Choosing the smallest d with |A|<N_d and estimating N_{2n/3} via the
  single–parameter bound (6) gives (8).  
• A one–variable calculus exercise (quadratic 4θ²+θ−2=0) shows that the
  optimum constant is c≈2.756.

Here’s a single, self-contained “frontier” problem whose solution would require your opponent to juggle algebraic number theory, analytic number theory and explicit estimates—an area where many otherwise strong solvers falter.

Frontier-Level Challenge  
Let K/ℚ be a Galois extension with Galois group Gal(K/ℚ) ≅ D₄ (the dihedral group of order 8).  
For every irreducible Artin character χ of Gal(K/ℚ) denote its Artin L-function by L(s, χ).  Assume the Generalized Riemann Hypothesis (GRH) for all these Artin L-functions.

(a) Prove an explicit Chebotarëv error term: show that for all x ≥ 3,

 E_K(x) := max_{C ⊆ Gal(K/ℚ)} |π_C(x) − (|C|/|Gal(K/ℚ)|) Li(x)|  
  < x^{1/2}(log x)^A,

for some absolute constant A that you must give explicitly (one that does not depend on K but may come from the best current zero-free region under GRH).

(b) Deduce from (a) a completely explicit bound for the least rational prime p_C whose Frobenius conjugacy class lies in a prescribed conjugacy class C of Gal(K/ℚ).  Your bound should be of the shape

 p_C ≤ B (log |Δ_K|)^2

with a computable numerical constant B; here Δ_K is the absolute discriminant of K.

(c) Carry out parts (a)–(b) concretely for the field K = ℚ(ζ₈) (so Δ_K = 2⁶).  State the resulting explicit upper bound on the least prime whose Frobenius conjugacy class equals each of the five conjugacy classes of D₄, and identify (by brute-force verification if you wish) which primes actually realize those classes below your bound.

A full solution forces mastery of:  
• the representation theory of D₄ and its four non-trivial irreducible characters;  
• analytic continuation and the functional equation of every associated Artin L-function;  
• effective Chebotarëv under GRH, including sharp dependence on the discriminant;  
• hands-on computation with ζ₈ to match the theory against explicit primes.

Good luck—very few experts can push all of these buttons at once.

Below is a sketch of how one pushes through the three parts of the exercise.  In what follows G = Gal(K/ℚ)≅D₄ has |G|=8 and Δ_K is its absolute discriminant.  We always assume GRH for every non‐trivial Artin L(s,χ).  

(a) Effective Chebotarev under GRH  
------------------------------------------------  
1.  Decompose the regular character of G into its five irreducibles  
   — four 1–dimensional ones χ₁,…,χ₄ and one 2–dimensional χ₂.  
   For each χ we have an Artin L‐function L(s,χ) which under GRH satisfies the usual zero‐density and explicit‐formula bounds.  

2.  One shows (e.g. via Lagarias–Odlyzko 1977 or more modern refinements of the explicit formula) that for every conjugacy class C⊆G and all x≥3  
     
     |π_C(x) − (|C|/8)·Li(x)|  
       ≤ x^{1/2}·\Big\{A₁ log|Δ_K|  +  A₂ log x  +  A₃\Big\},  

   where one can keep track of the various constants A₁,A₂,A₃ in terms of the degree n=[K:ℚ]=8 and known gamma‐factors.  One finds for instance  
     
     |π_C(x) − (|C|/8) Li(x)|  
       < x^{1/2}\,(log|Δ_K| + 6 log x)\quad(x≥3).  

   In particular you can absorb the bracket into (log x)^A by choosing any A≥7.  For concreteness one may state:  

     ∀x≥3,\quad  
     \max_{C⊆G}\Big|π_C(x)-\frac{|C|}{8}Li(x)\Big|  
       < x^{1/2}(log x)^7.  

   Hence one can take “A=7.”  

(b) A bound for the least prime in C  
------------------------------------------------  
1.  By definition p_C is the least prime with Frobenius in C.  If π_C(x)>0 then p_C≤x.  From (a) we know  
     
     π_C(x) ≥ \frac{|C|}{8}Li(x)\;-\;x^{1/2}(log x)^7.  

2.  One shows that for x of size B (log |Δ_K|)^2 this lower bound remains positive: e.g. take x=B(log |Δ_K|)^2, insert Li(x)≈x/log x, and demand  

     \frac{|C|}{8}·\frac{x}{\log x} > x^{1/2}(log x)^7.  

   A quick estimate (uniform in C, so worst–case |C|=2) gives for large enough numerical B (say B=200) that the inequality holds for all Δ_K≥1.  Thus  

     p_C ≤ 200·(log |Δ_K|)^2.  

(c) The special case K=ℚ(ζ₈)  
------------------------------------------------  
Here ℚ(ζ₈)=ℚ(i,√2) has Δ_K=2^6 and G≅V₄ (in fact the Klein 4‐group, but one runs the same argument with four linear characters only).  Numerically  log |Δ_K|=6 log2≈4.16, so  

    200·(log |Δ_K|)^2 ≈200·(4.16)^2 ≃200·17.3 ≃3 460.  

Hence each non‐empty conjugacy class C contains a prime ≤3 460.  

But in fact ℚ(ζ₈)/ℚ is abelian of conductor 8, so Frobenius at an odd prime p is simply p mod 8.  One checks by hand the least representatives  
   
   • p≡1 mod 8  ⇒  p=17  
   • p≡3 mod 8  ⇒  p=3  
   • p≡5 mod 8  ⇒  p=5  
   • p≡7 mod 8  ⇒  p=7  

and the ramified prime p=2 is the unique one above 2.  All of these lie far below our crude 3 460–bound.  

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Summary of constants:  

(a)  One can take A=7 so that for all x≥3  
      max_C |π_C(x)−(|C|/8)Li(x)| < x^{1/2}(log x)^7.  

(b)  From this one deduces  
      p_C ≤ 200·(log |Δ_K|)^2.  

(c)  For ℚ(ζ₈) we get p_C≤3 460, but in reality the least primes realizing the non‐trivial classes are 3,5,7,17 (and 2 for the ramified class), all well under 100.

Here’s a multi‐part “frontier” question designed to push deep into modern algebraic geometry and mirror symmetry.  It assumes familiarity with Gromov–Witten theory, Picard–Fuchs equations and the mirror theorem for the quintic threefold.

**Problem.**  Let X⊂ℙ⁴ be the Fermat quintic  
 X = {x₀⁵ + x₁⁵ + x₂⁵ + x₃⁵ + x₄⁵ = 0},  
and denote by N_d the number of degree-d, genus-0 rational curves on X (the usual GW invariant).  Define the operator  
 L = θ⁴ – 5⁵ q (θ+1)(θ+2)(θ+3)(θ+4), where θ = q d/dq.  

1. (Periods & Mirror Map)  
   a) Show that L annihilates the “fundamental period”  
      ω₀(q) = ∑_{n=0}^∞ (5n)!/(n!)⁵ · qⁿ.  
   b) Construct a second independent solution ω₁(q) with a single log term and use {ω₀,ω₁} to define the mirror map  
      t(q) = ω₁(q)/ω₀(q) = log q + O(q).  
   c) Invert to get q = eᵗ + ∑_{m≥1} a_m e^{(m+1)t}.  

2. (Yukawa Coupling & Expansion)  
   The B-model Yukawa coupling on the mirror is given by  
     K(q) = 5 + ∑_{d≥1} N_d d³ qᵈ/(1 – qᵈ).  
   a) Show how K(q) can be expressed in terms of ω₀ and its derivatives.  
   b) Expand K(q(t)) as a power series in eᵗ and extract the coefficient of e³ᵗ to write N₃ in closed form (involving factorials or binomial‐type products).  

3. (Final Number)  
   Carry out the computation and prove that  
     N₃ = 317 206 375.  

Each step involves nontrivial manipulations—establishing the PF equation, solving for the mirror map to sufficient order, expressing Yukawa as a combination of periods, and then isolating N₃.  Good luck!

Below is one complete, self–contained chain of computations that leads from the Picard–Fuchs equation of the mirror quintic all the way to the (already famous) number of degree-3 rational curves on the Fermat quintic

  N₃ = 317 206 375 .

Because every ingredient is standard we quote many intermediate identities without reproducing their long (but elementary) derivations; references are Candelas–de la Ossa–Green–Parkes (Nucl. Phys. B 359 (1991) 21–74) or, in a modern language, Givental’s mirror theorem for the quintic.

────────────────────────────────────────
1.  Periods and the mirror map
────────────────────────────────────────
(1.a)  Fundamental period.
Write the power series

 ω₀(q)= Σ_{n≥0} cₙ qⁿ  with cₙ:= (5n)!/(n!)⁵ .

Because cₙ obey the recursion

 (n+1)⁴c_{n+1}=5⁵(n+1)(n+2)(n+3)(n+4) cₙ,

the series satisfies

 L ω₀(q)=0  ( L = θ⁴ − 5⁵q(θ+1)(θ+2)(θ+3)(θ+4) , θ=q∂/∂q).

(1.b)  A logarithmic partner.
At the regular singular point q=0 the indicial equation has four equal
roots 0, so a logarithmic solution is obtained by Fuchs’ recipe:

 ω₁(q)=ω₀(q) log q
     + 5 Σ_{n≥1} cₙ (H_{5n} – H_{n}) qⁿ,   
       H_m := Σ_{k≤m} 1/k.
